(b)  The public utility has received written notification from the Village that the customer is exempt from the tax. 
(H)  Books and records: Every taxpayer shall keep accurate books and records, including original source documents and books of entry, denoting the activities or transactions that gave rise or may have given rise to any tax liability or exemption under this section. All such books and records shall, at all times during business hours, be subject to and available for inspection by the Village. 
(I)  Definitions: For the purpose of this section, the following definitions shall apply: 
PERSON: Any individual, firm, trust, estate, partnership, association, joint stock company, joint venture, corporation, limited liability company, municipal corporation or political subdivision of this state, or a receiver, trustee, conservator or other representative appointed by order of any court. 
PUBLIC UTILITIES ACT: The Public Utilities Act, as amended. 
PUBLIC UTILITY: A public utility as defined in section 3-105 of the Public Utilities Act. 
RETAIL PURCHASER: Any person who purchases gas in a sale at retail. 
SALE AT RETAIL: Any sale of gas by a retailer to a person for use or consumption and not for resale. For this purpose, the term "retailer" means any person engaged in the business of distributing, supplying, or furnishing or selling gas. 
(Ord. 5218, 12-15-2003, eff. 2-1-2004) 
3-32-8. - Home rule municipal retailers' occupation tax and service occupation tax. 
(A)  Municipal retailers' occupation tax imposed : A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the business of selling tangible personal property, other than an item of tangible personal property titled or registered, with an agency of the State of Illinois, at retail in the Village of Glen Ellyn at the rate of 1.25% on the gross receipts from these sales made in the course of such business. Such "home rule Municipal retailers' occupation tax" shall not be applicable to the sales of food for human consumption that is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food that has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, syringes and needles used by diabetics, and other items which may be specifically excluded by state law. The imposition of this home rule tax is pursuant to the provisions of section 8-11-1 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(B)  Home rule service occupation tax imposed : A tax is hereby imposed upon all persons engaged in the Village of Glen Ellyn in the business of making sales of service, at the rate of 1.25% of the selling price of all tangible personal property transferred by such serviceman, either in the form of tangible personal property or in the form of real estate, as an incident to a sale of service. Such "home rule Municipal service occupation tax" shall not be applicable to the sales of food for human consumption which is to be consumed off the premises where it is sold (other than alcoholic beverages, soft drinks and food which has been prepared for immediate consumption) and prescription and nonprescription medicines, drugs, medical appliances and insulin, urine testing materials, and syringes and needles used by diabetics, and other items which may be specifically excluded by state law. The imposition of this home rule tax is pursuant to the provisions of section 8-11-5 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(C)  Collection by state: The taxes hereby imposed and all civil penalties that may be assessed as an incident thereto shall be collected and enforced by the Department of Revenue of the State of Illinois. 
(D)  Annual Village Board review: The Village Board shall, as part of the annual budget process, review the uses of the home rule Municipal retailers' occupation tax and home rule service occupation tax and determine the future need for and the amount of the tax. Upon such review, the Village Board shall determine whether the imposition of the tax shall continue at its then current level, or shall be amended or eliminated. It is anticipated that the Village will act upon the results of such review, the tax shall, however, remain in effect until repealed or amended. 
(Ord. 5740, 3-30-2009; Ord. 6101, 12-10-2012; Ord. 6585, 3-12-2018) 
Chapter 33 - MASSAGE ESTABLISHMENTS AND MASSAGE SERVICES 

3-33-1. - Definitions. 
The following words and phrases, as used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them below, unless otherwise indicated by the context: 
EMPLOYEE: Any and all persons other than a massage therapist who render any service for the licensee and who receive compensation directly from the licensee but have no physical contact with customers or clients. 
LICENSEE: The operative of a massage therapy clinic. 
MASSAGE THERAPIST: Any person who, for any consideration whatsoever, engages in the practice of "therapeutic massage" as defined herein. 
MASSAGE THERAPY CLINIC: Any place of business having a source of income or compensation derived partly or solely from massage therapy, where a licensed massage therapist administers therapeutic massage or from where a massage therapist is dispatched to administer "therapeutic massage" as defined in this section. A massage therapy clinic may be located within the home of a licensed massage therapist who has met the requirements of this chapter. A massage therapy clinic also includes schools and institutions for purposes of this chapter. 
OFF PREMISES MASSAGE: The activity of providing massage services by a licensed massage therapist, for a fee, at a location other than at a massage therapy clinic. 
OFFICES WITHIN THE HOME: Offices within the home shall have a room(s) used solely for massage services. This shall mean that the office/treatment room(s) cannot double as a guestroom, child's bedroom, or be used for any other domestic/business purposes. 
PERSONS: Any individual, copartnership, firm, association, joint stock company, corporation, or any combination of individuals of whatever form or character. 
PROFESSIONAL MASSAGE THERAPY ORGANIZATION: An organization that shall require graduation from a "recognized school" as defined in this section or the passing of the National Certification Examination for Therapeutic Massage and Bodywork (NCETMB) for active membership. 
RECOGNIZED SCHOOLS/TRAINING: Any school which meets one or more of the following requirements: 
(A)  A state approved school operating according to state regulations, which has a current license, approval, accreditation and/or certification from the state in which it is located and provides an entry level massage training program consisting of a minimum of 500 hours of in-class work and 100 hours of clinical training, which program shall include anatomy and physiology, kinesiology, ethics, pathology, contraindications, and clinical experience. 
(B)  A massage school program accredited/approved by the Commission on Massage Training/Approval and Accreditation (COMTAA), a current list of which can be obtained through the COMTAA Manager, 820 Davis Street, Suite #100, Evanston, IL 60201-4444. 
(C)  Schools offering correspondence courses and not requiring actual class attendance shall not be deemed recognized schools. All coursework for credit hours shall be completed under the physical supervision of faculty. 
THERAPEUTIC MASSAGE: Therapeutic massage or massage therapy shall be defined to include, but shall not be limited to, joint mobilization techniques, stretches, effleurage (stroking), petrissage (kneading), tapotement (percussion), compression, vibration, friction, nerve strokes, and any reasonable method or pressure on the external soft parts of the body with the hands, elbows, or forearms or with the aid of any mechanical or electrical apparatus or appliance, with or without such supplementary aids as rubbing alcohol, oils, liniments, hot and cold packs, antiseptics, powders, creams, lotions, salt glows, ointments, or other similar preparations commonly used in the practice. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-2. - License required. 
(A)  Massage therapy clinic: It shall be unlawful for any massage therapist, person, association, firm, or corporation to engage in, conduct or carry on, or to permit to be engaged in, conducted or carried on, upon any premises in the Village, the operation of a "massage therapy clinic" as herein defined without first having obtained a license from the Village Cashier after the recommendation of the Village Administrator that such license be issued and the approval of the issuance thereof by the Village Cashier. 
(B)  Separate license: A separate license shall be required for each massage establishment location regardless of whether multiple massage therapy clinics are operated by the same person, association, firm or corporation. 
(C)  Sanitary provisions: It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm, or corporation to operate or conduct any massage therapy clinic which does not conform to the sanitary provisions contained in this chapter or to employ any nonlicensed person or persons as massage therapists. 
(D)  Name on license: It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm, or corporation licensed as provided in this chapter to operate under any name or conduct business under any designation not specified in such license. 
(E)  Employment of massage therapist: It shall be unlawful for any person, association, firm, or corporation to employ as a massage therapist any person who does not hold a current unrevoked and unsuspended Village of Glen Ellyn massage therapist license as outlined in this chapter. 
(F)  Off premises massage: It shall be unlawful for any person or persons to engage in the practice of or attempt to practice off premises massage as a massage therapist for a fee without a license issued pursuant to the provisions in this chapter. 
(G)  Massage therapist advertising: It shall be unlawful for any person to advertise him/herself within the Village as a "massage therapist" without a massage therapist license as defined in this chapter. 
(H)  Massage therapy advertising: It shall be unlawful for any person or establishment located within the Village to advertise "therapeutic massage", "massage therapy clinic", "massage therapy", or "massage" in the Village other than a licensed "massage therapist" and/or a licensed "massage therapy clinic" as defined in this chapter. 
(I)  Massage therapy school: A massage therapy school or institution operated within the Village shall obtain a license and be treated as a massage therapy clinic. 
(J)  Insurance: Any person, association, firm, or corporation shall provide proof of not less than $1,000,000.00 per occurrence professional liability insurance prior to a license being issued. 
(K)  CPR Certification: All massage therapists must provide proof of a current cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) certification for their licenses to be valid and in full effect. 
(L)  Employment by massage therapy clinic: It shall be the responsibility of the license holder for a massage therapy clinic to ensure that each person employed as a massage therapist shall first have obtained a valid massage therapist license as set forth in this chapter. It shall be unlawful for such a clinic to allow a licensed massage therapist to practice other than as defined in this chapter. 
(M)  Penalty for violation: Any person, clinic, or establishment who shall violate any of the provisions of this chapter shall be fined not less than $250.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-3. - License for massage therapy clinic or school. 
Any person desiring to obtain a license to operate or conduct a massage therapy clinic or school shall make application to the Village Cashier upon a form provided by the Village Cashier and pay a nonrefundable filing fee of $200.00 with the exception of not for profit organizations, which shall be exempt from such application fee. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-4. - Application for license for massage therapy clinic or school. 
Any person desiring to obtain a license to operate a massage therapy clinic or school shall set forth on the application the exact nature of the massage therapy to be administered and the proposed place and facilities thereof. In addition thereto, any applicant for a license and each partner or limited partner of an applicant, if a partnership applicant, and each officer and Director of a corporate applicant and any stockholder of a corporate applicant holding more than ten percent of the stock of the corporate applicant, shall furnish the following information and appropriate documentation: 
(A)  Written proof that each individual is at least 18 years of age. 
(B)  All residential addresses for the past three years. 
(C)  The business, occupation, or employment of each individual for the three years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(D)  The previous experience of the individual in massage therapy or similar business. 
(E)  Whether the individual has had any license denied, revoked, or suspended in the Village or in any other Municipality or any state for a massage therapy clinic, the reason therefor, and the business activity or occupation of the individual subsequent to such suspension, revocation or denial. 
(F)  Any conviction, forfeiture of bond, or plea of nolo contendere upon any criminal violation or Village ordinance violation (except minor traffic violations) within a five-year period. 
(G)  If the applicant is a corporation or any partner of any partnership is a corporation, then the name of the corporation shall be set forth exactly as shown in the articles of incorporation, together with the state of incorporation and proof of authority to do business in the State of Illinois. 
(H)  The applicant shall submit his/her fingerprints to be used in completing the investigation. Applicants are required to present themselves for fingerprints to be taken by the Village of Glen Ellyn Police Department. If the applicant is a corporation, fingerprints shall be required of applicant's officers, directors, and any stockholder or stockholders owning in the aggregate more than 20 percent of the stock of such corporation. If the applicant is a partnership, fingerprints shall be required of all general partners and any limited partner owning more than ten percent of the aggregate limited partner interest in such partnership. 
Applicant shall pay a fingerprint fee for each person required to submit fingerprints; provided, in the case of a renewal application, fingerprints and the fingerprint fee shall not be required from a renewal applicant, unless the Village Cashier has reason to believe that the renewal applicant may have reported convictions. 
(I)  Two passport size photographs (one inch by one and one-half inches) of the applicant (head and shoulders area, face forward) shall be provided by the applicant to be used in the identification of the applicant. 
(J)  The Village shall have the right to confirm any of the information asked for or provided in the application, including the fact that an applicant has actually matriculated, attended classes, and successfully completed the requirements from a recognized school. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996; amd. per letter dated 9-10-1997) 
3-33-5. - Processing of application for massage therapy clinic or school. 
(A)  The Village Cashier shall, within 15 days after receipt of an application for a license for a massage therapy clinic or school, refer copies of such application and all additional information to the Village Administrator. The Village Administrator shall cause the various departments of the Village, within 45 days thereafter, to inspect the premises proposed to be operated as a massage therapy clinic or school and make recommendations to the Village Administrator concerning compliance with the ordinances of the Village. 
Upon the receipt of the recommendations of the respective department managers, the Village Administrator shall notify the applicant as to whether his application has been referred to the Village Cashier for approval or disapproval or held for further investigation. The period of such additional investigation shall not exceed an additional 30 days unless otherwise agreed to by the applicant. If the Village Administrator determines that the application shall be forwarded to the Village Cashier, he shall do so with a written statement of his recommendations with respect thereto within 15 days after receipt of all reports of investigations made by the department managers as required hereunder. 
Within 45 days after the receipt from the Village Administrator of his recommendations, the Village Cashier shall act upon the application. Such application shall be deemed to be approved if the Village Cashier has not taken action with respect thereto within such 45-day period. The Village Administrator shall advise the applicant in writing as to whether the application has been granted or denied. If the application is denied, the Village Administrator shall advise the applicant in writing of the reason for such denial. 
The failure or refusal of the applicant to promptly give any information relevant to the investigation of the application or the refusal or failure of the applicant to appear at any reasonable time and place for examination under oath regarding said application or the refusal of the applicant to submit to or cooperate with an inspection required by this chapter shall be grounds for denial of the application. 
(B)  Upon receipt of the recommendations of the respective departments and with the information contained in the application, together with all additional information provided herein, the Village Administrator shall, together with his recommendation with respect thereto, refer the application to the Village Cashier unless the Village Administrator shall find: 
1.  That the operation of the massage therapy clinic or school as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with the applicable laws of the state and the ordinances of the Village; 
2.  That the applicant or any other person who shall be directly or indirectly engaged in the management and operation of the massage therapy clinic or school has been convicted of: a) a felony, b) an offense involving sexual misconduct with children, or c) any provision of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/2-.5 et seq.; or 
3.  That the operation of the massage therapy clinic or school as provided by the applicant, if permitted, would violate the provisions of this chapter. 
(C)  Upon receipt of the recommendation of the Village Administrator, the Village Cashier shall grant such application unless he/she shall find: 
1.  That the operation of the massage therapy clinic or school as proposed by the applicant, if permitted, would not comply with the applicable laws of the state and the ordinances of the Village; 
2.  That the applicant or any other person who shall be directly or indirectly engaged in the management and operation of the massage therapy clinic or school has been convicted of: a) a felony, b) an offense involving sexual misconduct with children, or c) any provisions of 720 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/2-.5 et seq.; or 
3.  That the operation of the massage therapy clinic or school as provided by the applicant, if permitted, would violate the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-6. - Term of license for massage therapy clinic or school. 
Each license for a massage therapy clinic or school, pursuant to this chapter, shall be for an initial term ending June 30 next following the issuance of the license, unless sooner suspended or revoked. Such license must be renewed annually, and any renewal shall be for a term of one year from July 1 through June 30. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-7. - Revocation of license for massage therapy clinic or school. 
Any license issued for a massage therapy clinic or school may be revoked or suspended by the Village Clerk upon direction to do so by the Village Manager. 
(A)  Upon having received a complaint from any person that a massage therapy clinic or school or massage therapist employed by such massage therapy clinic or school has violated any provision of this chapter or any other provisions of any ordinance of the Village or any section of this Code or any statute, rule or regulation of the State of Illinois or any other governmental agency, the Village Manager or his/her designee shall cause written notice of such charge to be served upon the licensee, either by personal service or by certified mail. Notice by certified mail shall be deemed to have been served ten days after the mailing thereof to the licensee's address as shown on the license, in the absence of any other evidence that service by certified mail was accomplished earlier than such ten days. Such notice shall fix a date and time for public hearing by the Village Manager or his/her designee on such charges not less than 30 days from the date of such notice. 
At such public hearing, the Village Manager or his/her designee shall hear such evidence bearing upon the question as may be presented by the complainant and the licensee. 
Each party shall have the right to cross examine witnesses produced by the other party, and each party may be represented by counsel. Such hearing may be continued from time to time by the Village Manager or his/her designee. The Village Manager shall have a stenographic record of the proceedings transcribed, at the cost of the Village. In the event that any party other than the Village, or an officer or employee thereof, desires a copy of such transcript, he shall pay the cost to the Village of such transcript, including the cost of the court reporter's attendance charges. 
Based upon the evidence taken at such hearing, the Village Manager or his/her designee shall make findings of fact. If the evidence has been heard by a designee, that designee shall also make a recommendation to the Village Manager as to whether the license should be suspended or revoked. Based on the evidence, the findings of fact, and (in appropriate cases) a recommendation, the Village Manager shall make a determination as to whether the license should be suspended or revoked within 30 days after the conclusion of the hearing and shall inform the licensee of that determination in writing. If the Village Manager determines that the license should be suspended or revoked, he shall immediately direct the Village Clerk to suspend or revoke the license. 
The Village Clerk shall, in such cases, suspend or revoke the license within ten days after receiving the manager's direction to do so. These procedures shall apply in all cases heard after these procedures have been adopted, regardless of when the alleged violations occurred. 
(B)  Cause for revocation or suspension shall include the violation of provisions of this chapter or of any criminal statute of the state by the licensee or by an employee of the licensee or any massage therapist employed by the licensee, provided that the violation of this chapter or any criminal law of the state shall not be a cause for revocation or suspension unless the licensee shall have had actual or constructive knowledge of such violation in the exercise of due diligence. It shall also be cause for revocation or suspension that the licensee has made a false statement on any application for permit under this chapter or in the event that the licensee shall refuse to permit any authorized Police officer, Building Inspector, health inspector, Fire Inspector, or other authorized representatives of the Village to inspect the premises or the operations thereof at reasonable times. 
(C)  When any license shall have been revoked for any cause, no license shall be granted to any person for the period of one year thereafter for the conduct of a massage therapy clinic or school on the premises described in such revoked license. 
(Ord. 4886, 11-13-2000) 
3-33-8. - License for massage therapist. 
Any person who engages in the practices of a "massage therapist" as herein defined shall file an application for a license as a massage therapist, which application shall be filed with the Village Cashier along with a nonrefundable filing fee of $30.00 for the original application and $30.00 for each renewal application. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-9. - Qualifications for massage therapist. 
Any person filing an application for a license as a massage therapist shall provide proof of meeting at least one of the following qualifications: 
(A)  Proof of active member status in a "professional massage therapy organization" as defined in this chapter; 
(B)  Successful completion of a professional level entry program which consists of 500 hours or more of in-classroom study in addition to 100 hours or more of clinical experience in a recognized school; or 
(C)  Successful completion of the national certification examination for therapeutic massage and bodywork (NCETMB) administered by the national certification program for therapeutic massage and bodywork, which is approved by the National Commission for Certifying Agencies (NCCA), the accrediting arm of the National Organization for Competency Assurance (NOCA). 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-10. - Application for license for massage therapist. 
The application for a license for a massage therapist shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable filing fee of $30.00 plus the current fingerprint fee and contain the following information and appropriate documentation with respect to the applicant: (per letter dated 4-28-1998) 
(A)  Name and residence. 
(B)  Social security number. 
(C)  Written evidence that the applicant is at least 18 years of age. 
(D)  Business, occupation, or employment of the applicant for three years immediately preceding the date of application. 
(E)  Whether the applicant has ever been convicted of, pleaded nolo contendere to, or suffered a forfeiture of bond on a charge of committing any violations of the Village ordinances or state statutes (except minor traffic violations). In the event any answer is in the affirmative, then the applicant shall state the place and court in which such conviction, plea or forfeiture was had, the specific charge and the sentence imposed as a result thereof. 
(F)  Transcript and copy of diploma or certificate of graduation from a recognized school or, in the case of an NCETMB certificate, a copy of the current certificate. 
(G)  Fingerprints, to be taken by the Village of Glen Ellyn Police Department. 
(H)  Two passport size photographs (one inch by one and one-half inches) with head, shoulders area and face forward. 
(I)  A signed medical report of a negative TB test by a medical doctor or the Director of the Public Health Department. 
(J)  Proof of current cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) certification. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-11. - Processing of application for massage therapist. 
(A)  The Village Cashier shall refer all applications to the Village Administrator within 15 days after receipt thereof. The Village Administrator shall cause the various departments of the Village government to conduct an investigation to determine if the applicant possesses the qualifications required by this chapter. Upon the receipt of the recommendations of the respective department heads, the Village Administrator shall notify the applicant as to whether the application has been referred to the Village Cashier for his/her approval or disapproval or held for further investigation. The period of such additional investigation shall not exceed an additional 30 days unless otherwise agreed to by the applicant. The Village Administrator shall advise the applicant in writing as to whether the application has been denied and if so, shall advise the applicant in writing the reason for such denial. 
(B)  The failure or refusal of the applicant to promptly give any information relevant to the investigation of the application or the refusal or failure of the applicant to appear at any reasonable time and place for examination under oath regarding said application shall be grounds for denial of the application. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-12. - Term of license for massage therapist. 
Each license for a massage therapist, pursuant to this chapter, shall terminate on June 30 following its issuance, and any renewal shall be for a one year term commencing July 1 and ending June 30 thereafter and shall be carried by the license holder while engaged in his or her employment. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-13. - Revocation of license for massage therapist. 
A license for a massage therapist may be revoked or suspended where it appears that the massage therapist has been convicted of any offense which would be cause for a denial of a license upon an original application, has made a false statement on an application for a license, or has committed an act in violation of this chapter. The Village Administrator or his/her designee shall give the license holder a written notice specifying the grounds of suspension or revocation. The license holder may, within 15 days after the date of such revocation or suspension, file a written request for public hearing, which hearing shall be scheduled within 15 days after receipt of the request from the license holder, who, at said hearing, may present evidence bearing upon the question. The Village Administrator shall then, within five days after the date of hearing, issue a written order as to whether the license shall be revoked or suspended. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-14. - Necessary facilities. 
No massage therapy clinic or school shall receive a license or be operated, established, or maintained, unless the establishment shall comply with each of the following minimum regulations: 
(A)  All massage tables, bathtubs, shower stalls, and bath areas shall have surfaces which may be readily disinfected. 
(B)  Suitable bathing, dressing, locker, toilet, and massage room facilities shall be provided for all patrons in the event that both female and male patrons are served simultaneously. 
(C)  All equipment used in contact with patrons must be maintained in a clean and sanitary manner. 
(D)  Toilet facilities shall be provided in convenient locations. When five or more employees or patrons of different sexes are on the premises at the same time, separate toilet facilities shall be provided. Lavatories or washbasins shall be provided with both hot and cold running water and shall be installed in either the toilet room or vestibule. Lavatories or wash basins shall be provided with soap and a dispenser with sanitary towels. 
(E)  Closed cabinets shall be provided for use in the storage of clean linens, towels, and other materials used in administering massages. All soiled linens, towels, and other materials shall be kept in properly covered containers or cabinets which shall be kept separate from the clean storage areas. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-15. - Operating requirements. 
(A)  Every portion of the massage therapy clinic or school, including appliances and apparatus, shall be kept clean and operated under sanitary conditions. 
(B)  Price rates for all services shall be prominently posted in the reception area in a location available to all prospective customers. 
(C)  All employees, including massage therapists, shall wear clean, nontransparent outer garments, and such outer garments shall be restricted in use to the massage therapy clinic or school. 
(D)  Doors to the dressing rooms shall open inward and shall be self-closing. 
(E)  All massage therapy clinics and schools shall be provided with clean laundered sheets and towels in sufficient quantity and shall be laundered after each use thereof and stored in a sanitary manner. 
(F)  The sexual or genital areas of patrons must be covered with towels, cloths, or undergarments when in the presence of an employee or massage therapist. 
(G)  It shall be unlawful for any person in a massage therapy clinic or school to place his or her hand upon or to touch with any part of his or her body or to fondle in any manner or to massage a sexual or genital area of any person. 
(H)  No massage therapist or employee or licensee shall perform, offer, or agree to perform any act which shall require touching of a patron's genital area. 
(I)  All walls, ceilings, floors, pools, showers, baths, and steam rooms and any other physical facilities shall be in good repair and maintained in a clean and sanitary condition. 
(J)  Oils, creams, lotions, and other preparations used in administering massages shall be kept in clean, closed containers or cabinets when not in use. 
(K)  Each massage therapist shall clean his/her hands in a sanitary manner before administering massage to each patron. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-16. - Advertising. 
No massage therapist, clinic, or school holding a license under this chapter shall depict, place, publish, distribute, or cause to be depicted, placed, published or distributed any advertising matter that suggests to prospective patrons that any services are available other than those services permitted by this chapter or which would suggest that employees or massage therapists are dressed in any manner other than that permitted by this chapter; and all advertisements shall contain the number of the Village license held by the massage therapist, clinic, or school. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-17. - Outcall registration. 
Any massage therapist who provides any of the services provided in this chapter at any hotel or motel must first register his or her name and license number with the owner, manager, or person in charge of such hotel or motel. No outcall massage service may be operated other than by a licensed clinic, and each outcall massage service must be performed within the manner provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-18. - Inspection. 
The Police Department, Fire Inspector, and Building Inspector shall from time to time, and at least twice a year, make inspections of each massage therapy clinic or school granted a license under the provisions of this chapter for the purpose of determining compliance with the provisions of this chapter. Such inspections shall be made at reasonable times and in a reasonable manner. It shall be unlawful for any licensee to fail to allow such inspection officers access to the premises or to hinder such inspection officers in any manner. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-19. - Employment. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner, operator, proprietor, manager, or other person in charge of any massage therapy clinic or school to employ any person who is not at least 18 years of age. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-20. - Transfer of license. 
No permit for operation of a massage therapy clinic or school shall be transferable. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-21. - Display of license. 
Each licensee shall display a valid current license in a conspicuous place within the massage therapy clinic or school so that the same may be readily seen by persons entering the establishment. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-22. - Exceptions. 
The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to: 
(A)  Massage therapy provided in a state licensed and approved hospital or nursing home or by persons working under the direction of an individual holding an unrevoked certificate to practice the healing arts under the laws of the state in the aforementioned facilities. 
(B)  Any person who shall be registered as a physical therapist by the state under the provisions of 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes 90/1. 
(C)  Any state registered athletic trainer who administers athletic related massage in the normal course of training duties. 
(D)  Any barber, cosmetologist, or aesthetician lawfully carrying on his/her respective business to the extent authorized under a valid unrevoked license or certificate of registration issued by the state, provided this exemption is only intended to permit normal and customary barber, cosmetologist, or aesthetician services which involve incidental physical contact, such as scalp rubs and facials, which otherwise qualify as massage activities. This exemption is not intended and does not permit general massage activities as part of any barber, cosmetologist, or aesthetician business beyond that authorized by his/her state license or certification. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-23. - Grandfather clause. 
Notwithstanding the requirements of the preceding sections of this chapter, a massage therapist licensed as such by the Village on or before June 10, 1996, who does not meet the qualifications outlined in subsections 3-33-9(A) through (C) of this chapter will be allowed to renew his/her license on an annual basis provided there is full compliance with all other applicable requirements within this chapter and provided said massage therapist's license has been maintained on a continuous basis and has not been allowed to lapse and has not been either canceled, revoked, or suspended. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-24. - Violation and penalty. 
Any person who violates any section of this chapter shall, upon conviction thereof, be punished by a fine of not less than $250.00 nor more than $500.00 for each offense. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
3-33-25. - Severability. 
If any section, subsection, paragraph, or part of this chapter is for any reason held to be unconstitutional or invalid by any final court of competent jurisdiction, such decision shall not affect the validity or effectiveness of the remaining portions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 4385, 6-10-1996) 
Chapter 34 - CABLE COMMUNICATIONS CODE 

3-34-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known as and may be cited as the Village of Glen Ellyn Cable Communications Code. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-2. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(A)  Provide for the franchising and regulation of community antenna television systems and other similar cable communication systems within the Village of Glen Ellyn; and 
(B)  Provide for the payment of a fee and other valuable consideration to the Village of Glen Ellyn for the use by a franchisee of Village streets and other public ways in the construction and operation of a community antenna television system or other similar cable communications system, and to compensate the Village of Glen Ellyn for costs associated therewith; and 
(C)  Provide for the regulation by the Village of Glen Ellyn of the rates and fees to be charged by the franchisees granted a franchise pursuant to the terms and the provisions of this chapter; and 
(D)  Provide for the development of a community antenna television system or other cable communications system as a means to improve communication between and among the citizens and public institutions of the Village of Glen Ellyn; and 
(E)  Provide remedies and prescribe penalties for violation of this chapter and the franchises granted hereunder. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-3. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different sense, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
AGENCY: The person, department or agency designated by the corporate authorities of the Village of Glen Ellyn to act in matters related to cable television or in the absence of such designation, the corporate authorities. 
BOARD: The Village President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Glen Ellyn, which constitutes the corporate authorities of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
CABLE COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION OR COMMISSION: The Village of Glen Ellyn Cable Communications Commission, as defined and established by section 2-15-1 of this Code. 
CABLE COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM OR SYSTEM OR CATV SYSTEM: A system composed of, without limitation, antennas, cables, wires, lines, waveguides, laser beams, satellites, earth stations, microwave links, towers, amplifiers, conductors, converters, equipment or facilities which are designed, constructed or wired for the purpose of producing, receiving, amplifying, storing, processing or distributing by coaxial cable, digital, fiber optics, microwave or other means, audio and/or visual, radio, television, electronic or electrical signals to and from subscribers, exclusive of any facility that is designed and operated to serve only subscribers in one or more multiple-unit dwellings under common ownership, control or management and which does not use Municipal rights of way. 
CHANNEL: A band of frequencies six or less megahertz wide in the electromagnetic spectrum capable of clearly and effectively carrying an audio data signal or an audiovisual television signal, digital signals or other electronic signals or some combination thereof, and as defined by the Federal Communications Commission rules and regulations. 
COMPANY: An individual franchisee to whom a franchise has been granted under the terms and provisions of this chapter, its successors and assigns, its present subsidiaries and affiliates, and its parent companies. 
CONVERTER: An electronic device provided by a franchisee which converts signals to a frequency not susceptible to interference within a television receiver of a subscriber, and by an appropriate channel selector also permits subscriber to receive all signals delivered at the designated dial locations. 
CORPORATE AUTHORITIES: The Village President and Board of Trustees of the Village of Glen Ellyn acting in their capacity of the corporate authority of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
EDUCATIONAL ACCESS CHANNEL: Any channel designated for use by local educational authorities. 
FM SERVICES: Broadcast of audio signals only on a broadband standard FM frequency. 
FEDERAL COMMUNICATIONS COMMISSION OR FCC: The Federal Communications Commission established by the communications act of 1934, as amended from time to time, and shall include any successor agency or other agency with respect to the federal regulation and licensing of cable communications systems. 
FRANCHISE: The nonexclusive rights granted pursuant to the terms and provisions of this chapter, as described and limited in an ordinance granting a franchise to a franchisee, to construct and operate a cable television system along the public ways in the Village of Glen Ellyn, or within specified areas in said Village, and is not intended to include any license or permit required for the privilege of transacting and carrying on a business within said Village, as may be required by other ordinances and laws of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
FRANCHISEE: The natural person, partnership, domestic or foreign corporation, association, joint venture, or organization of any kind granted a franchise under this chapter, and including its lawful successor, transferee, assignee, any and all subsidiaries and affiliates and its parent companies. 
LEASED ACCESS CHANNEL: Any channel available for lease, at fair and nondiscriminatory rates, on a first come, first serve nondiscriminatory basis. 
LOCAL ORIGINATION CHANNEL: Any channel programmed by the franchisee including automated program services. 
PERSON: Any individual, firm, partnership, limited partnership, association, corporation, company, or organization of any kind. 
PROPERTY OF THE COMPANY OR PROPERTY OF THE FRANCHISEE: All property owned, leased, installed or used by the company or franchisee in the conduct of a cable communications system. 
PUBLIC ACCESS CHANNEL: Any channel available to the general public for programming on a first come, first serve, nondiscriminatory, noncommercial basis. 
REGULAR SUBSCRIBER SERVICE RATES OR FEE: The monthly or other periodic charge for the availability of the system services to a subscriber, and includes any number of channels up to the maximum channels incorporated within the system, but excludes any premiums for FM radio services, pay per view fees, or premium pay television services. 
REVENUE: All revenue derived directly or indirectly by a franchisee from the operation or use of all or part of a community antenna system or cable communications system franchise pursuant to this chapter, whether that revenue is derived by the franchisee, its affiliates, subsidiaries, parents, or any person or firm of which the franchisee has a financial interest including, but not limited to, the following: 
(A)  Revenue from regular subscriber service fees, whether that fee is paid monthly or otherwise; 
(B)  That portion of receipts from programs from which a per channel or per program charge is made; 
(C)  Any and all revenue derived from any service fee charged for use of the system to transmit electronic or microwave impulses; 
(D)  Revenue derived as advertising income; 
(E)  Revenue from the leasing of cable channels; 
(F)  Revenue received for equipment rentals, including the rental of converters, studio equipment, studio facilities, fixed or mobile production equipment; 
(G)  Revenue received for furnishing other communications and nonbroadcast services either directly or as a carrier or another party, provided that revenues derived from the delivery of communication and nonbroadcast services shall be deemed to be equal to the system cost of providing such services. 
(H)  Revenue derived from the sale of personal property, including catalog sales conducted via cable communications system, data transmission, alarm or signal transmission; 
(I)  Receipts derived from installation, reconnection, inspection, repairs or modifications of any cable installation; 
(J)  Personnel fees received for services of personnel hired by others; provided however, that gross revenue shall not include any taxes on services furnished by the franchisee imposed directly on any subscriber or user by the state, or local governmental unit and collected by the franchisee on behalf of such governmental unit or, refer to that portion of advertising or leased access revenue dedicated for support of local programming. 
SCHOOLS: All public, private, elementary and secondary schools, junior colleges, colleges and universities which have been granted a certificate of recognition by the Illinois State Board of Education, pursuant to section 2-3.25 of the Illinois School Code (1979). 
STREET: The surface of and the space above and below any public place, street, right of way, road, highway, freeway, bridge, lane, path, alley, court, sidewalk, parkway, drive, communications or utility easement, or other dedicated public way of any kind whatsoever, now or hereafter existing as such within the franchise area, which shall entitle the Village of Glen Ellyn and the franchisee to the use thereof for the purpose of installing and maintaining a franchisee's cable communications system. Provided, however, that no reference herein, or in any ordinance granting a franchise, to a "street" or "public way" shall be deemed to be a representation or guarantee of the Village that its title in and to any property or easement is sufficient to permit its use for the installation of a cable communications system, and the franchisee shall be deemed to gain only such rights to use property in the Village as said Village may have the undisputed right and power to give. 
SUBSCRIBER: Any person who receives any regular or other service from a franchisee. 
TWO-WAY SERVICE OR INTERACTIVE SERVICE: The subscriber or any other location shall have the capability to choose whether or not to respond immediately or by sequential delay by utilizing any type of terminal equipment whatever, by push button code, dial code, meter, voice, video including, but not limited to, audio and video, electrical or mechanically produced signal, display and/or interrogation. 
USER: A person or organization utilizing a system channel or system equipment and facilities for purposes of production and/or transmission of material, as contrasted with receipt thereof in a subscriber capacity. 
VILLAGE: The Village of Glen Ellyn, and where appropriate, the corporate authorities of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-4. - Principles of construction. 
This chapter shall be construed and applied in accordance with the following principles: 
(A)  All ordinances or parts thereof in conflict with the provisions creating this chapter are to that extent hereby repealed. 
(B)  In connection with all actions and decisions to be taken or made under this chapter by the Village or a company to whom a franchise is granted, due consideration shall be given the respective interests of the Village, the company, subscribers and potential subscribers. Actions and decisions shall include, but not be limited to, increasing rates or otherwise amending this chapter. In the event of conflict of interest between potential subscribers and the interest of the Village, the company and subscribers, the interest of potential subscribers, except for potential subscribers who have not refused system service when available, shall be secondary to the interest of the Village, the company and subscribers. 
(C)  To the extent that any fee or monetary payment by a franchisee or another person under this chapter shall be declared or found to be excessive as it relates to a license or franchise, such fees or monetary payments shall be considered to be taxes. 
(D)  Words in the present tense include the future. 
(E)  Words importing the singular number may extend to and include plural, words importing the plural number may extend to and include the singular, and words in masculine gender shall include female gender. 
(F)  The specifications in this section of principles to apply in the construction of this chapter shall not be a limitation to other accepted principles of statutory construction. 
(G)  The general provisions of this chapter may be specifically waived in whole or in part for a particular franchisee, but only be a specific reference in an ordinance granting a franchise. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-5. - Requirement of a franchise. 
A person or entity, including a telecommunications carrier, seeking to provide cable service or video service shall not use the public rights of way for the installation or construction of facilities for the provision of cable service or video service or offer cable service or video service until it has obtained either: a) a state issued authorization to offer or provide cable or video service under section 401 of the cable and video competition law of 20071; or b) a cable franchise from the Village under the provisions of this chapter and section 11-42-11 of the Illinois Municipal Code. 
(Ord. 5622, 10-22-2007) 
3-34-6. - Unauthorized activities. 
The following actions or omissions by any person, corporation or unincorporated association shall be deemed to be unlawful and constitute a nuisance subject to the general penalty provisions contained in title 1, chapter 4 of this Code: 
(A)  The making of an unauthorized connection, whether physically, electronically, acoustically, inductively or otherwise with any part of a cable communication system operated within the Village of Glen Ellyn for the purpose of taking or receiving television or radio signals, pictures, programs or sounds, or for the purpose of enabling others to receive such signals, pictures, programs or sounds. 
(B)  The wilful tampering with, removal of, or injury to any cable, wires or equipment used for distribution of television or radio signals, pictures, programs or sounds without consent of the system owner. 
(C)  The reselling, without the prior written consent of both the franchisee and the board, of any cable service, program or signal transmitted by a cable communications system operated under a franchise granted pursuant to this cable communications ordinance. 
(D)  Any person, corporation or unincorporated association committing any of the unauthorized activities set forth in this chapter shall be deemed to be guilty of a misdemeanor and each and every day or portion thereof during which any violation of any of the provisions of this section is committed, or continued, or permitted shall be deemed a separate offense and upon conviction of any such violation such violator shall be punishable by a fine of not more than $500.00 or by imprisonment not exceeding six months. Any equipment or structure erected or maintained and any work commenced or continued in violation of this chapter shall be and is hereby declared unlawful and a nuisance. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-7. - Franchise application procedure. 
Applications for a cable communications franchise within the corporate limits of the Village of Glen Ellyn shall be made in accordance with the following procedures: 
(A)  After the effective date hereof, any person seeking a grant of a nonexclusive franchise to operate a cable communications system within the Village of Glen Ellyn shall submit an application in writing to the Village Clerk, who shall forward that application to the Cable Communications Advisory Commission for consideration. 
(B)  The application shall be in writing and shall contain information meeting the requirements of the procedures established by the Commission. 
(C)  The application shall be accompanied by a nonrefundable application fee in an amount determined from time to time by the Commission, which amount shall be reasonably determined to offset direct expenses incurred by the Village in the evaluation procedures, including, but not limited to, staff time and consulting assistance. 
(D)  All applications for a franchise shall be considered by the Commission in accordance with procedures and schedules established by the Commission. Following the consideration by the Commission, a report concerning any application shall be submitted to the corporate authorities. The report may be that no franchises or additional franchises are necessary or desirable to meet the needs of the Village. 
(E)  The corporate authorities shall consider any report and recommendation of the Commission and in addition shall consider the financial, technical, programming and rate proposals, as well as the legal and character qualifications of any applicant, and may or may not enter into negotiations with any applicant towards the end of obtaining a one or more cable communications system best suited to the unique needs and interest of the Village. The corporate authorities may, by ordinance, grant one or more nonexclusive franchises creating a right to construct and operate a community antenna television system or similar cable communications system within the public ways of the Village. One or more franchises may be granted to any applicant(s) which in the board's judgment may best serve the public interest; provided, however, no provision of this chapter shall be deemed or construed as to require the board to grant a franchise to any applicant. 
(F)  Prior to the enactment of the ordinance creating this chapter, the Village of Glen Ellyn requested interested companies to submit proposals for cable television service to the Village, and in response thereto a number of persons submitted applications. Each of those applications that were timely filed are hereby deemed to be in compliance with this section of this chapter and the report and recommendation heretofore made to the corporate authorities shall be deemed to be in full compliance with the provisions of this chapter and to give the corporate authorities the power to negotiate with any applicant who filed a response to the request for proposal. 
(G)  Any applicant to whom the Village of Glen Ellyn grants a nonexclusive franchise shall, in addition to the nonrefundable fee specified hereinabove, pay to the Village, at the time that the franchisee accepts the grant of franchise, an amount to be determined by the board to be a reasonable amount to reimburse the Village for all direct, reasonable expenses actually incurred by the Village in granting a franchise, which are not defrayed by the fees received with the application. Those reasonable expenses may include attorney fees, consulting fees, hired testing services and the reasonable value of staff time. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-8. - Franchise term and nonexclusivity. 
The term of an original franchise shall be no more than 15 years from the date the franchise is granted to a successful applicant. The term of a renewed franchise shall be no more than 15 years. No franchise granted pursuant to this chapter should give any exclusive right to a franchisee and every such franchise shall be deemed to reserve the right to grant other franchises to use and occupy the streets and public ways of the Village, for a community antenna television system, other cable communications system or any other purpose on such terms as the corporate authorities may, from time to time, deem appropriate. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-9. - Notice to the franchisee. 
Except for mandatory performance evaluation sessions required by this chapter, the Commission or the corporate authorities shall not take any final action involving the evaluation, modification, renewal, revocation or termination of the franchisee or the franchise granted hereunder unless the following conditions are met: 
(A)  A meeting has been called for the purpose of taking such action; 
(B)  The franchisee has been served at its local office with notice in writing at least 30 days prior to the meeting, as to its time, place and purpose; 
(C)  Notice has been published, at least once, no more than 15 nor less than seven days before the meeting in a newspaper of general circulation within the Village with any cost of publication to be paid by the franchisee; and 
(D)  The franchisee and any interested person are given an opportunity to be heard at such meeting. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-10. - Franchise review and modification. 
It shall be the policy of the Village to amend a franchise upon application of a franchisee, when necessary to enable a franchisee to take advantage of technological advancements which will afford it an opportunity to more effectively, efficiently, or economically service its subscribers; provided, however, that this section shall not be construed to require the Village to make any amendments in a grant of franchise. Further, within the term of the franchise, the corporate authorities may, after notice and hearing as required in section 3-34-9 of this chapter, adopt an ordinance or resolution providing for reasonable and appropriate modifications in a franchise grant ordinance of a nature that would not result in effectively terminating the grant or franchise. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-11. - Performance evaluation sessions. 
Recognizing that the field of cable communications is ever changing, to help achieve a continually advanced and modern cable communication system for the Village, the franchisee shall cooperate with the following review procedure: 
(A)  The Commission and the franchisee shall hold annual franchise performance evaluation sessions within 60 days of the first anniversary date of the effective date of a grant of a franchise, and within 60 days of each subsequent anniversary date of said effective date. All such review sessions shall be open to the public. 
(B)  Franchisee shall be solely responsible for notifying the Commission, in writing, at least 60 days in advance, of each of the annual performance evaluation sessions, and no notice to the franchisee pursuant to section 3-34-9 of this chapter shall be required. 
(C)  Special franchise review sessions may be held at any time during the term of the franchise, at the request of either the Commission or franchisee. All such special franchise review sessions shall be open to the public, and require notice as provided in section 3-34-9 of this chapter. 
(D)  The Commission and the franchisee shall endeavor to announce all review sessions in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village; however, no such newspaper announcement shall be required as to any adjourned meetings. In addition, franchisee shall be obligated to notify all subscribers of any annual or special franchise review session, including adjourned meetings, by an announcement on the highest use origination channel on its system no less than three times between the hours of 7:00 p.m. and 9:00 p.m. for five consecutive days immediately preceding each meeting, with the date, time, place and purpose of such meeting being included in any announcement. 
(E)  The following topics may be discussed at any annual or special evaluation session, but this listing shall not be construed to limit topics or to require such topics to be discussed at each session: service rate structures; franchise fees; penalties; free or discontinued services; applications of new technologies; system performance; services provided; programming offered; local programming; customer complaints; privacy; amendments to this Code concerning cable communications; modifications to the grant of franchise; judicial and FCC rulings; line extension policies; and franchisee's rules and regulations. 
(F)  Prior to and during any annual or special review or evaluation session, the franchisee shall fully cooperate with the Commission or other village officers or employees and shall provide such information and documents as such Commission, other officers and employees may request to reasonably perform its review functions. 
(G)  If at any time during its review, the Commission determines that reasonable evidence exists of inadequate cable communications system performance, it may require the franchisee to perform tests and analysis directed toward the suspected inadequacies. The franchisee shall fully cooperate with the Commission in performing such testing and shall prepare results and a report if requested within a reasonable time, as established by the Commission. Such report shall include the following information, unless expressly waived by the Commission: 
1.  The nature of the complaint or problem which precipitated the special test; 
2.  A description of the system component which was tested; 
3.  The equipment used and procedures employed in the testing; 
4.  The method, if any, in which such complaint or problem was resolved, or a statement that it was not resolved; 
5.  Any other information pertinent to said test and analysis which may be reasonably required or requested by the Commission. 
(H)  Should the Commission require testing as set forth hereinabove in subsection (G) of this section, the Commission may also require the test to be supervised by a professional engineer or other consultant, as selected by the Commission. Should such professional engineer or consultant not be on the permanent staff of the franchisee or the Village then all reasonable expense of such professional shall be paid by the franchisee. The professional may be required to sign all records of special tests and forward such reports, together with any requested report interpreting the results of the tests and recommending actions to be taken, to the Commission. 
(I)  The Commission's right under this section to require tests shall be limited to requiring tests, analysis and reports covering specific subjects and characteristics based upon actual complaints or other evidence when and under such circumstances as the Commission has reasonable grounds to believe that complaints or other evidence require tests be performed to protect the public against substandard community antenna television service or other cable communications service, provided by the franchisee. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-12. - Franchise renewal. 
The term franchise may be renewed in accordance with the following procedures: 
(A)  The franchisee shall be solely responsible for requesting the Commission, in writing, to hold a special meeting for the purpose of reviewing the franchisee's performance during the term of the franchise and to consider renewal of the franchise. Such special renewal review session shall consider the adequacy of the franchise from the standpoint of the Village, the franchisee and the federal communication's rules for cable communications or community antenna television systems and shall determine the advisability of renewing the grant of franchise to a franchisee. Unless the Village Board shall consent to some lesser notice, said request shall be made not less than 30 months prior to the franchise expiration date. Upon receipt of said request, the Commission shall adopt a resolution setting forth the time and place of the special renewal review session. If no request for renewal is made, the franchise shall expire according to its terms, provided, however, that the corporate authorities may extend the term of the franchise in six month increments during the franchise renewal process provided for in this section, but in no event longer than one year after its original term. 
(B)  The Commission shall hear any interested person during said special renewal review sessions and shall make findings of fact as to whether or not the franchisee reasonably complied with the terms and conditions imposed by this chapter, the ordinance granting the franchise, and federal communications commission's rules for community antenna television systems or cable communication systems. 
(C)  Public announcement of such renewal review sessions shall be made in accordance with section 3-34-9 and subsection 3-34-11(D) of this chapter. 
(D)  At least 30 days prior to the scheduled date of any review session, franchisee shall submit a written description of the cable communications system it proposes to furnish to the Village during the renewal term of the franchise. That description shall be the same description required by the Commission for a new applicant for a franchise, and may include information on the following topics: 
1.  System design and technical specifications; 
2.  Channel allocations and programming; 
3.  Fee schedules; 
4.  System construction programs; 
5.  Community communication provisions, including local programming; 
6.  Subscriber service provisions; and 
7.  Any other information the Commission deems necessary or appropriate. 
(E)  After considering the renewal proposal of the franchisee, and after receiving all evidence, the Commission shall submit a report to the board concerning its findings of fact as to reasonable compliance with the terms of this chapter, the ordinance granting the franchise and FCC rules and regulations. Further, the Commission shall report its recommendation as to whether or not renewal of the franchise would provide the best cable communications system for the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
(F)  Following the submission of the Commission's report on renewal, the board may request the franchisee to provide any further evidence, information, tests or proposals it deems necessary or appropriate. 
(G)  Notwithstanding any findings of fact of the Commission or recommendations of the Commission, the board may determine that the franchisee has been in reasonable compliance with the terms and conditions imposed by this chapter, the ordinance granting the franchise, and the FCC rules and regulations. Notwithstanding the fact that the board determines that the franchisee has been in said reasonable compliance, the board shall have the right not to renew the franchise. If the board does not renew the franchise, the board shall, to the extent then permitted by existing law, have the option to: 
1.  Acquire at fair market value all of the assets of the franchisee's operations within the Village; or 
2.  Require the sale at fair market value of all of such assets to a succeeding franchisee; or 
3.  Require the removal of all such assets from the Village; or 
4.  Take such other action as it deems appropriate. 
(H)  The Village shall have the right to recoup from the franchisee all direct expenses, including reasonable legal expenses, professional consulting expenses, publication expenses, or other expenses, incurred pursuant to the renewal process, should the Village offer to renew the franchise. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-13. - Franchise revocation procedures. 
In addition to all other rights, powers or remedies pertaining to the Village in connection with this chapter or otherwise, the Village reserves the right to terminate, cancel and revoke any franchise granted hereunder, together with all rights and privileges granted to a franchisee under the provisions of this chapter. The reserved right to terminate, cancel or revoke shall be exercised in accordance with the following procedure: 
(A)  The Village's right to terminate, cancel or revoke any franchise shall not be exercised by the Village, unless, after hearing as established herein before the Commission, it is found that a franchisee has: 
1.  Violated any material provision of this chapter or any rule, order or determination of the Village made pursuant to this chapter, except where such violation, other than violations defined in subsections (A)2. and (A)3. of this section, is without fault of the franchisee or through excusable neglect; or 
2.  Become insolvent, unable or unwilling to pay its debts, or is adjudged a bankrupt; or 
3.  Failed for a substantial time to provide effective transmission and receiving services capabilities to subscribers, except where such failure is due to strikes, war, civil commotions, acts of God or other causes beyond the control of the franchisee, or 
4.  Attempted to evade any of the provisions of this chapter or an ordinance granting the franchise or practices any fraud or deceit upon the Village, its subscribers or the Federal Communications Commission; or 
5.  Failed to establish, construct and operate the system substantially in compliance with the schedule set forth in any ordinance granting a franchise, with due consideration being given to the nature and causes of any delays; or 
6.  Failed to comply with the conditions of occupancy of any public way, street or right of way; or 
7.  Failed to pay franchise fees or other fees due to the Village when due; or 
8.  Arbitrarily and capriciously discontinued service to a substantial number of its subscribers. 
(B)  In the event the Village believes there is a reasonable probability that grounds for revocation exist or have existed, the Village shall notify the franchisee in writing, setting forth the nature and ultimate facts of such grounds for revocation. If, within 30 days following such written notice, the franchisee has not furnished reasonably satisfactory evidence that corrective action has been taken or is being actively and expeditiously pursued, or that the alleged violations did not occur, or that the alleged violations were beyond the franchisee's control, then the Commission shall establish a date, time and place for the conduct of a public hearing on the grounds for revocation, with the date of said public hearing being no sooner than 30 or later than 60 days after the notice of revocation was served upon the franchisee. 
(C)  The hearing on revocation shall be conducted as an administrative hearing with the Village having the obligation to prove the grounds of revocation by a preponderance of the evidence. 
(D)  Within 30 days after the conclusion of the hearing, the Commission shall submit its written findings of fact, and conclusions of fact and law to the board, together with its recommendation as to whether or not in its opinion the franchise should or should not be revoked. The Commission's recommendation shall not be binding upon the board, and the board may receive additional evidence. 
(E)  In the event that a franchise is revoked for cause, the Village shall then have the same options as set forth in subsection 3-34-12(G) of this chapter. 
(F)  The termination of a franchisee's rights under a franchise shall in no way affect any other rights the Village may have under the franchise or under any provision of law or ordinance. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-14. - Additional conditions and amendments. 
(A)  Throughout the term of any franchise granted pursuant to this chapter, the franchisee shall have an affirmative duty to notify the Village that it has been granted a cable television franchise by another Municipality or franchising authority located within 50 miles of the Village. 
(B)  For the purpose of this section, any affiliated person, subsidiary, partnership or wholly owned corporation related to the franchisee shall qualify as an entity which shall be considered to be equivalent to the franchisee. Further, any transferee or assignee of a franchisee shall be bound for the purposes of this section by any grant of franchise to such transferee or assignee, or to its transferor, or assignor. 
(C)  Subject to the conditions set forth in subsection (E) of this section the Village shall have the right to amend any ordinance granting a franchise to include any of the following terms or conditions which the franchisee has accepted in any franchise area located within 50 miles of the Village: 
1.  Franchisee fees in excess of five percent of gross revenues; 
2.  Franchise term less than 15 years from the grant of the franchise; 
3.  Rates for cable services which are lower than those proposed by franchisee and approved by the Village. 
(D)  Subject to the conditions set forth in subsection (E) of this section, the Village shall have the right to require the franchisee to modify its cable services to include, within a reasonable time, any services which the franchisee offers in any of its cable system located within 50 miles of the Village. 
(E)  The franchisee shall be obligated to accept any modifications in the ordinance granting a franchise or in its service obligations pursuant to this section, unless the franchisee is able to affirmatively demonstrate the following: 
1.  The additional or modified services involve services which are being tested on a trial basis only; or 
2.  The modification is not technically practical or feasible within the Village due to population, density or other relevant factors; or 
3.  The modification would have a substantial adverse impact upon the reasonable rate of return on investment during the remaining term of the franchise based upon the then current standards in the cable communications industry, and with the adverse impact being determined upon the cumulative effect of the proposed modification and all prior modifications required by the Village pursuant to the provisions of this section. 
(F)  In the event the Village determines that there should be a modification in the ordinance granting a franchise or in the franchisee's services pursuant to this section, then the Village shall so notify the franchisee in writing. Within three months of receipt of such notice, the franchisee shall notify the Village whether it will accept the modification or whether the franchisee rejects such modifications. If the franchisee rejects such modifications, then it shall state the reasons therefor and support those reasons with appropriate affidavits. 
(G)  Should the franchisee reject the modifications, the Village and the franchisee shall promptly meet and seek to find a mutually acceptable resolution of the impasse. 
(H)  If after 60 days no resolution has been achieved, either the Village or the franchisee shall be entitled to submit such matter to binding arbitration pursuant to the provisions of the uniform arbitration act, as enacted in the State of Illinois and as amended from time to time. The arbitrator's costs and other usual expenses shall be paid by the franchisee unless the arbitrators find that the Village's request for modification was unreasonable. The Village and the franchisee shall each be respectively responsible for its own attorney fees, costs and other expenses of presenting the matter to arbitration. 
(I)  Any modification in the franchise fee shall be effective as of the date the franchisee accepts any franchise fee in excess of five percent of its gross revenues in any other Municipality. All other amendments or modifications shall become effective within three months of service of notice requesting such modifications. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-15. - Liability, insurance and indemnification. 
(A)  The franchisee shall indemnify, defend and save and hold the Village, its corporate authorities, officers, boards, commissions, employees and agents harmless from any injury, claim, demand, suit, judgment, execution liability, debt, damages or penalty (hereinafter referred to as "claims") arising out of, resulting from, or alleged to arise out of or result from, the construction, erection, installation, operation, maintenance of, or other activity connected with, the franchisee's cable communications system, whether such acts or omissions are those of the franchisee, whether or not any act or omission is authorized, allowed or prohibited by this Code or the ordinance granting the franchise. These damages shall include, but not be limited to, penalties arising out of copyright infringements and damages arising out of any failure by franchisee to secure consents from the owners, authorized distributors or licensees of programs to be delivered by the franchisee's cable communications system, liabilities or claims of liability with respect to property damage, personal injury, invasions of the right of privacy, defamation of any person, the violation or infringement of trademark, trade name, service mark or patent, or any other right of any person, and failure of the franchisee to comply with the provisions of any federal, state or local statute applicable to the franchisee in connection with any franchise granted hereunder. The Village reserves the right to retain counsel of its choice, or in the alternative, approve counsel obtained by the franchisee or its insurance carrier, which approval shall not be unreasonably withheld or delayed. 
(B)  A franchisee shall pay and by its acceptance of a franchise shall be deemed to have specifically agreed that it will pay all expenses incurred by the Village in defending itself with regard to all claims mentioned in subsection (A) of this section. These expenses shall include all out of pocket expenses, such as attorney fees, and shall also include the reasonable value of any services rendered by any employee of the Village. 
(C)  A franchisee shall maintain at its own expense, and by its acceptance of a franchise shall be deemed to have specifically agreed that it will maintain throughout the term of such franchise, general comprehensive liability insurance insuring the Village, and the franchisee with regards to all claims mentioned in subsection (A) of this section, in the minimum amount of: 
1.  Comprehensive general all risk insurance to the extent of $3,000,000.00 per occurrence and $1,000,000.00 per person against liability for bodily injury, including death and to the extent of $2,000,000.00 per occurrence against liability for damage to property including loss of use, occurring on, arising out of or in any way related to the system operated by a franchisee; 
2.
