Workers' compensation insurance including all legal requirements for occupational diseases, sufficient to cover all employees who will be performing work described herein or in operation of the system in accordance with the Illinois state statutes; and employer's liability insurance with the limits of liability not less than $500,000.00; 
3.  Illinois structural work act insurance coverage to the extent of $3,000,000.00 per occurrence and $1,000,000.00 per person; 
4.  Comprehensive automobile liability insurance to the extent of $3,000,000.00 per occurrence and $1,000,000.00 per person against liability for bodily injury including death and to the extent of $2,000,000.00 per occurrence against liability for damage to property including loss of use occurring on, arising out of, or in any way related to the system. 
The limits and types of insurance required herein shall not be construed as a limit on the franchisee's undertaking provided in subsections 3-34-16(A) and (B) of this chapter. 
(D)  All policies of insurance required by this section shall be placed with companies which are qualified to write insurance in the State of Illinois by the Illinois Director of Insurance and which maintain throughout the policy term a general rating of "A" and a financial size category of "XV" as determined by the A.M. Best Company. No insurance policy which provides for a deductible in excess of $250,000.00 shall be accepted to meet the requirements of this section. 
(E)  The franchisee shall cause the Village and all of its officers and employees to be included as coinsureds on all insurance policies required by this section. The franchisee shall file with the Village copies of all such policies. All such policies shall contain a provision requiring at least 30 days' written notice to both the Village and the franchisee of any cancellation, termination or any other expiration and shall provide that no such cancellation, termination or expiration shall be effective until 30 days after delivery of such written notice. Notices of renewal and proof of payment of the premium of any expiring policy shall be filed with the Village Clerk at least 60 days prior to the date of such expiration. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-16. - Restraint on assignment or transfer of franchise. 
(A)  A franchise granted under the provisions of this chapter shall be a privilege to be held personally in trust by the franchisee. Except as otherwise provided in an ordinance granting the franchise, the franchise shall not be assigned, transferred, leased or sublet, sold or disposed of, transferred in trust, pledged, in whole or in part, by voluntary sale, merger, sale and leased back, consolidation or otherwise or by force or involuntary sale, without prior consent of the corporate authorities expressed by resolution or ordinance, and then only upon such conditions as may therein be prescribed. Any sale, transfer or assignment not made according to the procedures set forth in this chapter shall render the franchise voidable at the option of the corporate authorities. The sale, transfer or assignment in bulk of the major part of the tangible assets of the franchisee shall be considered an assignment and shall be subject to the provisions of this section. 
(B)  Any sale, transfer or assignment authorized by the corporate authorities shall be made by a bill of sale or similar document, an executed copy of which shall be filed with the Village Clerk within 30 days after any such sale, transfer or assignment. The corporate authorities shall not withhold its consent unreasonably; provided, however, the proposed assignee agrees to comply with all the provisions of this chapter and the ordinance granting the franchise and reasonable amendments thereto, and must at a minimum, satisfy the legal, financial, technical and character qualifications of an original applicant. 
(C)  The consent of the corporate authorities to any sale, transfer, lease, conveyance into trust, mortgage or other method of hypothecation shall not constitute: 
1.  A waiver or release of any of the rights of the Village under this Code or the ordinance granting the franchise; 
2.  A waiver or release of the requirement for prior approval of any subsequent assignment or transfer; or 
3.  A waiver or release of the rights of the Village in and to public rights of way. 
(D)  The prohibition against assignment and transfer of the franchise shall not be construed to prohibit a mortgage or pledge of system facilities or any part thereof or a leasing by the franchisee of system facilities or any part thereof for financing purposes in connection with construction of the system. Any such mortgage, pledge, or lease shall be subject and subordinate to the rights of the Village and subscribers of the franchisee. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-17. - Franchise fees. 
(A)  The franchisee, in consideration of the privilege granted unto the franchisee for the operation of a cable communication system, and the expense of regulation pursuant to the franchise incurred by the Village, shall pay to the Village a percent of its annual gross revenues during the period of its operation under the franchise. This percent shall be set forth in the ordinance granting the franchise and shall be no more than the maximum amount as may be set from time to time by controlling federal or state law. Such franchise fee shall be payable at least quarterly, as established in the ordinance granting the franchise. 
(B)  The Village reserves the right at any time to increase or decrease this percentage in compliance with applicable state or federal law. 
(C)  Each payment of a franchise fee shall be accompanied by a statement under oath from an official or representative of the company having the requisite knowledge to make such a statement certifying the gross revenues upon which the payment is based. Further, the franchisee shall also file, within 75 days following the conclusion of the grantee's fiscal year, an annual report prepared and audited, at franchisee's expense, by a certified public accountant, clearly showing the yearly total gross revenues; however, the Village may for good cause require that the report be certified by an independent certified public accountant acceptable to the Village. 
(D)  Upon termination, expiration or revocation of the franchise, the franchisee shall continue to render quarterly statements and certifications and the annual certified audit until such time as all payments due the Village for franchise fees have been paid and accounted for to the reasonable satisfaction of the Village. 
(E)  In the event that any franchise payment or other payments required of a franchisee is not made on or before their due date, interest shall be charged from such due date at an annual rate of two percentage points over the prime rate charged by the Continental Illinois National Bank of Chicago to its most credit worthy borrowers of demand loans. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-18. - Subscriber and user fees. 
(A)  By accepting the franchise granted pursuant to the terms and conditions imposed by this chapter, a franchisee agrees that the Village shall have the authority and right to review and approve or disapprove the franchisee's fee schedule for regular subscriber service, which shall include the basic monthly or other periodic service charge for cable communications availability; provided, however, that the Village's authority and right to review a franchisee's fee schedule for regular subscriber service shall be subject to all applicable state and federal laws, including FCC rules and regulations. Unless provided otherwise, review of any changes in the regular subscriber service rates or fees shall be conducted in accordance with the following procedure: 
1.  A franchisee may, from time to time but no more often than quarterly, request approval of a change in its rates so as to enable it a fair and reasonable return on its investment; 
2.  Any proposed change in its rates for regular subscriber service shall be set forth in a written notice served upon the Village at least 60 days prior to a proposed effective date for the revised rates; 
3.  The Commission may hold a public hearing to determine whether any change in the regular subscriber rates are required to enable a fair and reasonable return to the franchisee on its investment and efforts; 
4.  The franchisee shall cooperate with the Commission in such review of proposed changes in the rates, and upon request of the Commission shall supply such data as reasonably may be required by the Commission for determining the reasonableness and fairness of the proposed rate changes; 
5.  The pendency of any proceedings before the Commission to review the proposed changes in the regular subscriber service rates shall not prevent the proposed rate revisions from going into effect as scheduled, but if the corporate authorities ultimately disapprove of the rate revisions, the rates for regular subscriber service shall revert to those in effect prior to the proposed revisions and a new proposal may be submitted by the franchisee; 
6.  Notice of the Commission's hearing on a proposed rate revision shall be given pursuant to section 3-34-9 of this chapter; 
7.  The Commission shall render its recommendations to the corporate authorities within 30 days following the conclusion of the hearing, and the revised rate shall be deemed to be approved unless the corporate authorities pass a resolution or ordinance disapproving the rates within 30 days following submission of the recommendation by the Commission to the corporate authorities; and 
8.  Approval by the corporate authorities of any revision in the regular subscriber service rates or fees shall not be unreasonably withheld. 
(B)  The Village's right to review, approve or disapprove rates and proposed changes in the regular subscriber service fee is permissive and need not be exercised by the Village. Further, the Village may limit the right to certain tier, class or number of channels by specific reference in an ordinance granting a franchise. 
(C)  All charges to subscribers and users shall be consistent with a schedule of fees for all services offered as established by the franchisee. Subject to the review provisions of subsection (A) of this section for regular subscriber rates or fees, changes in the subscriber fee schedule shall not take effect until 90 days after notification of same is delivered to the Village and to current subscribers and users. In approving or disapproving requested changes in fees, the Village shall consider what is a fair rate of return to the franchisee for its investment and efforts. 
(D)  A franchisee shall not, with regard to fees, discriminate or grant any preference or advantage to any person, firm or entity; provided, however, that the franchisee may establish different rates for different classes of subscribers or users in recognition of the cost of service differentials, so long as the franchisee does not discriminate between any subscribers or users of the same class or receiving the same class or type of service. 
(E)  The Village shall have the right to require the franchisee to maintain the fee schedule set forth in its application for a period of time up to 36 months from the time service is provided to the first subscriber. 
(F)  Without prior approval of the Village, a franchisee shall have the authority and the right to add to its service or installation fees any federal, state or local taxes or fees directly imposed on subscribers, any increase in franchise fee payable to the Village in excess of the initial fee rate and any additional copyright fees that may be imposed as a result of legislative or judicial action at the federal, state or local level taken after the filing of the franchise application. If during the term of the franchise, the franchisee receives refunds of any copyright payments, it shall without delay notify the Village, suggest a plan for flow through of the refunds to its subscribers, and retain such refunds in an interest bearing escrow account pending order of the Village. After considering the plan submitted by the franchisee, the Village shall order flow through of the refunds with accrued interest to the franchisee's subscribers in a fair and equitable manner. 
(G)  Notwithstanding subsections (A) through (D) of this section, no action shall be taken by the corporate authorities with respect to the franchisee's rates, rules or regulations applicable thereto as set forth in its application, until at least the expiration of 30 months following the date service is provided to the first subscriber under the franchise. At any time thereafter, or with reference to additional services not scheduled in the franchisee's application, upon the Commission's own motion or upon request of a franchisee or of the corporate authorities, and after proper notice as provided in section 3-34-9 of this chapter, the Commission may hold public hearings to review the subscriber and user rates or fees charged by the franchisee. The Commission may, following such hearing, recommend approval or disapproval of or suggest adjustments to such rates as are requested by a franchisee or charged by a franchisee in accordance with the provisions of this chapter; provided, however, the Village shall not have the right to order the franchisee to rebate any fee or portion thereof charged during the initial period when such fees were not subject to the review of the Commission. Any approval or disapproval of subscriber and user fees or rates must be adopted by resolution or ordinance passed and approved by the corporate authorities, after advisory recommendation from the Commission following hearings as set forth herein. 
(H)  A franchisee shall apprise each new subscriber in writing of all applicable fees and charges for providing cable communication services. 
(I)  A franchisee may, at its own discretion, in a nondiscriminatory manner, waive, reduce or suspend connection fees or monthly service fees for promotional purposes. 
(J)  Except as may be otherwise provided in an ordinance granting a franchise, a subscriber shall have the right to have its service disconnected without charge, which shall include the removal of any equipment owned by the franchisee from the subscriber's residence. Such disconnection shall be made as soon as practicable and in no case later than 30 days following written notice to a franchisee of a subscriber's request for disconnection. No franchisee shall enter into any agreement with a subscriber which imposes any charge following disconnection of service, except for uniform connection charges, subsequent monthly or periodic charges, and a contractual damage amount for failure to return a convertor or similar equipment, and each of those charges and contractual damage amounts shall be no greater than charges for new customers. This section shall not prevent a franchisee from refusing service to any person because the franchisee's prior accounts with that person remain due and owing. 
(K)  Except as may be otherwise provided in an ordinance granting the franchise, a franchisee may offer service which requires advance payment of periodic service charges for no more than one year in advance subject to the conditions contained in this section. A subscriber shall have the right, at any time, to have its service disconnected without charge and with a refund of unused service charges paid to the customer within 30 days from the date of service disconnection. Rate increases shall not be effective with respect to any subscriber until after the expiration of any period for which advanced payment has been accepted by a franchisee. 
(L)  Franchisee shall refund fees pro rata to a subscriber in the event that service to that subscriber is interrupted for more than 24 hours for any reason whatsoever, except interruptions caused by acts or omissions of the subscriber. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982; Ord. 3829, 4-22-1991) 
3-34-19. - Required books and records. 
(A)  Unless excused by written resolution of the Commission, a franchisee shall maintain books and records of its operation in connection with activities within the boundaries of the Village with such books and records showing the following, in sufficient detail, consistent with generally accepted accounting principles: 
1.  Subscriber accounts receivable; 
2.  Subscriber transactions; 
3.  Cash receipts journal; 
4.  Cash disbursement journal; 
5.  General ledgers; 
6.  General journals or other journals permanently retained in the ordinary course of business; 
7.  Capital expenditures, to include capitalized interest and overhead, if any; and 
8.  Depreciation expense, by category. 
(B)  All financial records of the company in connection with its activities within the boundaries of the Village shall be maintained in a manner which permits distinguishing revenues earned within the Village from revenues earned by the franchisee in other villages. Any expenses or expenditures which apply to both the system within the Village and any other operations shall be reasonably allocated between all such operations, consistent with generally accepted accounting principles. 
(C)  A franchisee shall simultaneously file with the Village a copy of all petitions and applications, filed or submitted by the franchisee with any governmental entity or agency having jurisdiction with respect to any matter affecting the system, system facilities, or a franchisee's undertakings with respect to a franchise granted in the Village. 
(D)  At least ten days prior to construction of any part of the system or system facilities in public rights of way, a franchisee shall file with the Village copies of maps, plats or other drawings which accurately show the nature of the proposed construction or improvements. Such copies shall show all existing public or private improvements. Upon completion of such construction, the franchisee shall submit "as built" plans which also show existing public or private improvements. 
(E)  A franchisee shall, within 30 days following a request by the corporate authorities, or by the Commission, furnish the Village Clerk a list, showing the names and addresses of persons owning five percent or more of any class or a series of the outstanding voting stock or equivalent ownership interest of a franchisee, together with a roster of the franchisee's officers and directors (or equivalent managerial personnel) and their addresses. 
(F)  Copies of a franchisee's schedule of charges, contractor application forms for subscriber and user services, rules, regulations and policy statements regarding the processing of subscriber complaints, delinquent subscriber disconnect and reconnect procedures and any other terms and conditions adopted as the franchisee's policy in connection with its subscribers or users shall be filed with the Village Clerk. 
(G)  A copy of any books and records required to be maintained or filed with the Village pursuant to the provisions of this section of this Code, shall be furnished to the Village at the franchisee's expense within 11 business days of a request by the Village for such copy. The Village shall have the right, upon reasonable notice to a franchisee and during normal business hours to inspect all or any part of the franchisee's records and documents, planning records and documents, and engineering records and documents of every kind in connection with the grant of a franchise, the system, the system facilities, and a franchisee's undertakings with respect to the grant of a franchise for cable communications. 
(H)  All books and records required to be maintained by a franchisee shall be retained, in any reasonable, retrievable form, for a period of not less than 15 years. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-20. - Franchise areas. 
(A)  Unless a smaller area is specified in the application for a franchise, the grant of a franchise shall apply within the corporate limits of the Village, including all territory hereafter annexed to the Village. 
(B)  In the event and to the extent that the County of DuPage, Illinois, authorizes and in a manner not inconsistent with the grant of a franchise, or to the extent that an intergovernmental agreement or contract is made by and between the Village and the County in connection with the extension of the service and the offer of the services of the system to potential subscribers in areas outside of the Village's corporate limits, the grant of a franchise within the Village limits may be extended beyond the corporate limits by authorization of the corporate authorities so that the franchisee may so extend the system and offer services to potential subscribers within such extended areas. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-21. - Minimum extension of service. 
(A)  Every franchisee shall be required to extend the system to and to offer the services of the system to potential subscribers within all parts of the franchise area where there are at least a total of 40 residential dwelling units and/or occupied commercial or industrial structures per line mile. Every franchisee shall extend its system by cable to subscribers at no cost to the subscriber for the system extension other than the usual installation fee applicable to all subscribers. 
(B)  Where the density of residential dwelling and occupied commercial or industrial structures, adverse terrain, or other factors render extension of the system and offer of services impracticable or technically unfeasible or creates an undue economic hardship, the franchisee may petition the Commission for relief from the provisions requiring the minimum extension of service. Such application for relief must state as a minimum the part or parts of the franchise area into which extension would create a hardship, the reasons for that hardship, the normal cost of extending such service per subscriber and the additional or inordinate costs presented by the part or parts in which relief is requested. Notice of the hearing for such relief shall be in accordance with sections 3-34-9 and 3-34-11 of this chapter, and following the presentation of evidence, the Commission shall make written findings of fact and recommendations to the corporate authorities as to either waive extension of the service into such part or parts of the franchise area or allow the extension and offer of services on such special terms, conditions and provisions as appear to the Commission to be reasonable and fair, considering the rights and interests of the Village, the franchisee and potential subscribers in such areas. Following such findings of fact and recommendation, the board may either deny the request, waive extension or allow such extension and offer of services on any special terms, conditions and provisions as are deemed reasonable and fair. 
(C)  Every franchisee shall be required to extend service to any area subdivided or constructed after the effective date of the grant of a franchise, in accordance with the criteria set forth in subsections (A) and (B) of this section. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-22. - Individual service drops. 
(A)  Standard installation: Every franchisee shall extend and make cable television service available to any isolated subscriber within the franchise area requesting connection at the standard connection charge, if the connection to such subscriber would require no more than 150 feet of standard aerial or buried lead-in cable to connect the subscriber terminal to the nearest distribution system tap-off, trunk or feeder cable required to be installed pursuant to section 3-34-21 of this chapter, with the point of connection to the subscriber terminal being measured to where entry is made into the building through an outside wall adjacent to the location of the subscriber's television; where any internal wiring can be affixed to the surface of the wall or baseboard or placed in a readily accessible raceway; and where the method of installation, either aerial or underground, is the same as is employed in the distribution system serving that subscriber. 
(B)  Custom installation: A custom installation shall include every installation which employs outside construction methods, either aerial or underground, different from those employed in the distribution system serving that subscriber, where inside wiring involves installation of cable or wire in any attic, crawl space, or within the dead space area of any wall or other area not readily accessible or involving excessive time, care or expertise, or which requires the use of more than 150 feet of standard aerial or buried lead-in cable or of additional amplification equipment on the subscriber's property in order to provide proper service. Every franchisee shall extend and make available cable television service to subscribers requiring custom installation at a connection charge in excess of the standard installation charge, but not to exceed the actual installation costs incurred by the franchisee for the custom installation over and above the usual costs for a standard installation. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-23. - General system description and system. 
(A)  The cable communication system to be installed by franchisee shall comply in all respects with the requirements set forth in the FCC's rules for cable television including applicable amendments thereto, provided, however, that nothing contained herein shall be construed to prohibit a franchisee from proposing to comply with more rigid technical performance requirements, in which case the more rigid standards proposed in a franchisee's application shall be considered to be incorporated by reference in the ordinance granting the franchise and will be binding on the franchisee. If the FCC should delete said requirements, the Village hereby reserves the right to amend this Code to incorporate similar standards and every franchise granted pursuant to this chapter shall be subject to such reserved power whether or not expressly so conditioned. 
(B)  Applications for franchise may include proposals for the provision of public, educational, local governmental, and leased access channels, and any other similar system components. Such proposals by a franchisee, if accepted by the Village, shall be incorporated into the ordinance granting the franchise. The Commission may propose minimum requirements for cable communications system. 
(C)  Every franchisee shall provide, without charge within the franchise area, one service outlet activated for regular subscriber service to each fire station, school, police station, public library and such other buildings used for governmental purposes as may be designated by the Commission. Applications for franchise may include more liberal proposals for the extension of services to public buildings. Such proposals by a franchisee, if accepted by the Village shall be considered to be incorporated into the ordinance granting the franchise. 
(D)  Every franchisee shall establish and construct its system in accordance with the highest standards of the art of cable communications and in accordance with the highest standards of conduct with respect to businesses of the size and type similar to that of the franchisee. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-24. - Lockout device requirement. 
(Repealed by Ordinance 5623, October 22, 2007) 
3-34-25. - Operational requirements. 
(A)  Every franchisee shall construct, operate and maintain the cable communication system in full compliance with the rules and regulations including applicable amendments, of the federal communications Commission and all other applicable federal, state or local laws and regulations, including the provisions of the Electrical Code of the Village of Glen Ellyn and all the amendments thereto. The cable communication system and all its parts shall be subject to inspection by the building Commissioner, and the Village hereby reserves the right to review each franchisee's construction plans prior to the commencement of construction. The Village shall not, however, be required to make inspections or approve the franchisee's system and plans and specifically disclaims such obligation. Each franchisee shall be solely responsible for taking all steps necessary to assure compliance with such laws and regulations and the safety of its system as installed. 
(B)  Unless otherwise specified in an ordinance granting the franchise, each franchisee shall provide a system designed, established, constructed, operated and maintained as follows: 
1.  To provide 24-hour a day continuous operation; 
2.  To produce for receipt on subscriber's receivers, which are in good working order, either monochrome or color pictures, providing the receiver is color capable, that are free from any significant interference, distortion, or ghosting which would cause any material degradation of video or audio quality, within the limits imposed by the technical state of the art; 
3.  To provide uninterrupted service to all areas of the franchise to which extension of the service is required, unless absolute need or emergency circumstances require interruption; 
4.  To provide the level of service represented to the Village in the application for a franchise; 
5.  Each franchise shall construct, equip and operate its system to provide emergency override alerts whereby the Village or other governmental units or agencies designated by the Village may issue a bulletin on all channels simultaneously. 
(C)  In the case of any major emergency or disaster, each franchisee shall, upon request of the Village, make available its facilities to the Village, or other governmental units or agencies designated by the Village, without cost, for emergency use during such major emergency or disaster. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-26. - Tests and performance monitoring. 
(A)  No later than 90 days after any new or substantially rebuilt portion of the system is made available for service to subscribers, technical performance tests shall be conducted by the franchisee to demonstrate full compliance with the technical standards applicable pursuant to subsections 3-34-23(A) and 3-34-25(A) of this chapter. Such tests shall be performed by, or under the supervision of a qualified independent registered professional engineer or an engineer with proper training and experience. A copy of the report shall be submitted to the Village, describing test results, instrumentation, calibration, and text procedures, and the qualifications of the engineer responsible for the test. 
(B)  System monitor test points shall be established at or near the output of the last amplifier in the longest feeder line, at or near trunk line extremities, or at the locations to be specified by the Commission. Such periodic tests shall be made at the test points as shall be required in the exercise of the reasonable discretion of the Commission. 
(C)  At any time after commencement of service to subscribers, the Commission may require additional reasonable tests, including full or partial repeat tests, different test procedures, or tests involving a specific subscriber's terminal at the franchisee's expense to the extent such tests may be performed by the franchisee's employees using its existing facilities and equipment; provided, however, that the Village reserves the right to conduct its own tests upon reasonable notice to the franchisee and if noncompliance is found, the expense thereof shall be borne by the franchisee. The Commission will endeavor to arrange its request for such special tests so as to minimize hardship or inconvenience to grantee or the subscriber. 
(D)  A copy of the annual performance tests report required by the federal communications Commission shall be submitted to the Village within ten days of its completion and may be considered at any annual or special evaluation session. 
(E)  The Village shall have the right to employ qualified consultants if necessary or desirable to assist in the administration of this, or any other section of this Code. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-27. - Local office requirement. 
(A)  Unless expressly stated otherwise in an ordinance granting a franchise, each franchisee shall establish, operate and maintain within the corporate limits of the Village a business office and agent for the purpose of receiving inquiries, requests and complaints concerning all aspects of the establishment, construction, maintenance, and operation of the system and the payment of subscribers' service charges. The office shall have a listed telephone and shall be open during reasonable business hours. Further, each franchisee shall employ an operator or maintain a telephone answering service 24 hours per day, each day of the year, to receive subscriber complaints and to dispatch assistance in the case of an emergency or major system malfunction affecting a number of subscribers. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-28. - Service, adjustment and complaint procedure. 
(Repealed by Ordinance 5623, October 22, 2007) 
3-34-29. - Street, right-of-way and other easement occupancy. 
(A)  All system facilities erected, constructed or placed by a franchisee within the Village shall be located so as not to interfere with the proper use of streets, alleys, rights of way and other public ways and places, to cause minimal interference with the rights or reasonable convenience of property owners who adjoin any of said streets, alleys, rights of way or other public ways and places, and to not interfere with existing public utility installations. 
(B)  All service lines shall be underground in those areas of the Village where both public utilities providing telephone or electric service are underground at the time of installation. In areas where telephone or electric utility facilities are aboveground at the time of installation, a franchisee may install its service aboveground. If, subsequently the telephone or electric utility facilities go underground, the affected facilities of the franchisee shall be installed underground simultaneously, at the sole cost of the franchisee. 
(C)  The franchisee shall use existing poles, conduits and other facilities whenever possible, and shall not construct or install any new, different or additional poles, conduits, or other facilities whether on the public way or on privately owned property within the Village, unless prior written approval of the Village, and, if necessary, of the property owner is obtained. Such approval shall not be unreasonably withheld by the Village. No location of any pole, wire holding structure or other facility of the franchisee shall be a vested interest and such poles, structures and facilities shall be removed, relocated or modified by the franchisee at its own expense whenever the Village or other governmental authority determines that the public convenience would be enhanced thereby. Nothing herein or in any ordinance granting a franchise shall be construed to entitle a franchisee to the use of any property other than the public way. 
(D)  The Village may use, for any public or Municipal purpose, any poles or conduits maintained exclusively by or for a franchisee in any street, provided such use by the Village does not interfere with the use by the franchisee. 
(E)  The franchisee shall protect, support, temporarily disconnect, relocate in the same street or other public place, or remove from the street or other public place, all such activity of the franchisee being herein referred to as "relocation", property of the franchisee when reasonably required by the Village by reason of traffic conditions, public safety, street construction, change or establishment of street grade, installation of sewers, drains, water pipes, power lines, tracks, structures or other improvements by public agencies. Such relocation shall be solely at the expense of the franchisee. 
(F)  The franchisee shall not place the cable communication system above or below ground where the same will interfere with any gas, electric, telephone fixtures, water hydrants or other utility, and all such poles, conduits or other fixtures placed in any street shall be so placed as to comply with all ordinances of the Village, or other applicable laws. 
(G)  The franchisee may be required by the Village to permit joint use of its cable communications system located in the street, alleys or other public right of way of the Village of utilities insofar as such joint use may be reasonably practicable and upon payment of reasonable rental therefor; provided that in the absence of agreement regarding such joint use, the Commission shall arbitrate the terms and conditions of such joint use and the compensation to be paid therefor, which arbitration shall be final. 
(H)  The franchisee shall, at the request of any person holding a valid building moving permit issued by the Village, temporarily raise, lower or cut its cables as may be necessary to facilitate the moving of buildings. The direct expense of such temporary raising, lowering or cutting of the cables, including standby time, shall be paid by the person requesting the same, and the company may require payment in advance. Furthermore, the company may require no less than 72 hours' advanced notice to arrange for such temporary changes. 
(I)  The franchisee shall have the authority, except when in conflict with existing village ordinances, to trim any trees upon and overhanging public right of way so as to prevent the branches of such trees from coming in contact with the property of the franchisee, except that at the option of the Village, such trimming may be done by it, or under its supervision and direction at the expense of the franchisee. The franchisee shall notify the Village department of forestry in writing of its general schedule of tree trimming work sufficiently in advance of the franchisee beginning such work to enable the department of forestry to supervise or oversee such activity. 
(J)  The Village shall have the right to install and maintain free of charge upon the property of any franchisee its own equipment, including, but not limited to, a police and fire alarm system and emergency services disaster agency, on the condition that such equipment does not interfere with the franchisee's establishment, construction, operation and maintenance of the system. 
(K)  If a franchisee seeks to construct and maintain its cables and other system facilities on or above public or private property, and an easement for such use has already been granted to telephone company, electric or other public utility, said easement shall, if at all possible, be interpreted or construed so as to grant the franchisee the same rights and privileges as have been granted to the telephone and electric companies and other public utilities. In such easements, the words "telephone" or "telephone company", "electric company" and the like shall be interpreted to include a franchisee granted a cable communications franchise under this chapter. 
(L)  A franchisee shall not be required to extend the cable communications service to areas where the required easements are not reasonably available or obtainable. 
(M)  Whenever, in the case of emergency, it shall become necessary in the judgment of the Village to remove or damage any of the franchisee's facilities, no charge shall be made by the franchisee against the Village for restoration and repair. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-30. - Repair and restoration of private and public property. 
(A)  In the event of any disturbance of pavement, sidewalk, driveway, or other surfacing, the franchisee shall, at its own expense, and in the manner required by the Village ordinances or policies, replace and restore all such paving, sidewalk, driveway or other surface of any street, alley, public way or right of way so disturbed. The repair and restoration shall be subject to approval by the Director of Public Works or other designated Village official. 
(B)  In the event of disturbance, on either private or public property, of the land surface, including lawn, plantings and trees, by the franchisee, it shall be restored by the franchisee, at the franchisee's own expense, to substantially its previous condition. 
(C)  In the event of disturbance of any utility service, including telephone, electric, gas, water, storm or sanitary sewer, during the course of construction by the franchisee, the franchisee shall immediately notify the affected utility or the Village for Village operated utilities of such disturbance. Such disturbed utility shall be immediately repaired or restored by the appropriate authority at the expense of the franchisee. With reference to Village utilities, the reasonable value of the time of Village employees and the use of Village equipment shall be included within the cost of repair or restoration. 
(D)  In order to secure any franchisee's faithful performance of its duty to repair and restore disturbed surfaces, landscaping or utilities, as a condition of acceptance of the grant of a franchise hereunder, each franchisee shall deposit with the Management Services Director either a cash deposit or an irrevocable letter of credit in a form approved by the attorney for the Village, in the amount of $20,000.00, to be held by the Village until such time as the franchisee has completed the installation of the extension of its service to all parts of the franchise area, or for at least two years, whichever is longer, at which time the deposit or letter of credit may be reduced to $10,000.00. If the franchisee fails to repair or restore a disturbed surfacing or landscaping or fails to pay the cost of repairing or restoring disturbed utilities services within 30 days from the date of notice to cause such repair, restoration or payment, then the Public Works Director shall direct the Management Services Director to forfeit all or so much of said cash deposit or letter of credit as is required to effect such repair, restoration or payment. Failure of the franchisee to restore such cash deposit or letter of credit to its original amount within ten days after receiving written notice to do so, shall give rise to grounds for revocation of the franchise, pursuant to the franchise revocation procedures set forth in section 3-34-13 of this chapter. 
(E)  The security deposit required herein shall be in lieu of any security deposit required by section 8-1-16 of this Code, or any other provision of this Code and ordinances. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-31. - Construction schedule and reports. 
(A)  Upon accepting the grant of franchise, the franchisee shall, within 60 days, file all documents necessary to obtain all necessary federal, state and local licenses, permits and authorizations required for the conduct of its business, it shall submit monthly reports to the Village Clerk on progress in this respect until all such documents are in hand. Failure of the franchisee to pursue all necessary steps to secure the aforementioned authorizations with due diligence shall constitute a substantial violation of this chapter and give rise for grounds of revocation pursuant to section 3-34-13 of this chapter. 
(B)  Franchise applications shall include a schedule for construction of the cable communications system, including the timetable commencement of cable television services to subscribers. Said schedule shall be incorporated into the franchise and shall be enforceable as to the franchisee under the provisions of this chapter. 
(C)  Within 120 days after accepting a franchise, a franchisee shall furnish the Village Clerk a copy of the preliminary engineering drawings and an operating construction schedule setting forth target dates by area for construction activity. The drawings and schedules shall be updated whenever substantial changes become necessary. 
(D)  Every three months after the start of construction, a franchisee shall furnish the Village Clerk a report on progress of construction until complete. The report shall include a map that clearly defines the areas wherein regular subscriber service is available. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-32. - Safety requirements. 
(A)  Each franchisee shall at all times employ ordinary care and shall use commonly accepted methods and devices for preventing failures and accidents which are likely to cause damage, injuries or nuisances to the public. 
(B)  Each franchisee shall maintain all structures, lines and equipment in, over, under and upon the streets and rights of way wherever located, in a safe condition and in good order and repair, consistent with the Village's Electrical Code now or hereafter in effect. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-33. - Protection of privacy. 
(Repealed by Ordinance 5623, October 22, 2007) 
3-34-34. - Restriction of other business activities. 
(A)  The franchisee or any of its employees shall not engage in the sale, leasing or rental of television or radio receivers or in the repair of the same. This provision shall not prohibit the sale, lease or repair of converters, parental discretion locks, if a charge is permitted, or equipment utilized in the operation of the cable communications systems by a franchisee. 
(B)  The franchisee shall not allow its cable or other operations to interfere with television reception of persons not served by the franchisee, nor shall the system interfere with, obstruct or hinder in any manner, the operation of the various utilities serving the residences of the Village. 
(C)  The franchisee is expressly prohibited from requiring the removal or from offering to remove or to provide any inducements for removal of any potential or existing subscriber antennas as a condition for provision of service to the subscriber. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-35. - Security for performance. 
(A)  Each franchisee shall furnish with and at the time of its acceptance of the right, privilege and franchise granted to it, a performance bond or letter of credit, in a form approved by the attorney of the Village, in an amount equal to 100 percent of the proposed estimated construction cost of the cable communications system, or in the amount established in the ordinance granting the franchise. When regular subscriber service is available to more than 90 percent of the occupied dwelling units of the parts of the franchise area to which the extension of service is mandatory, as defined in section 3-34-21 of this chapter, then the amount of the performance bond or letter of credit shall be reduced to the amount specified in the ordinance granting the franchise, or if no amount is specified therein, then to the sum of $100,000.00. Said bonds or letters of credit shall be conditioned upon the franchisee faithfully fulfilling and performing in connection with each provision, term and condition of this chapter and of any ordinance granting the franchise, and that in case of any breach, the Village shall be entitled to recover on said performance bond or letter of credit in the amount of any damages, lost benefits to the Village or other public bodies, unfulfilled commitments contained in an ordinance granting a franchise, costs and attorney fees incurred by the Village, both as a body politic and as a representative of the subscribers, proximately resulting from the failure of the franchisee to well and faithfully observe and perform under any and all of the provisions, terms and conditions of this chapter or of any ordinance granting the franchise to the franchisee. Said damages, lost benefits and unfulfilled commitments shall be deemed to include, as a minimum and without limitation, any and all unfulfilled promises or commitments made to the Village as an inducement to the issuance of a franchise, any expenses as may be incurred by the Village as a result of the franchisee's failure to comply with the obligations imposed by this chapter and any ordinance granting the franchise, the present value of all future franchise fees payable to the Village, based upon the most current available data, the cost of refranchising, including any inducements to future franchisees required for their committing to provide comparable service, the cost of removal or abandonment of any property, or other costs and fees which may be in default or which may be incurred by the Village. The Village shall have no obligation to devote the proceeds of such performance bond or letter of credit to the completion, connection, operation or removal of franchisee's cable communications system, all of which shall remain the obligation of the franchisee. The Village's right to recover under the performance bond or letter of credit shall be in addition to any other rights retained by the Village under this chapter or other applicable law, except that any sum recovered by the Village by reason of such bond or letter of credit shall be deducted from any recovery which the Village might have against the franchisee. 
(B)  In addition to the requirements of a performance bond or letter of credit, the franchisee shall maintain at its own expense, and by its acceptance of a franchise be deemed to have agreed that it will maintain on deposit with the Village throughout the term of such franchise a cash deposit or a letter of credit from an Illinois financial institution in an amount of $10,000.00 or such greater or lesser sum as may be specified in the ordinance granting the franchise. The form and content of such cash escrow or letter of credit shall be subject to the approval of the attorney for the Village. The escrow or letter of credit shall at least be conditioned in the same manner as the bond required by subsection (A) of this section and may be drawn on by the Village to compensate itself for any delinquent costs or fees. In particular, but without limitation, such escrow or letter of credit shall be drawn on in the case of any default or failure of the franchisee to pay any fees, penalties, liens or taxes due to the Village, or to compensate the Village for direct costs which are the obligation of the franchisee or to pay any liquidated claims which are the obligation of the franchisee under section 3-34-15 of this chapter. Upon drawing on such escrow or letter of credit for any reason, the Village shall notify the franchisee. The franchisee, shall within 30 days of the receipt of such notification, take all action required to restore the escrow or letter of credit to its original full amount. The rights reserved to the Village with respect to the escrow or letter of credit are in addition to all other rights of the Village, whether reserved by this chapter or the ordinance granting the franchise or authorized by law, and no action, proceeding or exercise of a right with respect to such escrow or letter of credit shall affect any other right the Village may have. Resort to the deposit letter of credit shall not be a condition precedent to any cause of action the Village may have against the franchisee, or any cause for revocation of the franchise. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-36. - Minimum damages on abandonment or revocation. 
In the event the company fails to perform in accordance with any of the provisions of this chapter by abandoning the franchise or should a revocation for cause of the franchise be declared in accordance with section 3-34-13 of this chapter, then it is understood and agreed that the Village shall be entitled to the sum of $50,000.00 as and for minimum damages, which sum shall be in addition to any sum covered by the security required to be posted by the franchisee in section 3-34-35 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-37. - Areawide interconnection to other systems. 
(A)  Each franchisee shall seek to enter into interconnection agreements with cable franchisees of adjacent communities for the purpose of sharing locally originated programs enjoying a community of interest with that of the Village. 
(B)  To facilitate interconnection, a franchisee may be required by resolution of the board to provide local origination equipment that is compatible with that used by other cable communications systems servicing adjacent areas. 
(C)  Upon the adoption of a resolution by the board requesting the franchisees to interconnect with adjacent systems, each franchisee shall make a good faith effort to obtain agreements for the sharing of interconnection costs among all interconnecting companies. The Village may extend any time limit to interconnect or may rescind its order to interconnect upon finding that the franchisee has made a good faith effort but has been unable to obtain a reasonable interconnection agreement or that the cost of the interconnection would cause an unreasonable increase in subscriber rates. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-38. - Limits on franchisee's recourse. 
(A)  A franchisee shall have no recourse against the Village for any loss, expense or damage resulting from the terms and conditions of this chapter or the franchise or because of the Village's granting or enforcement thereof nor for the Village's failure to have the authority to grant the franchise. The franchisee expressly agrees that upon its acceptance of a grant of franchise it does so relying upon its own investigation and understanding of the power and authority of the Village to grant such franchise. 
(B)  A franchisee, by accepting a grant of franchise, acknowledges that it has not been induced to accept same by any promise, verbal or written, by or on behalf of the Village or by any third person regarding any term or condition of this chapter or the franchise unless that term or condition is expressed herein. The franchisee further pledges that no promise or inducement, oral or written, has been made to any Village employee or official, past or present, regarding receipt of the cable communications franchise other than as contained in the franchise application and ordinance granting the franchise. 
(C)  The decision of the board in their selection of one or more franchisees and their awarding of the franchise(s) shall be final. 
(D)  A franchisee shall not apply for any waivers, exceptions, or declaratory rulings from the Federal Communications Commission or any other federal or state regulatory agency without prior written notice to the Village, and by accepting any grant or franchise agrees to be bound by this provision. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-39. - Compliance with local, state and federal jurisdiction. 
(A)  Each franchisee shall establish, construct, operate and maintain its system subject to the reasonable supervision of the Village, and in strict compliance with all applicable laws, ordinances, rules and regulations, or amendments thereto. 
(B)  If at any time the powers of the Village, state or federal government or any agency or official thereof in connection with the system are duly transferred to or later reside in any other board, authority, agency or official, such board, authority, agency or official shall have the power, rights and duties previously vested, in addition to any other which they may acquire by such transfer. 
(C)  Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, each franchisee shall at all times comply with all state and federal laws, rules and regulations, or any administrative agency thereof; provided, however, if any such ordinance, law, rule or regulation shall require the franchisee to perform any service or do any act in conflict with the provisions and terms of this chapter or of any law, rule or regulation of the Village, then as soon as possible following knowledge thereof the franchisee shall notify the Village of the point of conflict believed to exist. If the Village determines that a material provision of this chapter is affected by such action, the Village shall have the right to modify or amend any of the provisions herein to such reasonable extent that may be necessary to carry out the full intent and purpose of this Code. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-40. - Special license. 
Upon such conditions as the board may deem necessary, and notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, the board may issue a license, easement or other permit to anyone other than a franchisee to permit that person to traverse any portion of the Village in order to provide service outside the Village. Such license or easement, absent a grant of a franchise in accordance with this chapter, shall not authorize nor permit said person to provide cable communications services of any nature to any home or place of business within the Village, nor to render any service or connect any subscriber within the Village to said person's cable communications system. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-41. - Franchise validity. 
(A)  The franchisee agrees, by the acceptance of the franchise, to accept the validity of the terms and conditions of this chapter as they existed on the date of the franchise grant and of the franchise grant ordinance in their entirety and that it will not, at any time, proceed against the Village in any claim or proceeding challenging any term or provision of this chapter or of the franchise as unreasonable, arbitrary, invalid, or void, or that the Village did not have the authority to impose such term or condition. 
(B)  In case of conflict or ambiguity between this chapter, any ordinance granting a franchise, or the franchisee's application, the franchisee agrees that the provisions which provide the greatest benefit to the Village, in the sole discretion of the Village shall prevail. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-42. - Failure to enforce franchise. 
The franchisee shall not be excused from compliance with any of the terms and conditions of this chapter or the ordinance granting a franchise by any failure of the Village, upon any one or more occasion, to insist upon the franchisee's performance or to seek franchisee's compliance with any one or more of such terms or conditions. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-43. - Rights reserved to the Village. 
The Village hereby expressly reserves the following rights which shall not be deemed to be waived or abrogated by any ordinance granting a franchise pursuant to this chapter: 
(A)  To exercise its governmental powers, now or hereafter, to the full extent that such powers may be vested in or granted to the Village; 
(B)  To exercise the Police powers of the Village by adopting and enforcing general ordinances deemed necessary by the corporate authorities to promote the safety and general welfare of the public, including adopting amendments to this chapter, provided any conflict between the provisions of an ordinance granting a franchise and any other present or future lawful exercise by the Village of its Police powers shall be resolved in favor of the Village's present or future lawful exercise of its Police powers, except that any such exercise that is not of general application within the jurisdiction or which applies exclusively to the franchisee or to cable communications which contains provisions inconsistent with this chapter as it exists on the date of any grant of a franchise or with an ordinance granting a franchise shall prevail only if the Village finds such exercise to be necessary to protect the public health, safety, property or general welfare or such exercise as mandated by subsequent changes in applicable federal or state law, or by court action; and 
(C)  To renegotiate any franchise granted pursuant to this chapter should substantial sections of this chapter or the ordinance granting a franchise be rendered void by the Federal Communications Commission, by subsequent changes in applicable federal or state law, or by court action, so that substantial benefit to the Village is eliminated. In the event that the Village and the franchisee fail to mutually agree on renegotiated terms within six months of any event giving rise to the Village's right to renegotiate, then to the extent permitted by applicable state law either the franchisee or the Village shall be entitled to submit such matter to binding arbitration, pursuant to the uniform arbitration act, as adopted in Illinois and as amended from time to time, provided however that should it be judicially determined that the controversy cannot lawfully be settled by arbitration, then the franchise shall be voidable at the election of the Village. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-44. - Nondiscrimination employment requirements. 
The franchisee shall not refuse to hire, nor discharge from employment, nor discriminate against any person regarding compensation, terms, conditions or privileges of employment because of age, sex, race, color, creed or national origin. The franchisee shall take affirmative action to ensure that employees are treated fairly and equally during employment, without regard to their age, sex, race, color, creed or national origin. This condition includes, but is not limited to, the following: recruitment; advertisement; employment interviews; employment; rates of pay; upgrading; transfer; demotion; layoff and/or termination. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-45. - Time essence of agreement/force majeure. 
(A)  Whenever any provision of this chapter or an ordinance granting a franchise sets forth any time for any act to be performed by a franchisee, such time shall be deemed of the essence and the franchisee's failure to perform within the time allotted shall, in all cases, be sufficient grounds for the Village to invoke the remedies available under the provisions controlling revocation of the franchise. 
(B)  Whenever a period of time is provided for in this chapter for either the Village or the franchisee to do or perform any act or obligation, neither party shall be liable for any delays due to war, riot, insurrection, rebellion, strike, lockout, unavoidable casualty or damage to personnel, materials or equipment, fire, flood, storm, earthquake, tornado, orders of a court of competent jurisdiction, any act of God, or any cause beyond the control of said party. In such event, said time period shall be extended for the amount of time said party is so delayed. Are act or omission shall not be deemed to be beyond a franchisee's control if committed, omitted or caused by a corporation or other business entity which holds a controlling interest in the franchisee, whether held directly or indirectly. Further, the failure of a franchisee to obtain financing, or to pay any money due from it to any person, including the Village, for whatever reason, shall not be an act or omission which is "beyond the franchisee's control". 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-46. - Acceptance of franchise grant. 
(A)  The provisions, terms and conditions of this chapter and of any ordinance granting a franchise shall be accepted by a franchisee by written instrument filed with the Village Clerk within 30 days after the passage and approval of the ordinance granting the franchise, unless said time period is extended by the board at its sole discretion. 
(B)  By its acceptance, the franchisee shall be deemed to have declared that it has carefully read the terms and conditions of this chapter and the ordinance granting the franchise, accepts without reservation the obligations imposed by all of those terms and conditions and agrees to abide thereby. 
(C)  The written instrument required by this section shall be in substantially the following form: 
ACCEPTANCE OF GRANT OF FRANCHISE FOR A CABLE COMMUNICATIONS SYSTEM WITHIN THE VILLAGE OF GLEN ELLYN 
Now, this day of _______, 20___, the franchisee having been advised by the Village of Glen Ellyn, Illinois, that the President and Board of Trustees of said Village have passed and approved an ordinance granting a cable communications franchise to the undersigned on the day of _______, 20___, to enable the undersigned to establish, construct, operate and maintain a cable communications system within the corporate limits of the Village, hereby accepts the grant of said franchise and agrees to comply fully and in all respects with the terms, conditions, provisions and intent of Chapter 34, Title 3 of the Village Code, the ordinance granting said franchise and all other rules, regulations and ordinances of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
Franchisee 
STATE OF ILLINOIS ) 
)ss: 
COUNTY OF DUPAGE ) 
I, the undersigned, a Notary Public in and for said County and State aforesaid, DO HEREBY CERTIFY THAT _______, and _______, the and _______, of the above identified corporation personally known to me to be the same persons whose names are subscribed to the foregoing instrument, appeared before me this day in person and acknowledged that they signed, sealed and delivered the said instrument as their free and voluntary act and the free and voluntary act of the Franchisee, and that they were fully and duly authorized by the Franchisee to so subscribe, for the uses and purposes therein set forth. 
Given under my hand and notarial seal this day of _______, 20___. 
Notary Public 
My Commission Expires: 
(D)  The acceptance, to be effective, must be accompanied by an initial reimbursement to the Village for costs and expenses incurred in granting the franchise, as set forth herein or in the ordinance granting the franchise, by the security required in sections 3-34-30 and 3-34-35 of this chapter, any certificates of insurance required by section 3-34-15 of this chapter, and any other documents, fees or securities required by the ordinance granting the franchise. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-47. - Delegation of powers. 
Any right, power or duty of the Village, the corporate authorities of the Village, the Cable Communications Advisory Commission or any other official of the Village under this chapter may be transferred or delegated by ordinance, resolution, or other appropriate action of the corporate authorities to an appropriate officer, employee, or department of the Village, or any legal authority, including any governmental agency created for the purpose of regulating the operation and development of an intercommunity cable communications system. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-48. - Severability. 
If any section, paragraph or provision of this chapter or of any ordinance granting a franchise hereunder, or any portion thereof, is held invalid or unconstitutional by any court of competent jurisdiction or administrative agency, such decision shall not affect the validity of the remaining portions hereof, except as otherwise provided for herein. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
3-34-49. - Effective date. 
This chapter shall become effective ten days following the passage, approval and publication, as provided by law of the ordinance creating this chapter. 
(Ord. 2734, 2-22-1982) 
Chapter 34A - CABLE/VIDEO SERVICE PROVIDER FEE AND PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE 

3-34A-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
CABLE SERVICE: That term as defined in 47 USC section 522(6). 
COMMISSION: The Illinois Commerce Commission. 
GROSS REVENUES: All consideration of any kind or nature, including, without limitation, cash, credits, property, and in-kind contributions received by the holder for the operation of a cable or video system to provide cable service or video service within the holder's cable service or video service area within the Village. 
(A)  Gross revenues shall include the following: 
1.  Recurring charges for cable or video service. 
2.  Event based charges for cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, pay per view and video on demand charges. 
3.  Rental of set top boxes and other cable service or video service equipment. 
4.  Service charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, activation, installation, and repair charges. 
5.  Administrative charges related to the provision of cable service or video service, including, but not limited to, service order and service termination charges. 
6.  Late payment fees or charges, insufficient funds check charges, and other charges assessed to recover the costs of collecting delinquent payments. 
7.  A pro rata portion of all revenue derived by the holder or its affiliates pursuant to compensation arrangements for advertising or for promotion or exhibition of any products or services derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service within the Village. The allocation shall be based on the number of subscribers in the Village divided by the total number of subscribers in relation to the relevant regional or national compensation arrangement. 
8.  Compensation received by the holder that is derived from the operation of the holder's network to provide cable service or video service with respect to commissions that are received by the holder as compensation for promotion or exhibition of any products or services on the holder's network, such as a "home shopping" or similar channel, subject to subsection (A)9. of this definition. 
9.  In the case of a cable service or video service that is bundled or integrated functionally with other services, capabilities, or applications, the portion of the holder's revenue attributable to the other services, capabilities, or applications shall be included in the gross revenue unless the holder can reasonably identify the division or exclusion of the revenue from its books and records that are kept in the regular course of business. 
10.  The service provider fee permitted by 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b). 
(B)  Gross revenues do not include any of the following: 
1.  Revenues not actually received, even if billed, such as bad debt, subject to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(c)(1)(vi). 
2.  Refunds, discounts, or other price adjustments that reduce the amount of gross revenues received by the holder of the state issued authorization to the extent the refund, rebate, credit, or discount is attributable to cable service or video service. 
3.  Regardless of whether the services are bundled, packaged, or functionally integrated with cable service or video service, any revenues received from services not classified as cable service or video service, including, without limitation, revenue received from telecommunication services, information services, or the provision of directory or internet advertising, including yellow pages, white pages, banner advertisement, and electronic publishing or any other revenues attributed by the holder to noncable service or nonvideo service in accordance with the holder's books and records and records kept in the regular course of business and any applicable laws, rules, regulations, standards, or orders. 
4.  The sale of cable services or video services for resale in which the purchaser is required to collect the service provider fee from the purchaser's subscribers to the extent the purchaser certifies in writing that it will resell the service within the Village and pay the fee permitted by 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b) with respect to the service. 
5.  Any tax or fee of general applicability imposed upon the subscribers or the transaction by a city, state, federal, or any other governmental entity and collected by the holder of the state issued authorization and required to be remitted to the taxing entity, including sales and use taxes. 
6.  Security deposits collected from subscribers. 
7.  Amounts paid by subscribers to "home shopping" or similar vendors for merchandise sold through any home shopping channel offered as part of the cable service or video service. 
(C)  Revenue of an affiliate of a holder shall be included in the calculation of gross revenues to the extent the treatment of the revenue as revenue of the affiliate rather than the holder has the effect of evading the payment of the fee permitted by 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(b) which would otherwise be paid by the cable service or video service. 
HOLDER: A person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the Commission pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-401. 
INCUMBENT CABLE OPERATOR: A person or entity that provided cable services or video services in the Village under a franchise agreement with the Village issued under chapter 34 of this title and pursuant to section 11-42-11 of the Illinois Municipal Code on January 1, 2007. 
PEG: Public, education and governmental. 
PEG ACCESS SUPPORT FEE: The amount paid under this chapter and 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(d) by the holder to the Village for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
SERVICE: The provision of "cable service" or "video service" to subscribers and the interaction of subscribers with the person or entity that has received authorization to offer or provide cable or video service from the Commission pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-401. 
SERVICE PROVIDER FEE: The amount paid under this chapter and 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801 by the holder to a village for the service areas within its territorial jurisdiction. 
VIDEO SERVICE: Video programming and subscriber interaction, if any, that is required for the selection or use of such video programming services, and which is provided through wireline facilities located at least in part in the public right of way without regard to delivery technology, including internet protocol technology. This definition does not include any video programming provided by a commercial mobile service provider defined in 47 USC section 332(d) or any video programming provided solely as part of, and via, service that enables users to access content, information, electronic mail, or other services offered over the public internet. 
(Ord. 5622, 10-22-2007) 
3-34A-2. - Cable/video service provider fee imposed. 
(A)  Fee imposed: A service provider fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the Village. 
(B)  Amount of fee: The amount of the service provider fee imposed hereby shall be five percent of the holder's gross revenues. 
(C)  Notice to the Village: Unless the holder has earlier sent notice to the Village pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(a), the holder shall notify the Village at least ten days prior to the date on which the holder begins to offer cable service or video service in the Village. 
(D)  Holder's liability: The holder shall be liable for and pay the service provider fee to the Village. The holder's liability for the fee shall commence on the first day of the calendar month following 30 days after receipt of the ordinance adopting this chapter by the holder. The ordinance adopting this chapter shall be sent by mail, postage prepaid, to the address listed on the holder's application notice sent pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-401(b)(6) to the Village. Together with the ordinance adopting this chapter the Village shall send the holder instructions for remitting the payment and statement required hereby. 
(E)  Payment date: The payment of the service provider fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, 45 days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(F)  Exemption: The fee hereby imposed does not apply to cable service or video service providers that have an existing franchise agreement with the Village issued under chapter 34 of this title in which a fee is paid. 
(G)  Credit for other payments: An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-301(c) with credit for prepaid franchise fees under that agreement may deduct the amount of such credit from the fees that operator owes under subsection (B) of this section. 
(Ord. 5622, 10-22-2007) 
3-34A-3. - PEG access carriage requirements; PEG access support fee imposed. 
(A)  PEG channels; number; carriage: On the date set forth in subsection 3-34A-2(D) of this chapter, but not earlier than 90 days after the holder sends notice to the Village under 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-801(a), the holder shall: 1) designate the same amount of capacity on its network to provide for public, education, and government access use, as the incumbent cable operator is required to designate under its franchise terms in effect on January 1, 2007; and 2) retransmit to its subscribers the same number of public, education, and government access channels as the incumbent cable operator was retransmitting to subscribers on January 1, 2007. 
(B)  PEG fee imposed: A PEG access support fee is hereby imposed on any holder providing cable service or video service in the Village in addition to the fee imposed pursuant to section 3-34A-2 of this chapter. 
(C)  Amount of fee: The amount of the PEG access support fee imposed hereby shall be one percent of the holder's gross revenues or, if greater, the percentage of gross revenues that incumbent cable operators pay to the Village or its designee for PEG access support in the Village. 
(D)  Payment: The holder shall pay the PEG access support fee to the Village or to the entity designated by the Village to manage PEG access. The holder's liability for the PEG access support fee shall commence on the date set forth in subsection 3-34A-2(D) of this chapter. 
(E)  Payment due: The payment of the PEG access support fee shall be due on a quarterly basis, 45 days after the close of the calendar quarter. If mailed, the fee is considered paid on the date it is postmarked. Each payment shall include a statement explaining the basis for the calculation of the fee. 
(F)  Credit for other payments: An incumbent cable operator that elects to terminate an existing agreement pursuant to 220 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/21-301(c) shall pay, at the time they would have been due, all monetary payments for PEG access that would have been due during the remaining term of the agreement had it not been terminated pursuant to that section. All payments made by an incumbent cable operator pursuant to the previous sentence may be credited against the fees that that operator owes under subsection (C) of this section. 
(Ord. 5622, 10-22-2007) 
3-34A-4. - Applicable principles. 
All determinations and calculations under this chapter shall be made pursuant to generally accepted accounting principles. 
(Ord. 5622, 10-22-2007) 
3-34A-5. - No impact on other taxes due from holder. 
Nothing contained in this chapter shall be construed to exempt a holder from any tax that is or may later be imposed by the Village, including any tax that is or may later be required to be paid by or through the holder with respect to cable service or video service. A state issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the Village's simplified Municipal telecommunications tax or any other tax as it applies to any telephone service provided by the holder. A state issued authorization shall not affect any requirement of the holder with respect to payment of the Village's 911 or E911 fees, taxes or charges. 
(Ord. 5622, 10-22-2007) 
3-34A-6. - Audits of cable/video service provider. 
(A)  Audit requirement: The requirements provided in subsection 3-34-17(C) of this title to submit an annual audited financial statement of that part of its books and records necessary to show how it calculated the fees herein imposed shall apply to the holder's books and records.
