Editor's note- Ord. 6641, § 1, adopted Nov. 12, 2018, amended Ch. 4, §§ 4-4-1-4-4-9, in effect repealing and reenacting said chapter as set out herein. Former Ch. 4 pertained to similar subject matter and derived from Ord. 1529, adopted June 26, 1967; Ord. 1616, adopted Oct. 28, 1968; Ord. 1920, adopted Feb. 10, 1975; Ord. 2852, adopted Jan. 24, 1983; Ord. 4746, adopted Aug. 9, 1999; Ord. 5154, adopted March 24, 2003; Ord. 5762, adopted May 26, 2009; Ord. 5796, adopted Sept. 28, 2009; and Ord. 5996, adopted Jan. 30, 2012. 

4-4-1. - Building and Zoning Official. 
(A)  Appointment: The Building and Zoning Official, a division head under the Community Development Department, shall be appointed by the Community Development Director, subject to approval by the Village Manager. 
(B)  Duties and authority: The Building and Zoning Official shall perform the following duties, together with such other duties as may be assigned to him from time to time, have the duties and authorities as specified in this section and in other sections of the Village Code, and as specified for the Building and Zoning Official in the amended and adopted codes regulating zoning and construction within the Village. 
The Building and Zoning Official shall have the authority to assign the occupancy classification of any building or structure, examine and approve all plans for the construction or alteration of buildings prior to the issuance of building permits, inspect for code compliance, enforce all Village code provisions relating to buildings and zoning, and enforce code regulations prescribed by any federal, state, county, or local governmental agency with jurisdiction when such authority is granted to the Building and Zoning Official by the governmental agency. 
(C)  Zoning compliance: The Building and Zoning Official shall have the duty and authority to approve or reject a Business Registration and Certificate of Zoning Occupancy Application after complete and accurate information has been submitted as required in zoning code section 10-10-6. The Building and Zoning Official shall have the duty and authority to issue a Certificate of Zoning Occupancy after a zoning occupancy inspection has been completed and approved, as required in this section and in zoning code section 10-10-7. 
(D)  Power of entry: The Building and Zoning Official, or his authorized representative, shall have the power to enter, at any reasonable hour, any building or premises where a building permit application or a Business Registration and Certificate of Zoning Occupancy Application has been received or where alterations, repairs or construction is proceeding for the purpose of making the inspections required by this chapter. 
(Ord. 6641, 11-12-2018; Ord. 6674, 2-25-2019) 
4-4-2. - Inspections required. 
The Building and Zoning Official, or his duly authorized representative, shall make, or cause to make, the following inspections to confirm compliance with all applicable regulations in the Village Code. 
(A)  Construction inspections: All construction work completed under a building permit shall be periodically inspected to confirm compliance with applicable building and fire codes. The building permit applicant or property owner shall request the required inspections listed on the building permit and provide access and the means to complete the inspections and shall not cover or conceal the work or continue the work until the required inspections are completed and approved. The Building and Zoning Official shall inspect all buildings and structures being erected or altered as frequently as may be necessary to confirm compliance with approved plans and the Village's codes that regulate construction. 
(B)  Fire prevention inspections: 
1.  The Building and Zoning Official, or his duly authorized representative, shall make an annual fire prevention inspection of all churches, public assembly units, schools, theaters, business buildings, multiple use buildings consisting of business and dwelling units, common areas within multi-family residential buildings and other occupiable buildings and structures to confirm fire and life safety code compliance. 
Exception: Detached single- and two-family dwellings and single-family attached dwellings (townhouses) and their accessory structures, and individual dwelling units in multi-family buildings and their accessory structures, shall not be subject to annual fire prevention inspections. 
2.  It shall be the duty of the owner, agent, lessee, occupant or person in charge of, or in control of, a building or structure to permit the Building and Zoning Official, or his duly authorized agent, to make an annual fire prevention inspection at any reasonable time, upon demand duly made. 
3.  A fee for the annual fire prevention inspection of each building shall be paid to the Village and shall be based on the Schedule of Fees and Deposits in section 4-1-4 of this title. Each part of a building occupied by a different business shall be considered as a separate building. See section 4-1-4 of this title. 
4.  Any owner of a building failing to pay the annual fire prevention inspection fee within 30 days of receipt of the bill shall pay double the amount of the fee billed, up to 60 days, with an additional $5.00 per day after 60 days until paid but not more than $500.00. 
(C)  Zoning occupancy inspections: 
1.  It shall be the duty of either the owner, agent, lessee or occupant of a building or structure to file with the Building and Zoning Official an application for a Business Registration and Certificate of Zoning Occupancy in accordance with zoning code section 10-10-7. Such application shall be submitted to the Village when one or more of the following events occur: 
(a)  Change of ownership of the building, business or structure, 
(b)  Change of occupancy, 
(c)  Change of business name, 
(d)  Change of business address, or 
(e)  New business 
2.  A fee shall be paid to the Village for the registration of each business in accordance with the schedule of fees and deposits in section 4-1-4 of this title. 
3.  Following receipt of Business Registration and Certificate of Zoning Occupancy Application and, prior to the establishment of a new use, or a change of use, or a change of occupancy, a zoning occupancy inspection shall be completed by the Building and Zoning Official, or an authorized representative. 
4.  It shall be the duty of the owner, agent, lessee, occupant or person in charge of, or in control of, a building to permit the Building and Zoning Official, or his duly authorized representative, to make a zoning occupancy inspection at any reasonable time, upon demand duly made. 
5.  The Building Registration and Certificate of Zoning Occupancy Application shall include the name, title, home address, email address and telephone number of the property owner and the person to be notified in the event of a fire, accident or other emergency in or to the building, and any other information requested by the Building and Zoning Official to ensure the building occupancy and use complies with all applicable regulations. Further, the police department shall be furnished with such information as it may require to implement the protection provided for the building occupants and the property. 
(D)  Business license and permit inspections: Upon the Village's receipt of an application for a business license or permit, the Building and Zoning Official shall perform the applicable inspections required by Title 3 and Chapter 5 of Title 7 of this Code. 
(E)  Elevators and conveying system inspections: 
1.  Inspection required: Every elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or other conveyance now in operation or which may hereinafter be installed, together with the hoistway and all equipment thereof, shall be inspected under and by the authority of the Building and Zoning Official annually and in no case shall any new equipment be placed in operation until an inspection of the same has been made. It shall be the duty of every owner, agent, lessee or occupant of any building wherein any such equipment is installed, and of the person in charge or control of any such equipment to permit the making of a test and inspection of such elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or other conveyance, and all devices used in connection therewith upon demand being made by the Building and Zoning Official. 
2.  Order to stop operation: Whenever the Building and Zoning Official finds any elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator or other conveyance in an unsafe condition, he shall prepare a statement of all the facts relating to the condition of such equipment. It shall then be the duty of the Building and Zoning Official to order the operation of such equipment to be stopped and to remain inoperative until it has been placed in a safe condition and it shall be unlawful for any agent, owner, lessee or occupant of any building wherein any such equipment is located, to permit or allow the same to be used after the receipt of a notice from the Building and Zoning Official, which notice is in writing, that such equipment is in an unsafe condition and until it has been restored to a safe and proper condition as required by the provisions of this Code. 
3.  Inspection fee: A fee shall be paid to the Village for the annual inspection or required periodic testing of each elevator, dumbwaiter, escalator, or other conveyance as required by the Office of the State Fire Marshal. See section 4-1-4 of this title. 
(Ord. 6641, 11-12-2018) 
4-4-3. - Notices and orders. 
When the inspection made by the Building and Zoning Official, or his duly authorized representative, shows that a building, structure or occupancy fails to comply with the provisions of the applicable village code which regulates construction, as adopted and amended by Glen Ellyn ordinance, in any respect, it shall be the duty of the Building and Zoning Official to notify the owner, agent, lessee or occupant, and to specify wherein such building, structure or occupancy fails to comply with the requirements of the code and order the discontinuance of the illegal action or condition and the abatement of the violation. 
Thereupon, it shall become the duty of such owner, agent, lessee or occupant to promptly make whatever changes or alterations are required to comply with the provisions of all applicable codes. 
(Ord. 6641, 11-12-2018) 
Chapter 5 - SIGN CODE 

4-5-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known and cited as the Glen Ellyn Sign Code. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014) 
4-5-2. - Statement of purpose. 
It is hereby determined that the primary purpose of signage is to help people find what they need without difficulty or confusion. Thus, while not restricting freedom of expression, regulations must be established for preventing an overload of graphic messages in the environment. The purpose of signs is subordinate to the structures and land use functions they reference. Signs are to be considered accessory components of an overall composition of architectural elements, not as freestanding or dominant architectural elements by themselves. There should not be a proliferation of off premises signs as it can obscure the legitimate efforts of local business establishments to reasonably identify the location and nature of their businesses. 
This chapter establishes standards and regulations for the erection, display, safety and maintenance of signs which are intended to allow a person to observe or ignore graphic messages, according to that person's own purpose, as well as to encourage the general attractiveness of the community and to protect property values. These standards and regulations are intended to meet the following objectives: 
(A)  Effective communication: A reasonable, orderly and effective display of signs is to be promoted by authorizing the use of signs which: 
1.  Are legible in the context in which they are viewed; 
2.  Are appropriate to the functions to which they pertain; 
3.  Clearly and efficiently identify and classify the goods, services, facilities, activities and locations made available to the community by businesses, community service organizations and other enterprises; and 
4.  Eliminate or reduce the "canceling out" effect created by the inappropriate placement of signs in proximity to one another. 
(B)  Public welfare: The public health, safety and welfare is to be preserved, protected and promoted through sign regulations which: 
1.  Recognize that signs are a necessary means of visual communication for the convenience of the general public taken as a whole, as opposed to the convenience of any individual person; 
2.  Minimize the blighting influences posed by visual clutter, decay and neglect; 
3.  Reduce distractions, obstructions, and hazards to pedestrian and automobile traffic caused by the indiscriminate placement and use of signs and to protect pedestrians and motorists from injury and property damage caused by, or which may be fully or partially attributable to, cluttered, distracting or illegible signage; 
4.  Prohibit the placement of signs which obstruct vision or access in a manner which creates dangerous conditions; 
5.  Protect the physical and mental well-being of the general public by encouraging a sense of aesthetic appreciation for the Village's visual environment and ensuring that signs harmonize with their surroundings and are consistent with the character of their community context; 
6.  Promote the use of graphics which are aesthetically pleasing, of appropriate scale, and integrated with surrounding buildings and landscaping, in order to meet the community's expressed desire for quality development; 
7.  Protect the value of the Village's architectural resources, by ensuring that the integrity of the architectural elements and character of buildings and sites to which signs principally relate is maintained; 
8.  Assure that public benefits derived from expenditures of public funds for the improvement and beautification of streets in accordance with the downtown, Roosevelt Road and historic Stacy's Corners streetscape plans, and other public structures and spaces, are protected by exercising reasonable controls over the character and design of graphic structures; 
9.  Preserve the value of private property by assuring the compatibility of signs with surrounding land uses; 
10.  Promote economic development by encouraging a more attractive economic and business climate within the commercial areas of the Village; 
11.  Further the objectives of the comprehensive plan and downtown strategic plan; 
12.  Protect the general public from damage and injury caused by the faulty and uncontrolled construction and use of signs within the Village; and 
13.  Respect the rights of nearby property owners. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014) 
4-5-3. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different sense, the terms set forth below shall, for the purposes of this chapter, have the meanings indicated herein. In the event a conflict arises concerning terms not defined in this section, the following sources shall be consulted and the definition found in the sources listed in order of priority to be consulted shall be deemed correct: 
(A) Glen Ellyn Zoning Ordinance 3617-Z, as amended. 
(B) Webster's Collegiate Dictionary, most recent edition. 
ABANDONED SIGN: A sign located on property which becomes vacant, or any sign which pertains to a use or activity which is no longer available on the premises where the sign is displayed. 
ANIMATED SIGN: Any sign which includes action or motion. For the purposes of this chapter, this term does not refer to flashing, changing or indexing signs, which are separately identified. 
ATTENTION GETTING DEVICE: A sign or other device designed to attract attention. Examples of such signs and devices include searchlights, beacon lights, lighting bands and any pennant, flag, banner, propeller, spinner, streamer, whirligig, inflatable device, balloon or similar device/ornamentation designed for the purposes of attracting attention or for promotion or advertising. 
AWNING: An architectural projection, which provides weather protection, identity or decoration which is supported by the building to which it is attached and composed of a lightweight rigid or retractable skeleton structure over which another cover is attached which may be made of fabric or other materials. 
AWNING AREA: The total surface area of an awning including any side panels and valances. 
AWNING SIGN: Individual letters, words or symbols painted or otherwise permanently affixed to an awning surface. 
BANNER SIGN: A temporary sign composed of cloth, canvas or other lightweight material either enclosed or not enclosed in a rigid frame. 
BARE BULB ILLUMINATION: Exposed or uncovered lighting elements, for example, light bulbs without a cover. 
BILLBOARD: See definition of Off Premises Sign. 

BREEZEWAY SIGN
BREEZEWAY SIGN: A sign attached to the underside of a breezeway or arcade in a shopping center which identifies the establishments located therein. 
BUILDING SIGNAGE: Permanent, non-exempt sign affixed to the exterior surface of a building to serve the establishment contained within the building that the building signage is affixed to. Wall signs, awning signs, and marquee signs are considered building signs. Building signage does not include prohibited signs or temporary signs. 
COMMON PROGRAM SIGN: A uniform flag or projecting banner associated with a program or initiative sponsored or facilitated by a governmental entity, community service organization or educational, religious or charitable organization. 
COMMUNITY SERVICE ORGANIZATION: A not for profit entity or corporation whose principal purpose is to provide services, financial assistance or personnel which benefit the residents of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
COPY: The wording or symbols on a sign surface, either in permanent or changing letter form. 
DEVELOPMENT: An area of land sharing common elements such as access drives, parking and stormwater facilities and constructed as a unified site. 
DOUBLE SIDED SIGN: A sign with two distinct faces, each designed to be viewed from separate directions. 
DRIVE-THROUGH CANOPY INFORMATIONAL SIGNAGE: Signs placed on the canopy of drive-through establishments intended to guide traffic and provide instructional information to motorists such as "Open", "Closed" and "Clearance" and including no advertisements. 
ELECTRONIC IDENTIFICATION SIGN: An electronic sign constituting the main establishment identification signage which may include, the name or other generally recognizable symbol or logo of an establishment, not including electronic message boards. 
ESTABLISHMENT: An individual business, institution or activity that occupies a portion of a building and has its own exterior public entrance accessible from ground level. 
ESTABLISHMENT FRONTAGE: The linear length of the principal building frontage of an establishment oriented toward the front property line. 
EXTERNAL ILLUMINATION: Illumination of a sign that is affected by an artificial source of light not contained within the sign itself, but not including silhouette lighting. 
FESTOON LIGHTING: A group of two or more bulbs hung or strung on a building or structure, which are not shaded or hooded to prevent direct rays of light from being visible. 
FLASHING SIGN: Any sign, exclusive of "message boards (electronic)" on which illumination intermittently flashes off and on in whole or in part, or which includes the illusion of intermittent or flashing light by means of animation, or an externally mounted intermittent light source. 
FREESTANDING SIGN: A sign erected on a freestanding frame, mast or pole or supported by the ground and not attached to any building, including, but not limited to, "monument signs" and "pole or pylon signs". 
GAS STATION CANOPY: A roofed structure supported by posts or columns with no exterior walls and serves as a sheltered area above gas dispensing pumps. 
GAS STATION PUMP SIGNAGE: Signs located on an individual gas pump associated with a gas station use provided the combined size of all signage located at each vehicle position of each gas pump does not exceed 12 square feet. 
ILLUMINATED SIGN: Any sign which emanates or receives light. Light may be transmitted internally through the sign face, be illuminated externally, or illuminated by indirect light. 
INDEXING SIGN: A sign that has a series of triangular vertical sections that turn or stop, designed to show three messages in the same area. 
INDIVIDUAL LETTER WALL SIGN: Any sign made of individual letters that is mounted directly on the face of a building. 
INTERNAL ILLUMINATION: A light source that is concealed or contained within the sign and becomes visible in darkness through a translucent surface. 
LOT FRONTAGE: The combined length of the front and any corner side yard property lines. 
MARQUEE AREA: The total surface area of a marquee excluding the top and bottom surfaces. 

MARQUEE SIGN
MARQUEE SIGN: A permanent roof like structure containing signage and projecting from a building that provides protection from the elements. Also known as a canopy sign. 
MENU BOARD: A permanent sign which functions to list items or show pictures of items for sale at a drive-through and which is intended to be visible by motorists placing orders from their vehicles. 
MESSAGE BOARD (ELECTRONIC): A sign such as an electronic or electronically controlled time, temperature or date sign, message center or reader board, where different copy changes are shown at timed intervals as regulated in section 4-5-15 of this chapter. 
MESSAGE BOARD (MANUAL CHANGING): A sign on which copy is changed manually in the field, i.e., reader boards with changeable letters or changeable pictorial images. 
MONUMENT SIGN: A sign for which the base/supports are 100 percent (on all sides) in contact with the ground and the width of the base is no less than 66 percent of the width of the sign face. 
MULTI-FAMILY DWELLING SIGN: A sign identifying a multi-family building, other than a senior facility, consisting of three or more dwelling units including apartments and condominiums, which may contain the name and contact information of the management company and associated information. 
MULTI-TENANT SIGN: A sign that serves as a common or collective sign for buildings with two or more ground floor establishments located on the same lot or in the development which may contain the name of the development and/or information about one or more of the establishments located therein. 
MUNICIPAL SIGN: Sign of a duly constituted municipality, as defined in the Illinois municipal code. 
MURAL: Artwork painted directly on an exterior building wall that contains no identification, description, illustration or device which directs attention to or provides information about a product, service, or business. A Mural is not a sign. 

NAMEPLATE
NAMEPLATE: A small wall mounted nonelectronic sign identifying a business or occupant located on the premises on which the sign is located. If any premises includes more than one business or occupant, nameplate refers to all the businesses or occupants identified as well as the name of the building and directional information. 
NEON SIGN: A sign in which an inert gaseous chemical element is contained in a glass tube and which may be bent to form letters, symbols or other shapes. 
NONCOMMERCIAL SPEECH SIGN: A sign whose primary purpose is not to direct attention to a business, development, institution, good, product, or service located on the premises or for sale and which is typically of political, religious or ideological nature. 
NONCONFORMING SIGN (LEGAL): Any sign which was lawfully erected and maintained prior to enactment of this chapter and which fails to conform to all applicable regulations and restrictions of this chapter. 
NONRESIDENTIAL ESTABLISHMENT SIGN: A sign identifying an establishment other than a residential establishment such as a business, institutional, private recreational, office, or service establishment or any associated products, facilities or services located on the site. 
OFF PREMISES SIGN: Outdoor sign which advertises goods, products or services not sold or provided on the premises on which the sign is located. 
OFFICE COMPLEX: A continuous area of land and any office buildings or structures thereon, under single ownership or operated under a single entity with more than one firm or business. 
OFFICE COMPLEX DIRECTORY SIGN: A sign identifying the offices or other businesses located in an office complex. 
ORDER CONFIRMATION SIGN: A sign displaying items, prices and total cost of a single transaction or purchase made at a drive-through facility. 
OWNER: A person recorded as such on official records. 
PARAPET OR PARAPET WALL: A wall like barrier at the edge of a roof that extends above the roof surface and which may be an extension of the exterior building wall or a continuation of a vertical feature beneath the roof. 
PARK SIGN: A sign identifying a public park or any public recreational facilities located thereon. 
POLE OR PYLON SIGN: A freestanding sign that is permanently supported in a fixed location by a mast or pole that has a width that is 66 percent or less of the width of the sign face and which is not supported by a building or end piers. 
POLITICAL CAMPAIGN SIGN: A sign referring to a candidate or issue subject to public election. 
PORTABLE SIGN: A sign which is not intended to be permanently attached to a structure or to the ground, but can be moved or is intended to be moved from one location to another. 
PRIVATE PARKING LOT SIGN: A sign located in a private parking lot intended to regulate traffic or parking and which may denote time limits or other legal responsibilities. Such signs may include, but not be limited to, towing and no trespass signs. 

PROJECTING SIGN
PROJECTING SIGN: Any sign other than a wall, awning, marquee or breezeway sign which is suspended from or supported by a building or wall and not in the same plane as the wall. 
PUBLIC REGULATION SIGN: Any notice or warning sign required by a valid and applicable federal, state or local law, regulation or resolution or used by a public body for the control of traffic, parking, legal notice, information or direction required by such bodies, but not including establishment identification signs. 
REAL ESTATE SIGN: A sign indicating the sale, lease or rental of the parcel, structure or establishment on which the sign is located. 
RESIDENTIAL DEVELOPMENT SIGN: A sign identifying a single-family detached, single-family attached or senior residential development. 
ROOF SIGN: A signed erected on or extending above the roof or parapet of any building or structure. 
SIGHT TRIANGLE: A triangle formed by extending the lot lines at a street intersection 30 feet in each direction and connecting the extended lines using a straight path. 
SIGN: Any identification, description, illustration or device illuminated or nonilluminated which directs attention to or provides information about a product, service, place, activity, person, institution, business or solicitation, including any permanently installed or situated merchandise or any emblem, banner, pennant, placard or temporary sign designed to advertise, identify or convey information. An object in the shape of a product is considered a sign. 
SIGN AREA: The total area within a continuous perimeter enclosing the extreme limits of characters, lettering, illustrations, ornamentations, or other figures of the sign, together with any material, or color used as an integral part of the display or to differentiate the sign from the background. Where a base or frame is used as an integral part of the sign structure such elements shall not be included in the sign area unless lettering or graphics are located thereon. More information about how to calculate sign area can be found in section 4-5-13 of this chapter. 
SIGN FACE: The entire area of the sign on which copy could be placed. 
SIGN INCORPORATING MOVEMENT: Any turning, rotating, swinging or other motion or simulated action of a sign or signpost. 
SIGN STRUCTURE: Any structure which supports, has supports or is capable of supporting a sign including decorative cover. 

SILHOUETTE 
ILLUMINATED
SIGN
SILHOUETTE ILLUMINATED SIGN: A sign that is illuminated by casting or reflecting light behind the sign so as to create a silhouette or halo around the outer perimeter of the sign. Sometimes referred to as a "halo" sign. 
SPECIAL EVENT SIGN: A temporary sign authorized by section 4-5-7 of this chapter to promote an event, sale or other special activity. 
TEMPORARY SIGN: A sign which is not permanently affixed such as real estate and construction signs, banner signs, and other similar devices, and other signs of a temporary nature, as regulated in sections 4-5-6 and 4-5-7 of this chapter. 
TRAFFIC DIRECTIONAL SIGN: A sign which directs traffic movement into or within a site. 
UNLAWFUL SIGN: A sign which violates this chapter. 
VIDEO DISPLAY SIGN: An electronic sign that displays motion or pictorial images and which may include the presentation of pictorials or graphics displayed in a progression of frames which give the illusion of motion, including, but not limited to, the illusion of moving objects, moving patterns or bands of light, or expanding or contracting shapes. 
WALL SIGN: A sign attached or erected against, or painted directly on, the wall of a building with the sign face in a parallel plane to the plane of the building. 
WINDOW SIGN: A sign installed on, inside or near a window for purpose of viewing from outside the building. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014; Ord. 6656, 12-10-2018) 
4-5-4. - General standards and design criteria. 
All signs shall be constructed and maintained in conformance with the following general provisions: 
(A)  Corner lots: Signs located within the 30-foot sight triangle must be constructed and maintained in such a manner that clearance is maintained from three feet to eight feet from ground level. 
(B)  Electrical requirements: All signs in which electrical wiring and connection are required shall conform to the applicable provisions of the Electrical Code adopted by the Village of Glen Ellyn. Conductors for all illuminated signs shall be enclosed in rigid conduit or enclosed in poles or raceways and be controlled with an external disconnect located at the sign. In no case shall the wiring be exposed to the view of the public. 
(C)  Framework: All signs shall be designed so that all framework for the lateral support of the sign, other than the supporting base, poles or end piers of a freestanding sign, shall be contained within or behind the face of the sign or within the structure of the building to which it is attached, in such a manner as to not be visible from public view. 
(D)  Glass requirements: All glass forming a part of any sign shall be designed to resist a 90-mile per hour three-second gust wind speed and shall have safety glazing where subject to impact loads or placed in a hazardous location in accordance with the standards and regulations in the Building Code adopted by the Village. 
(E)  Illumination: Signs may be externally illuminated, internally illuminated, silhouette illuminated or otherwise illuminated unless expressly stated otherwise in this chapter. The illumination of signs shall comply with the following regulations: 
1.  Externally illuminated: Signs in the CR and any residential zoning districts shall only be externally illuminated. 
2.  Restrictions: Illumination shall not be used for decorative, advertising or attention getting purposes, except that incidental lighting may be provided to aid in the identification of the address and the entrance location. This requirement applies to all signs including awning and marquee signs. 
3.  Brightness limitation: In no instance shall the lighting intensity of any sign, whether resulting from internal illumination or external illumination, exceed the following: 
(a)  Fifty foot-candles measured perpendicular to the face of the sign from a distance equal to the narrowest dimension of the sign; or 
(b)  One foot-candle on the adjoining residential property lot line closest to the sign, measured three feet above the surface of the ground. 
4.  Constant: Illumination shall be constant in intensity and color and shall not consist of blinking, flashing, animated or scintillating lights including externally illuminated signs which shall be illuminated only with steady and stationary light sources. Time and temperature signs are considered electronic message boards and shall not be considered flashing signs. 
5.  Nonglaring: Whenever an external artificial light source is used to illuminate a sign, the illumination source shall be located, shielded, and directed so as not to be directly visible from any public street and shall be so designed, located, shielded and directed so as to illuminate only the sign face and to prevent the casting of glare or direct light upon adjacent property or streets. 
6.  No traffic hazards: Neither the direct nor reflected light from light sources shall create a traffic hazard for, or confuse operators of motor vehicles, or in any way interfere with the driver's view of approaching, merging or intersecting traffic. 
7.  Luminaries: Marquee sign luminaries shall be the cut off type with horizontally mounted flat lenses that do not extend below the marquee ceiling. Prismatic and drop lenses are prohibited. 
8.  Projecting light fixtures: Gooseneck reflectors or arms projecting from the sign surface mounted with lights for the purpose of illuminating the sign shall be permitted for wall and freestanding signs, except that fixtures shall not project more than two feet over the public right-of-way and a minimum clearance of seven feet six inches must be maintained beneath the fixture. 
(F)  Letters to be secured: All letters, figures, characters or representations which are attached or superimposed on any sign shall be safely and securely built or attached to the sign structure. 
(G)  Obstruction to ventilation: No sign shall be constructed or maintained so as to obstruct any window surface required for ventilation by an applicable code of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
(H)  Obstructions to doors, windows or fire escapes: No sign shall be constructed or maintained so as to obstruct or obscure the visibility of any fire escape, required exit, or window or door opening used as a means of egress. No sign shall be attached to a standpipe or fire escape. 
(I)  Sign in or over the right-of-way: No sign, except a: 
1.  Public regulation sign; 
2.  Municipal sign; 
3.  Awning sign; 
4.  Marquee sign; 
5.  Projecting sign; 
6.  Light pole banners approved by the Village; 
7.  Common program sign; or 
8.  Special event sign as authorized in this chapter; 
shall be placed on or extend into or over any public right-of-way or municipal property. Awnings, marquee signs and projecting signs are permitted to project no closer than two feet to the curb line. The Village may, without prior notice, remove any sign unlawfully placed on public right-of-way. 
(J)  Sign projection: 
1.  Wall signs shall not extend more than 12 inches from the wall or structural members to which they are attached or extend beyond the top or ends of the surface of the wall to which they are attached. 
2.  Projecting signs may extend no farther than four feet from the building wall. 
(K)  Sign to not obstruct vision: No sign shall be installed or constructed which obstructs vision or access in a manner that creates a dangerous condition. 
(L)  Sign to not constitute traffic hazards: In order to obtain and secure traffic safety, no sign shall be erected or maintained in such a manner as to be likely to interfere with, obstruct the view of, or be confused with any authorized traffic sign, signal or device, or interfere with, mislead, confuse traffic or detract from the effectiveness of any traffic control device as determined by the chief of police. Accordingly, no sign shall make use of the words "stop", "go", "look", "slow", "danger", or other similar word, phrase, symbol or character, or employ any red, yellow, orange, green or other colored lamp in such a manner as to interfere with, mislead or confuse traffic. 
(M)  Compliance with Building Code: Any "sign" as defined in this chapter, shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the standards and regulations in the Building Code adopted by the Village. 
(N)  Wind pressure and dead load requirements: All permanent signs and the attached mounting shall be capable of withstanding a 90-mile per hour three-second gust wind speed and of receiving dead loads based on the actual weight of the structure. 
(O)  Fire resistance: All permanent signs shall be constructed of fire resistant materials. 
(P)  Minimum clearance: A minimum seven foot six inch vertical clearance must be maintained between any sign and walkway, except as otherwise permitted in section 4-5-6 of this chapter for common program signs where a minimum clearance of seven feet must be maintained beneath the sign support structure. 
(Q)  Maintenance required: The owner of a sign and the owner of the premises on which such sign is located shall be jointly and severally responsible to maintain the sign including its illumination sources, at all times in compliance with all applicable codes and ordinances in a safe and secure condition, in a neat and orderly condition and in good working order, and to prevent the development of any rust, fading, corrosion, rotting or other deterioration in the physical appearance or safety of such sign. Signs constructed from wood shall be maintained to prevent wood rot or delamination of wood plies. Rotted or delaminated wood signs shall be removed or replaced. The premises around freestanding signs shall be kept clean and free of all rubbish and weeds. No signs or sign structure shall have any nails, tacks, wires or sharp metal edges protruding therefrom. 
(R)  Freestanding signs: 
1.  Material: Freestanding signs shall be constructed of noncombustible or limited combustible materials, according to the Building Codes adopted by the Village. 
2.  Structural requirements: Freestanding signs shall be designed and constructed in accordance with the standards established by the Building Codes adopted by the Village. 
3.  Location: Freestanding signs located on property adjacent to the Roosevelt Road right-of-way must maintain a minimum setback of ten feet from the lot line adjacent to Roosevelt Road and five feet from all other lot lines. All other freestanding signs must maintain a minimum setback of five feet from each property line. 
4.  Sign spacing: No freestanding sign shall be located closer than 30 feet to any other freestanding sign unless the Community Development Director determines such spacing to be impossible or impractical. 
5.  Number: A maximum of one freestanding establishment sign shall be permitted per property or development, except as otherwise expressly permitted herein for multi-tenant signs. 
6.  Base height: The base of a monument sign shall not be greater than five feet in height. 
7.  Support material: The material of the support structure shall match the primary material of the front building facade. 
8.  Landscaping: A landscape area equal to two square feet for each square foot of signage is required around the base of all freestanding signs. The landscaped area shall contain living landscape material consisting of shrubs, perennial ground cover plants or a combination of both. Nonconforming freestanding signs that are required to be modified to be compliant with the Sign Code shall provide the required amount of landscaping. 
(S)  Noncommercial speech: Any sign that can be displayed under the provisions of this chapter may contain a noncommercial message. 
(T)  General safety: Notwithstanding any other provision of this chapter, no sign shall be constructed or maintained in any area or in any manner so as to create a nuisance or a threat to the public safety and welfare as determined by the Community Development Director. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014; Ord. 6656, 12-10-2018; Ord. 6674, 2-25-2019) 
4-5-5. - Prohibited signs. 
The following signs are specifically prohibited: 
(A)  Abandoned sign in accordance with section 4-5-17 of this chapter. 
(B)  Attention getting devices, except for balloon displays, special event signs, public regulation signs and municipal signs expressly authorized by sections 4-5-6 and 4-5-7 of this chapter. 
(C)  Bare bulb illumination (except as permitted in subsection E of this section). 
(D)  Electronic identification signs. 
(E)  Festoon lighting (except in the C5A and C5B zoning districts in accordance with the following): 
1.  All such lights shall be white in color, except as otherwise allowed in association with permitted holiday decorations. 
2.  Such festoon lighting shall not blink, flash or otherwise change in illumination intensity. 
3.  A minimum clearance of seven feet six inches shall be maintained between ground level and any festoon lighting. 
4.  Such festoon lighting shall be maintained and operated in good working order. 
5.  Such festoon lighting shall not be strung across vehicular access drives, between buildings or in any location where it is the opinion of the fire chief that such lights may interfere with emergency operations. 
6.  Bare bulbs shall be kept a safe distance away from and shall not come in contact with any combustible material. 
7.  All festoon lighting shall conform with the applicable provisions of the Building Code. 
(F)  Indexing sign. 
(G)  Neon tube lighting or light emitting diode (LED) lighting outlining or illuminating the features of a building or structure including, but not limited to, windows. 
(H)  Neon, LED, and lighted window signs of any type are prohibited in the C5A and C5B zoning districts with the exception of window signs that contain only the word "Open" and no other wording, logos, pictures, graphics, or any other form of advertising, provided they are no larger than three square feet. 
(I)  Off premises sign or billboard sign, except for municipal signs, and special event signs authorized pursuant to sections 4-5-6 and 4-5-7 of this chapter. 
(J)  Pole or pylon sign with the exception of municipal signs and private traffic directional signs authorized by section 4-5-6 of this chapter. 
(K)  Portable sign, except on private property in the C5A and C5B zoning districts, pursuant to subsection 4-5-6(W) of this chapter or when authorized by the Village Manager in conjunction with construction, public notification or enforcement activities. 
(L)  Roof sign, including all types of inflatable balloons and other temporary signs. 
(M)  Signs attached to a tree, utility pole, light pole or light standard whether on public or private property, except as approved by the Village on village owned light poles or standards. 
(N)  Signs incorporating movement such as flashing signs, rotating signs, moving signs, animated signs, signs with moving lights, searchlights, or any other sign creating the illusion of movement with the exception of public regulation and municipal signs and electronic message boards expressly authorized herein. 
(O)  Signs painted directly on a roof or fence. 
(P)  Sign which contains words, statements or pictures of obscene, indecent or immoral characters and which offends public morals or decency of the Glen Ellyn community. 
(Q)  Vehicle and trailer signs. Any vehicle or trailer parked on private commercial property containing any advertising, lettering, graphics, or any other writing or illustration that advertises a business, product or service that is for sale and parked so as to be visible from any adjacent roadway. Provided however that during regular business hours, any vehicle or trailer necessary for the operation or servicing of a business on a given property and which contains advertising for the associated business, may be parked on the subject property provided that the vehicle or trailer is parked within a standard marked or striped parking space and is licensed, insured and operable and is not parked in the front yard if parking is available elsewhere on the site. Signs placed on parked vehicles for the primary purpose of attracting attention to an occupant's presence within a building or products or services that are for sale and signs resting on, or attached to, vehicles or trailers used as a means to circumvent the provisions of this chapter are prohibited. This section shall not apply to food trucks permitted by the Zoning Code. 

SIGN CAST
ONTO SIDEWALK
(R)  Any sign which by reason of size, location, content, color or type of illumination which is determined to be a traffic hazard as defined in section 4-5-4 of this chapter. 
(S)  Any sign which is located on or which extends over the public right-of-way except as expressly permitted by subsections 4-5-4(I) and (J) of this chapter. 
(T)  Any lighted sign cast onto a public or private sidewalk, street, building or other object. 
(U)  Any sign not expressly permitted by this chapter is prohibited. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014; amd. Ord. 6303, 3-9-2015; Ord. 6656, 12-10-2018) 
4-5-6. - Exempt signs. 
The following signs shall be exempt from the requirement to obtain a sign permit and pay fees (unless expressly stated otherwise below or a building permit is required for associated electrical or structural work), but shall be subject to the other provisions of this chapter, including sections 4-5-4 and 4-5-5 of this chapter. Exempt signs shall not be included for purpose of calculating the total allowable number and size of signs on a premises. No exempt sign shall exceed the maximum sign height permitted in the district it is located. 
(A)  Address sign: Address sign not over three square feet in area. 
(B)  Automatic teller machine (ATM) identification signage: An establishment identification sign located on an ATM machine provided that the size of such sign does not exceed a total of four square feet. 
(C)  Awning valance sign : Lettering and logos located on the valance of an awning provided the valance does not exceed eight inches in height and no lettering or logos exceed six inches in height. 
(D)  Balloon displays : Outdoor balloon displays in the C2 Community Commercial District, C3 Service Commercial District, and the C5A and C5B central business zoning districts provided that they comply with the following: 
1.  Such displays shall be limited to two bunches of no more than six) balloons per bunch for each business location. 
2.  The size of each balloon shall not exceed 24 inches in diameter. 
3.  Balloon displays shall only be displayed outside of the first floor of a building. 
4.  A minimum five foot wide clear area along all sidewalks must be maintained free from any balloon obstructions. 
5.  Balloons may not be attached to structures, street furniture, utility poles or signs in the public right-of-way. 
6.  Balloons shall not be placed in a location which obstructs the vision of pedestrians or motorists, restricts access or creates a dangerous condition. 
(E)  Breezeway sign: One sign located under the breezeway of a shopping center is permitted for each establishment in the shopping center. Establishments located in a corner unit may have two breezeway signs with one sign located under the breezeway of each exterior building elevation. Breezeway signs shall not exceed four square feet each. 
(F)  Common program sign: Upon written approval of the Village Manager or his or her designee, establishments in the C5A and C5B zoning districts shall be permitted to display a maximum of one flag or projecting banner sign that recognizes the establishment as participating in a program or initiative sponsored or facilitated by a governmental entity, community service organization or educational, religious or charitable organization provided that all such flags or banners throughout the C5A and C5B districts have a uniform design, size, colors and attachment/bracket system. Such signs may extend a maximum of 18 inches over the public right-of-way and must be removed upon conclusion of the program or initiative that they are associated with. A minimum clearance of seven feet must be maintained beneath any sign support structures and a maximum sign area of four square feet shall be permitted for the flag or banner. 
(G)  Decorations: Decorations customarily displayed on a national, local or religious holiday, provided they are displayed for a period of not more than 60 days. 
(H)  Door sign: Sign affixed to a door which identifies the name or address of the establishment and not exceeding two square feet. 
(I)  Drive-through canopy informational signage: Drive-through canopy informational signage. 
(J)  Flags: The official flags of any nation, political subdivision, religious, charitable, public or nonprofit organization. A corporate flag can be flown only in conjunction with the flag of the United States of America. 
(K)  Food trucks: Signage on permitted food trucks as defined by the Zoning Code. 
(L)  Garage sale: One sign not to exceed six square feet is permitted to advertise a private garage or yard sale. The sign must be located on private property and can be displayed only on the days of the sale. A garage sale sign shall not be illuminated. 
(M)  Gas station canopy signage : Signs located on a gas station canopy associated with a gas station use provided the signage complies with the following: 
1.  No more than one sign is permitted on the gas station canopy facing the front lot line. Corner properties may have one additional sign on the gas station canopy facing the corner side lot line. 
2.  Each sign shall be limited to no more than 14 square feet. 
3.  Signage shall not extend above, below, or to the sides of the fascia of the pump canopy. 
(N)  Gas station pump signage : Signs located on an individual gas pump associated with a gas station use provided the combined size of all signage located at each vehicle position of each gas pump does not exceed 12 square feet. 
(O)  Light pole banners: Shopping centers comprised of six and one-half acres or more and motor vehicle dealerships shall be permitted to install banners on no more than 50 percent of the light poles on their property. A maximum of two styles of banners shall be permitted with no more than one banner per pole and the banners shall be secured to the pole(s) at both the top and bottom. Each banner shall have an area of no more than 18 square feet and a minimum clearance of 12 feet shall be maintained between the banners and ground level. Light pole banner signs shall only be displayed on privately owned light standards and shall not extend over public property. 
(P)  Historic plaque: Commemorative plaque located on a historic structure officially designated as such by the Village or other nonprofit or community service organization. 
(Q)  Memorial sign: Memorial sign or tablet indicating the name of a building and/or date of construction when cut into any masonry surface or otherwise made an integral part of the structure whether made of bronze, aluminum or other noncombustible material. 
(R)  Menu boards: Drive-through businesses shall be permitted to display no more than three menu boards the area of which shall not exceed 60 square feet each. To the extent possible, menu boards shall be oriented so that the sign face is not visible from the public right-of-way or any adjacent residential property. A sign permit is required for a menu board. 
(S)  Miscellaneous information: Informational or instructional signage not including any business names, logos, emblems or other advertisements where the height of the lettering does not exceed four inches. 
(T)  Municipal signs: Municipal signs. 
(U)  Murals : Murals shall be exempt from the number and size requirements of a sign of a particular district. Murals shall be subject to exterior appearance review by staff and shall require Village Board approval prior to work commencing for said mural. 
(V)  Nameplate: Nameplates that do not exceed two square feet in area and that are directly fastened to a building, including signage for home occupations as defined in the Zoning Code. Where more than one business is located in a building such information must be consolidated on one common nameplate. The total square footage permitted for the common nameplate sign may be increased an additional two square feet for each additional business above one located in the building, provided that the total area of the nameplate sign does not exceed six square feet. 
(W)  Noncommercial speech: Noncommercial speech signs are only permitted on private property and may be placed on a property only with the approval of the property owner. The total area of noncommercial speech signage on a property shall not exceed 32 square feet. Corner lots may have two such signs, with one sign directed toward each street frontage. Noncommercial speech signs shall not be illuminated. 
(X)  Not visible: A sign that is not visible from a public right-of-way or neighboring residential property. 
(Y)  Open window sign : The total area of a sign indicating an establishment is open for business shall not exceed three square feet and shall be limited one sign per establishment. Open signs shall only be located on the inside of a window of an establishment and shall not be placed on the exterior of the building. No advertising of any kind is permitted in an open sign. Open signs shall be static and shall not flash, blink, or contain any type of motion or animation. 
(Z)  Order confirmation sign: The total area of any advertising on an order confirmation sign shall not exceed two square feet. 
(AA)  Political campaign signs : The total area of political campaign signs, announcing candidates seeking office or political issues, shall not exceed a total of 32 square feet for each property. Corner lots may have two such signs, with one sign directed toward each street frontage. Political campaign signs are only permitted on private property and may be placed on a property only with the approval of the property owner. Political campaign signs shall not be illuminated. Political campaign signs located in nonresidential districts shall be removed from a property no later than one week following the date of an election. 
(BB)  Portable sign: One portable sign may be located on a private sidewalk for ground floor establishments in the C5A and C5B zoning districts and shopping centers in the C3 zoning district comprised of six and one-half acres or more provided that a five foot area is maintained on the sidewalk free of any obstructions. Permission may be granted by a property owner to allow businesses located above or below a ground floor establishment to also use the sign. Portable signs are only permitted to be displayed when the associated business or businesses are open and shall not exceed six square feet in area and four feet in height. Portable signs are not allowed in the public right-of-way and shall not be illuminated. 
(CC)  Private parking lot sign: Private parking lot sign not exceeding six square feet in area per sign. Private parking lot signs shall not be illuminated. 
(DD)  Private warning signs: Such signs shall be no more than six square feet in area each, shall be limited to the number necessary to accomplish the intended purpose, and shall be illuminated only as required to accomplish such purpose. Such signs may include, but not be limited to, towing and no trespass signs. 
(EE)  Public regulation signs: Public regulation signs. 
(FF)  Railroad sign: Warnings at railroad crossings. 
(GG)  Real estate sign: Real estate signs must be located entirely within the property to which the sign applies and must be removed within seven days after the sale, rental or lease has been accomplished. Real estate signs shall not be illuminated. 
1.  Detached single-family, attached single-family and two-family properties may have one real estate sign with an area not exceeding six square feet. 
2.  Multi-family and nonresidential properties may have one sign with an area not exceeding 32 square feet, except that corner lots may have a maximum of two with one sign directed toward each street frontage. 
(HH)  Religious symbol: Religious symbol or commemorative plaque located on a building or property. 
(II)  Scoreboard: Scoreboard for athletic fields, provided that no more than 25 percent of the area is used for advertising and any electronic portion thereof complies with the provisions for message boards set forth in section 4-5-15 of this chapter. 
(JJ)  Special event sign: In accordance with the provisions set forth in section 4-5-7 of this chapter. 
(KK)  Temporary construction signs: One sign per construction project is permitted identifying the names of the architects, engineers, contractors and other firms or individuals involved in the project. A temporary construction sign shall not exceed 32 square feet. Corner lots may have two such signs, with one sign directed toward each street frontage. Temporary construction signs must be located on the same site as the associated construction project, and removed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy, whether temporary or final. Temporary construction signs shall not be illuminated. 
(LL)  Temporary developer's sign: One sign advertising future construction on a site shall be permitted. A temporary developer's sign shall not exceed 32 square feet. Corner lots may have two such signs, with one sign directed toward each street frontage. Temporary developer's signs must be located on the same site as the associated construction project, and removed prior to issuance of a certificate of occupancy, whether temporary or final. Temporary developer's signs shall not be illuminated. 
(MM)  Temporary fundraising sign: One temporary sign advertising a fundraiser shall be permitted on a property. A temporary fundraising sign shall not exceed 32 square feet. Corner lots may have two such signs, with one sign directed toward each street frontage. Temporary fundraising signs may be located on a property for no more than 45 consecutive days and shall be removed within seven days of the conclusion of the associated fundraiser. Temporary fundraising signs shall not be illuminated. 
(NN)  Temporary hiring signs: Temporary signs indicating that a business or other entity is hiring personnel. Such signs shall not exceed six square feet in area and must be located on the same premises as the business or entity doing the hiring. Temporary hiring signs shall not be illuminated. 
(OO)  Traffic directional sign: No more than two signs shall be displayed at each entrance or exit and no more than five such signs shall be displayed on the interior of the lot. Each sign shall not exceed four square feet in area and four feet in height. In commercially zoned districts, no more than 25 percent of each sign shall be used to advertise any business, product or service, and such signs shall contain no advertisement in residential districts. The use of standard traffic signalization (stop, yield, etc.) is not limited by this chapter. 
(PP)  Vendor carts: Signage located on vendor carts with an approved license from the Village. 
(QQ)  Window display: Merchandise, pictures or models of products or services incorporated in a window display. 
(RR)  Window sign: Sign located on the interior or exterior of a window in the CR, CC, C2, C3, C4, C5 and C6 zoning districts; provided that not more than 50 percent of the total window area or an individual windowpane is covered. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014; amd. Ord. 6221, 3-10-2014; Ord. 6301, 2-23-2015; Ord. 6303, 3-9-2015; Ord. 6656, 12-10-2018) 
4-5-7. - Special event signs. 
No special event sign shall be installed outdoors except under the conditions identified below. Special event signs shall be exempt from the requirement to obtain a permit and pay fees (except for banner signs or unless a building permit is required for associated electrical or structural work), but shall be subject to the other provisions of this chapter, including sections 4-5-4 and 4-5-5 of this chapter. No special event sign identified below shall exceed the maximum sign height permitted in the district it is located. 
(A)  Commercial event banner sign: An on premises banner sign advertising or directing attention to a special product, promotion, or other commercial event may be located only in commercial districts with the issuance of a sign permit in accordance with the following standards: 
1.  Application for approval shall be made by the owner or tenant of property; 
2.  Signs shall not exceed 32 square feet in area; 
3.  There shall not be more than one banner sign per lot, except that on a corner lot two signs, one directed toward each street, shall be allowed; 
4.  The banner sign shall be affixed at each corner in such a manner so as not to allow wind activation; 
5.  Banner signs may be displayed for a maximum period of 14 days; 
6.  No entity may display a banner sign more than three times a calendar year; with the exception of new businesses which are permitted to display one additional banner sign advertising a grand opening; 
7.  Banner signs may not be located on or over the public right-of-way; 
8.  Signage must be located on the site of the event and on property owned or controlled by the business, organization or institution hosting the event. 
(B)  Special event sign; private property: Special event signs, banner signs and displays for special events sponsored by governmental entities, community service organizations and educational, religious and charitable institutions are allowed in accordance with the following standards: 
1.  The sign must be located on property owned or controlled by the organization or institution; 
2.  Such signs may be displayed for a maximum period commencing 14 days prior to, and ending three days after, the scheduled event; 
3.  Banner signs shall be affixed at each corner in such a manner so as not to allow wind activation; 
4.  Signs shall not exceed 32 square feet in area; 
5.  There shall not be more than one sign per lot, except that on a corner lot two signs, one directed toward each street, shall be allowed; 
6.  No entity may display a temporary banner sign more than three times a year; except for religious institutions who shall be permitted to display such signage in conjunction with all religious holidays and events; 
7.  Signage advertising or providing direction to special events of governmental entities, community service organizations and educational, religious and charitable institutions may only be placed on private property with the permission of the property owner; and 
8.  Such signs may not be located on or extend over a public right-of-way. 
(C)  Special event sign; rights-of-way: Special event directional signs, whether for governmental entities, educational, religious and charitable institutions, or community service organizations are allowed only upon prior written approval of the Village Manager or his or her designee, in accordance with the following standards: 
1.  The sign may extend on, into or over the public right-of-way or easement on the basis of need, impact on pedestrian and vehicular traffic and impact on surrounding property; 
2.  Such signs are limited to a total of ten signs for the event; 
3.  Each sign shall not exceed a maximum height of three feet and a maximum surface area of six square feet per sign; 
4.  No special event directional sign may be displayed for more than one day immediately preceding the event, and the sign must be removed immediately after the conclusion of the event; and 
5.  A minimum five-foot wide open area along all sidewalks must be maintained free from any obstructions. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014)

4-5-13. - Sign area and height computations. 
(A)  Sign area: The area of a sign shall be computed in accordance with the following: 
1.  The area of a sign shall be measured by computing the area of the smallest polygon that can encompass all words, letters, figures, emblems, and other elements of the sign (see subsections (A)6.(a) and (A)6.(e) of this section). 
2.  Any material or color used as an integral part of the display or to differentiate the sign from the surface on which it is placed shall be included in calculating the area of the sign (see subsections (A)6.(b), (A)6.(c), (A)6.(d) and (A)6.(f) of this section). 
3.  The supporting structure or bracing of a sign shall be omitted in measuring the area of the sign, unless such structure or bracing is made part of the message or face of the sign (see subsections (A)6.(c), (A)6.(d) and (A)6.(f) of this section). 
4.  Only one side of a double faced sign shall be used in calculating the area of the sign provided that both faces are the same dimension, parallel to each other, and supported by the same structure. 
5.  When different elements of a sign are separated by a distance equal to or greater than half of the maximum height of the tallest element of the sign, such elements shall be considered separate signs (see subsection (A)6.(g) of this section). 
6.  Examples: 
(a) Individual letters/elements mounted on a building: (b) Wall sign with contrasting background on building or box sign: (c) Freestanding sign: (d) Individual letters mounted on brick or other background: (e) Sign area of awning: (f) Sign area of multi-tenant sign: (g) Spacing between different sign elements:    
(B)  Sign height: The height of a sign shall be the distance measured from grade level vertically to the highest point of the sign structure. Where a freestanding sign is located on uneven ground the height shall be the average height of the two extreme ends of the sign measured from grade (see subsection (B)1.(c) of this section). 
1.  Examples: 
(a) Freestanding sign supported by end piers: (b) Monument sign: (c) Freestanding sign on uneven ground:  
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014) 
4-5-14. - Bonus provisions to increase sign area. 
The maximum permitted sign area set forth in sections 4-5-8 to 4-5-12 of this chapter may be increased by a specified percentage for compliance with the design criteria listed below. The percentage increase shall be based on the original maximum sign area allowed. If more than one criterion is met, then bonuses may be granted cumulatively. 
(A)  Individual letters: Ten percent bonus for any wall sign which consists of individual letters mounted directly on the building surface. For the purposes of this chapter, letters mounted on a raceway are not considered individual letter signs. 
(B)  Setback: One percent cumulative bonus for any wall sign for every ten feet the building is set back above and beyond the required building setback. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014) 
4-5-15. - Message boards. 
Message boards (manual changing or electronic) shall be allowed subject to the following regulations, in addition to all other applicable regulations in this chapter: 
(A)  Message boards shall be erected only by attachment to a freestanding sign. Only one message board per property is allowed. Manually changing message boards are allowed in all zoning districts. Electric message boards shall only be permitted as expressly identified herein below. 
(B)  The area of a message board shall be included in the allowable area of identification signage for the establishment or property. The maximum area of a message board shall not exceed 18 square feet, unless operated by a governmental body. 
(C)  Messages must be static, the use of video displays, animation, or flashing, scrolling or blinking characters is prohibited. 
(D)  All message boards are subject to the illumination standards in subsection 4-5-4(E) of this chapter. 
(E)  Message board text and graphics must be located on a black or "paper white" background. 
(F)  A message board displaying time, temperature or date is allowed only in commercial districts, with the exception of the C5A and C5B districts. The message shall update in intervals of no less than five seconds. 
(G)  An electronically variable message board sign, other than a time, temperature and date sign is allowed for governmental bodies and for property in the CC, CR, C3, C4 and C6 districts subject to the following regulations: 
1.  The sign shall be equipped with photosensitive equipment which automatically adjusts the brightness and contrast of the sign in direct relation to the ambient outdoor illumination. 
2.  In locations where an electronic message board is visible to an adjacent residential use, the message board may operate only between the hours of 6:00 a.m. and 10:00 p.m. and shall be turned off when not in operation. 
3.  The message displayed on such sign may be changed no more than once every 15 seconds. 
4.  The face of an electronically variable message board shall be oriented away from any adjacent residential properties to the extent possible and shall not cause illumination in excess of 0.05 foot-candle at any residential property line adjoining or across the street from the electronically variable message board. 
5.  Messages must change instantaneously and shall not fade out or dissolve. 
6.  Single messages shall not be divided between two or more screens. 
7.  The Village shall have the right to utilize any electronic message board during emergency situations to provide instructions and information to the public. Examples of such emergency situations may include, but not be limited to, natural disasters and Amber Alerts. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014) 
4-5-16. - CC Community College Special Sign District. 
In accordance with subsection 4-5-17(G)1.(c) of this chapter, the CC community college zoning district is hereby designated as a special sign district. The permitted type, number, height and area of signage in this district shall be in accordance with a comprehensive sign plan approved by the Village. Signage in this district shall otherwise comply with all other provisions in this chapter. 
(Ord. 6215, 2-10-2014) 
4-5-17. - Sign Code administration. 
This chapter shall be administered in accordance with the following provisions: 
(A)  Type, size, location and number of signs: Permitted sign types and the maximum surface area, maximum height, location and number of such signs are established for zoning districts as they are defined in the Zoning Code, and delineated on the zoning district map published annually by the Village. Each sign type permitted shall meet all the applicable standards in this chapter. 
(B)  Sign permit required: Unless otherwise exempted from this chapter, no sign shall be erected, altered or relocated without a permit being issued by the Building and Zoning Official. When an electrical permit is required, it shall be obtained at the same time as the sign permit. 
1.  Permit exceptions: No permit shall be required for repainting, cleaning and other normal maintenance or repair of a sign, or for changing copy on a sign specifically designed for the use of changeable copy. 
2.  Permit application: Application for a permit shall be made to the Building and Zoning Official on the forms provided by the Village and shall include the following information: 
(a)  Permit fees: Every applicant shall pay the applicable permit fee set forth in this Code. 
(b)  Identity: Name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of applicant, person, firm, corporation or association submitting the application and the owner of the property if the property is not owned by the applicant. 
(c)  Proof of ownership: Proof of ownership in the form of a deed or title insurance policy for the property on which the sign is to be placed. 
(d)  Location: Location of the building, structure or parcel of property to which, or upon which, the sign is to be attached or erected. 
(e)  Sign plan: A plan showing the location of the proposed sign(s) and any other existing signs on the property in relation to nearby buildings, structures, access drives and parking spaces with the setback of the sign from any adjacent rights-of-way identified. 
(f)  Structural drawings: Unless waived by the Building and Zoning Official, two copies of plans and specifications showing the method of construction, location and support. These plans must be sealed by a registered architect, structural engineer or registered professional engineer. 
(g)  Sign elevation: An elevation or sketch showing sign faces, exposed surfaces and proposed message thereof accurately represented in scale as to size, proportion, dimensions of letters and features, color and with the total square footage of the sign noted thereon. 
(h)  Building elevation: If the sign is to be placed on a building or other structure, an elevation or photo rendering drawn to scale shall be submitted showing the sign thereon. 
(i)  Owner's consent: If the sign is proposed to be placed on property not owned by the applicant, written consent of the owner(s) of the building, structure or land on which the sign is to be erected. 
(j)  Indemnification: The owner of the sign for any and all signage projecting over the public right-of-way shall indemnify and hold the Village harmless from any damage, cause of action or claim to be caused by the improper construction or maintenance of the sign. 
(k)  Removal upon abandonment: A statement that the sign owners agree to remove the sign at their own expense in the event the sign is abandoned as defined in subsection (E) of this section. 
(l)  Other information: Such other information as may be reasonably required by the Building and Zoning Official to show full compliance with this and all other ordinances of the Village. 
(C)  Issuance of permit: It shall be the duty of the Building and Zoning Official or his or her designee, upon the filing of an application for a permit to examine such plans and specifications, and determine whether or not the proposed structure is in compliance with all requirements of this chapter and all other provisions of this Code, in which event a permit shall be issued. If the work authorized under the permit has not been initiated within six months and completed within 12 months after the date of issuance, the permit shall become null and void. 
(D)  Removal of unsafe or unlawful sign: If the Building and Zoning Official shall find that any sign is unsafe, insecure or a menace to the public, or has been constructed, erected or maintained in violation of the provisions of this section, written notice shall be given to the property owner, sign owner or permittee thereof. If the property owner, sign owner or permittee fails to remove or alter the structure so as to comply with the standards herein set forth within 15 days after such notice, the Building and Zoning Official may cause the sign to be removed or repaired to place the sign in a safe condition pursuant to the corporate powers granted by the Illinois Municipal Code as amended. The Village may remove any sign illegally placed in the public right-of-way without prior notice. 
(E)  Removal of abandoned sign: 
1.  Nonconforming sign: If the Building and Zoning Official finds that a nonconforming sign is abandoned, the official shall give written notice to the permittee or owner to remove the sign. If the permittee or owner fails to remove or bring such sign and sign structure into conformance with this chapter within 30 days after such notice, the Building and Zoning Official may initiate judicial process to cause the sign to be removed, and the owner shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of this Code. 
2.  Conforming sign: If the Building and Zoning Official finds that a conforming sign is abandoned, the official shall give written notice to the permittee or owner thereof. If the permittee or owner fails to cover the sign face with an opaque single color material or remove the sign face within 30 days after such requirement notice, the Building and Zoning Official may initiate judicial process to cause the sign to be removed, and the owner shall be subject to the general penalty provisions of this Code. 
(F)  Enforcement official: 
1.  The Community Development Director is hereby authorized and directed to enforce all of the provisions of this chapter. Upon presentation of proper credentials, the Community Development Director, or a duly authorized representative, may enter, at reasonable times, any building, structure or premises in the Village to perform any duty imposed by this chapter. 
2.  Where there is any ambiguity or dispute concerning the interpretation of this chapter, the interpretation of the Community Development Director shall prevail, subject to appeal as provided herein. 
(G)  Sign variation request: 
1.  Manner of requesting: 
(a)  Any person seeking a variation from this chapter shall file an application with the Community Development Director who shall, in a timely manner, place the request on an agenda for the Plan Commission to consider at a public hearing. The Plan Commission shall act in an advisory capacity and make a recommendation on the request to the Village Board of Trustees. Upon receiving a recommendation from the Plan Commission, the request shall be scheduled for consideration by the Village Board in a timely manner. The Village Board shall then approve, approve with conditions or deny the application. 
(b)  An application for variation must be filed with the Director of Community Development on the forms provided by the Village and shall contain at least the following: 
(1)  Application fee: Every applicant shall pay the applicable application fee for a sign variation request set forth in this Code. 
(2)  Sign variation application: A completed sign variation application, including information about how the request complies with the standards for granting approval of a sign variation set forth in subsection (G)3. of this section. 
(3)  Identity: Name, address, e-mail address and telephone number of applicant, person, firm, corporation or association proposing to install the sign and the owner of the property if the property is not owned by the applicant. 
(4)  Proof of ownership: Proof of ownership in the form of a deed or title insurance policy for the property on which the sign is proposed. 
(5)  Legal description: A current legal description of the property. 
(6)  Location: Location of the building, structure or parcel of property to which, or upon which, the sign is to be attached or erected. 
(7)  Sign plan: A dimensioned plan showing the location of the proposed sign(s) and all other existing signage on the property in relation to nearby buildings, structures, drive aisles and parking spaces with the setback of the sign(s) from any adjacent rights-of-way identified. 
(8)  Sign elevation: An elevation or sketch showing sign faces, exposed surfaces and proposed message thereof accurately represented in scale as to size, proportion, dimensions of letters and features, color and with the total square footage of the sign noted thereon measured from ground level. 
(9)  Building elevation: If the sign is to be placed on a building or other structure, an elevation or photo rendering drawn to scale shall be submitted showing the sign thereon and indicating the height of the sign.
