(D)  Rabies control: Each cat which bites a person shall be promptly reported to the Police Department and, thereupon, shall be securely quarantined in a veterinary hospital for a period of ten days. Upon a demand made by a Police Officer, the owner shall immediately surrender for supervised quarantine any cat which has bitten a person or which is suspected of having been exposed to rabies, and the expense of such quarantine shall be borne by the owner. 
An owner or keeper of a cat which has bitten a person, or which is suspected of having rabies, who shall, upon demand by a Police Officer, refuse to immediately deliver such cat to the officer, shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor. 
The Police Department of the Village, upon receipt of any notification or report of a cat bite or that a cat has symptoms indicative of rabies, shall immediately determine, so far as possible, the identity of each person known or suspected to have been bitten by or come in contact with such cat, so that each person, his parents or guardian, may be given adequate warning. 
Every veterinarian or any person discovering any cat suffering from rabies shall immediately report this fact to the Police Department. This report shall give the name, if known, the place of residence of the person owning or keeping such cat, and the place where the cat can be found. The cat shall be immediately taken up and placed in a veterinary hospital for observation by a licensed veterinarian until the time of its death or recovery. In the event of its death, the head shall be removed, and a suitable pathological examination of the brain made to determine whether or not the cat died of rabies. 
The owner or keeper of a cat suspected of having, or having, rabies shall be liable for all veterinary and laboratory fees incurred pursuant to any provisions of this section. 
(Ord. 1597, 7-8-1968; amd. 1975 Code; Ord. 2148, 11-22-1976; Ord. 5352, 4-25-2005; Ord. 6481, 2-13-2017) 
Chapter 4 - FAIR HOUSING 

6-4-1. - Policy. 
It is hereby declared to be the policy of the Village and the purpose of this chapter, in the exercise by the Village of its Police and regulatory powers for the protection of the public safety, for the health, morals, safety and welfare of the persons in and residing in the Village, and for the maintenance and promotion of commerce, industry and good government in the Village, to secure to all persons living, or desiring to live, in the Village an equal opportunity to purchase, lease, rent or occupy housing regardless of color, national origin, race or religion. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-2. - Severability. 
If any provision of this chapter, or the application thereof to any person or circumstances, is held invalid, the remainder of this chapter and the application of the provisions to other persons not similarly situated, or to other circumstances, shall not be affected thereby. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-3. - Definitions. 
For the purpose of this chapter, the following words and phrases are defined as follows: 
ADVERTISE: To announce publicly, by posted sign, printed notice or any other means, that property is for sale or rent. 
BOARD: The President and Board of Trustees of the Village. 
COMMISSION: The Glen Ellyn Community Relations Commission. 
DISCRIMINATE: To categorically distinguish between persons on a basis of color, national origin, race or religion rather than individual merit. 
HOUSING ACCOMMODATION: Includes any building or structure, or portion thereof, which is used or occupied, maintained, arranged or designed to be used as a home. 
LEASE: Includes sublease, assignment and rental, and includes any contract to do any of the foregoing. 
LENDING INSTITUTION: Any bank, insurance company, savings and loan association, other persons in the business of lending money or guaranteeing loans, any person in the business of obtaining, arranging or negotiating loans as agent or broker, and any person in the business of buying or selling loans or instruments for the payment of money which are secured by title to, or a security interest in, real estate. 
MEDIATOR: A person designated by the board to act between parties at variance to effect an agreement, compromise or reconciliation under the provisions of this chapter. 
OWNER: Any person, firm, corporation, trust or association holding any interest in property which may be used for housing accommodations. 
PURCHASE: Includes any contract to purchase. 
QUALIFIED BUYER: Any person having the present financial ability to purchase or rent the housing accommodation selected, or a duly authorized attorney or real estate broker representing such person. 
REAL ESTATE BROKER: Any person who, for a consideration, acts as an employee or agent to manage or negotiate the sale, purchase or rental of any real property, or any interest therein. Real estate broker includes, but is not limited to, all persons required to be licensed pursuant to the provisions of 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes. 
REAL ESTATE SALESMAN: Any person licensed as a real estate salesman in accordance with the provisions of 225 Illinois Compiled Statutes, or who is required thereby to be licensed. 
REAL ESTATE TRANSACTION: The purchase, sale, exchange or lease of any real property, or interest therein, or any negotiations in connection therewith. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-4. - Licenses. 
Before the license of a real estate broker is issued or renewed, the applicant shall file a signed statement with the Village Clerk that he has read this chapter and agrees to comply with its provisions, and that each real estate salesman employed by him has read, and will comply with, this chapter. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-5. - Unlawful real estate practices. 
It shall be unlawful for any real estate broker, either by himself or his officers, employees or real estate salesmen, to: 
(A)  Make any substantial misrepresentation or engage in untruthful advertising in connection with any real estate transaction. 
(B)  Act for more than one party in a transaction without the knowledge and consent of all parties for whom he acts. 
(C)  Fail to furnish copies, upon request, of all documents relating to a real estate transaction to all parties executing the same. 
(D)  Pay a commission or any consideration to any person for acts or services performed, in violation of this chapter. 
(E)  Employ any person as a means of evading the law. 
(F)  Display a "FOR RENT" or "FOR SALE" sign on any property without the written consent of an owner or his authorized agent, or advertise any property for sale or for rent in a newspaper or other publication without the consent of the owner or his authorized agent. 
(G)  Fail, within a reasonable time, to provide information requested by the board, commission or mediator in connection with a complaint for a violation of this chapter. 
(H)  Perform any other act which constitutes a violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-6. - Discrimination prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any owner who has advertised or listed his property for sale or rent or a real estate broker, salesman, lender, financial institution or advertiser, either by himself or through his officers, employees, agents or salesmen to: 
(A)  Discriminate against any qualified buyer in connection with any real estate transaction. 
(B)  Publish or circulate, or cause to be published or circulated, any notice, statement or advertisement, announce a policy, use any form of application for the purchase, lease, rental or financing of real property, or make any record or inquiry in connection with the prospective purchase, rental or lease of real property, which expresses, directly or indirectly any discrimination, or intent to discriminate. 
(C)  Discriminate by overcharging any qualified buyer for real property, or by changing conditions or privileges of any kind relating to a real estate transaction. 
(D)  Discriminate in connection with borrowing or lending money, guaranteeing loans, accepting mortgages, or otherwise obtaining or making available funds for the purchase, acquisition, construction, rehabilitation, repair or maintenance of any real property in the Village. 
(E)  Solicit or enter into any agreement for the sale, lease or listing for sale or lease of any real property within the Village on the ground of loss of value due to the present or prospective entry into any neighborhood of any person or persons of any particular race, religion, national origin or gender orientation, in violation of section 6-2-1.1 of this title. 
(F)  Distribute, or cause to be distributed, written material or statements designed to induce any owner of real property in the Village to sell or lease real property because of any present or prospective change in the race, religion, national origin or gender orientation of persons in the neighborhood. 
(G)  Make any statement that the presence, or anticipated presence, of persons of any particular race, religion, national origin or gender orientation in that area will, or may, result in the lowering of real property values in the area, block or neighborhood, in an attempt to obtain a listing for lease or sale, or the lease or sale, of any property. 
(H)  Refuse to sell or lease real property, or any interest therein, to a qualified buyer because of race, religion, national origin or gender orientation. 
(I)  Refuse to show to any qualified buyer who has specified his needs and demonstrated his ability to finance the purchase or lease of real property the list or other records identifying all real properties reasonably meeting such specifications. 
(J)  Aid, abet, incite or coerce any person to engage in unlawful housing practices. 
(K)  Willfully interfere with the performance of a duty or the exercise of a power by the commission, or one of its members or representatives. 
(L)  Willfully obstruct or prevent a person from complying with the provisions of this chapter, or an order issued thereunder. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968; amd. Ord. 5751, 4-27-2009) 
6-4-7. - Inciting discrimination. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to aid, abet, incite or coerce any other person to discriminate in the sale, purchase or rental of a housing accommodation. 
(Ord. 1696, 1-11-1971) 
6-4-8. - Limitations and exclusions. 
(A)  This chapter shall not apply to the rental of a room in any owner occupied single-family dwelling, or to the rental of a housing accommodation in an owner occupied duplex. 
(B)  Nothing in this chapter shall require an owner to offer for sale or lease real property to the public at large, nor shall this chapter be deemed to prohibit discrimination for any reason other than race, religion, national origin or gender orientation. 
(C)  Nothing in this chapter shall require a broker or owner offering real property for sale or lease to show such property to any person not negotiating for the purchase or lease of such real property in good faith, either for himself or his principal. 
(D)  Nothing in this chapter shall prevent an owner from taking his property off the market or removing it from any previous listing. 
(E)  An agent acting for an undisclosed principal shall be personally liable for the contract he makes. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968; amd. Ord. 5751, 4-27-2009) 
6-4-9. - Duties of Community Relations Commission. 
It shall be the duty of the Community Relations Commission to initiate, receive and investigate complaints charging discrimination; seek conciliation of such complaints or compliance by violators; and hold hearings, make findings of fact, issue recommendations, and publish its findings of fact and recommendations, in accordance with the provisions of this chapter: 
(A)  Any person aggrieved in any manner by a violation of any provision of this chapter may file a written complaint with the mediator. The complaint shall be under oath, addressed to the commission, and shall state: 1) the name and address of the complainant, 2) the name and address of the person against whom the complaint is brought, if known to the complainant, and 3) the facts surrounding the alleged violation of this chapter. Such complaint shall state the name and address of all persons believed to have knowledge concerning the alleged violation. 
The commission shall provide a printed form of complaint for the use of aggrieved persons. 
(B)  After the filing of the complaint, the mediator shall serve a copy of the complaint personally, or by certified mail, on the party or parties charged, and shall furnish a copy to the chairman of the commission. 
(C)  The mediator shall investigate the complaint; and if he determines that probable cause exists in support of the allegations of the complaint, he shall set a date for a meeting and notify the parties of the time and place thereof. At such meeting, the mediator shall interview the complainant and the person or persons against whom the complaint has been directed, and attempt to resolve the complaint by reconciliation. 
(D)  If the mediator is unable to conciliate the complaint, he shall notify the chairman of the commission within 30 days after the filing of the complaint, and the commission shall, within ten days, hold a hearing on the complaint, either by the full commission or by a three-member panel thereof, as determined by the chairman. 
(E)  If the mediator determines that no grievance exists, the complaint shall be dismissed. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968; amd. Ord. 1696, 1-11-1971) 
6-4-10. - Hearing by commission or panel. 
Hearings shall be conducted by the commission or a panel thereof, upon notice, by certified mail, to all parties. The conference shall provide a court reporter to take a transcript of the hearing. All evidence shall be under oath administered by an officer authorized to administer oaths. All parties, at their election, may be represented by counsel, and shall have the right to call witnesses and cross examine witnesses. If the hearing is conducted by a three-member panel, the panel shall furnish the commission with its findings of fact, its recommendations, and a transcript of the hearing. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-11. - Action by the Commission. 
Within five days after the conclusion of a hearing, the commission shall take any one or more of the following actions: 
(A)  Resolve the complaint by conciliation; 
(B)  Dismiss the complaint; 
(C)  Make findings and recommendations to the board regarding revocation of license; 
(D)  Recommend that the board file a complaint in the circuit court for a fine, or a complaint to enjoin the violation and for other appropriate relief; or 
(E)  In the case of the violation of this chapter by any person in the course of performing under a contract or subcontract with the state, or any political subdivision or agency thereof, or with the United States of America, or any agency or instrumentality thereof, notify, by certified mail, such contracting agency for the purpose of causing it to terminate such contract, or any portion thereof, either absolutely or on condition of compliance with the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-12. - Action by board. 
The Board shall act upon the report or recommendation of the commission on or before the second meeting following receipt of such report or recommendation. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-13. - Action by complainant. 
At any time after final action by the board, or after dismissal of a complaint by the mediator or commission, or in the event of the failure of the mediator, commission or board to act on a complaint within the time limits herein set forth, the complainant may file a complaint in the circuit court for appropriate relief for the alleged violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
6-4-14. - Time limit; file complaint. 
Any complaint shall be barred from consideration unless it is filed with the commission within 30 days after the alleged discriminatory practice occurred. However, it is recommended that all complaints be filed within seven days of the first knowledge of the alleged discriminatory practice. 
(Ord. 1593, 5-27-1968) 
Chapter 5 - PARADES; OPEN AIR MEETINGS 

6-5-1. - Permit required. 
No parade shall be allowed on any public way, nor shall any open air public meeting be held in or upon any public way, or upon any ground abutting upon any public way, until a permit therefor shall first be obtained from the Police Chief. 
Application to conduct such parade, procession or open air meeting shall be made in writing to the Village President and Board of Trustees at least 30 days prior to the event by the person or persons in charge or control thereof or responsible therefor; and such application shall set forth the desired route along which such parade or procession is to proceed, the desired time of starting, the duration, the name of the person or society in control thereof, and the purpose of such parade or procession. 
In the case of an open air meeting, such application shall specify the place at which it is desired to hold such meeting, the purpose thereof, the name of the person or society in control thereof, the time at which such meeting is to be held, and the probable duration thereof. Upon such application being made, the Police Chief shall investigate, or cause to be investigated, the person or society making such application and the truth of the statements made therein. 
(Ord. 1555, 11-13-1967) 
6-5-2. - Prohibited throwaways. 
No candy, gum, balloons, toy, promotional novelty or advertisement shall be tossed or pitched from any vehicle participating in a parade, except that such items may be distributed by persons walking or standing along the permitted parade route. 
(Ord. 1555, 11-13-1967) 
Chapter 6 - POLICE/FIRE ALARM SYSTEMS 

6-6-1. - Purpose. 
The purpose of this chapter is to define, prevent and abate nuisances resulting from false alarms summoning the Police/Fire Department by establishing regulations and controls for the various types of privately owned Police and fire alarm devices designed to summon the Police/Fire Department to any location in response to a signal, whether the signal is visual, audible, transmitted, telephoned, radioed, or otherwise relayed, directly or indirectly, to the Police/Fire Department, by requiring permits therefor, by establishing fees and by providing for punishment of violations of provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-2. - Definitions. 
ALARM SYSTEM: Any signaling device which sends visual and/or audible signals, whether that signal is visually displayed or audibly sounded in or on the premises where the alarm is located or transmitted over a signal line to be registered by indicators at a monitor panel in a receiving terminal of the Police/Fire Department and/or alarm answering company's receiving location. 
ALARM USER: Any person on whose premises an alarm system is maintained within the Village except for alarm systems on motor vehicles or contained within proprietary systems which have the control system located within the premises and under the supervision of, and monitored by, the proprietor of the protected premises. 
AUTOMATIC PROTECTION DEVICE: An instrument which automatically sends a visual and/or audible alarm signal directly to the Glen Ellyn Police and/or Fire Department over regular public telephone lines upon detection of a fire, unauthorized intrusion, and/or medical emergency. 
CALENDAR YEAR: The period commencing on January 1 and ending on December 31 of each year. 
FALSE ALARM: The activation of an alarm system through electrical or mechanical failure, malfunction, improper installation, or negligence of the owner or lessee of an alarm system or of his employees or agents. "False alarm" does not include alarm signals activated by violent conditions of nature, telephone line interruptions, acts of God, or other extraordinary circumstances not reasonably subject to control by the alarm user. 
YEAR: The period commencing on September 1 and ending on August 31 of each year. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982; amd. Ord. 5737, 3-9-2009; Ord. 5765, 6-8-2009) 
6-6-3. - Automatic protection devices prohibited. 
No person shall operate or maintain any automatic protection device which automatically transmits a signal, message or warning directly to the Glen Ellyn Police/Fire Department or its agents. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-4. - Permit required. 
Each person within the Village who wishes to install, maintain or operate, in his home, place of business or other premises, an alarm system, calculated to directly or indirectly summon the Police or Fire Department, or that is connected directly or indirectly to the Police and/or Fire Department or to an alarm answering company's receiving location, shall obtain an alarm user's permit for each separate alarm system he wishes to operate. 
Without regard to the person who is the holder of the license, the person or persons who install, maintain or operate the alarm system, along with the owner of the property where the alarm system has been installed, shall all be subject to the obligations and responsibilities under this chapter, although only one of them shall be required to procure and update the information, which results in the issuance of a permit. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982; Ord. 5765, 6-8-2009) 
6-6-5. - Restrictions on alarm systems. 
The following restrictions shall apply to all alarm systems installed, maintained or operated in the Village: 
(A)  Each alarm system and any corresponding alarm indicator which terminates at the Police/Fire Department shall be used to report only one specific type of emergency; 
(B)  Each alarm system terminating at the Police/Fire Department must include a reversible relay which will indicate whether an alarm indication is due to a transmission line malfunction; 
(C)  No person shall conduct any test or demonstration of an alarm system without first obtaining permission from the Police Chief or his duly authorized agent, and test or demonstration without prior permission shall be deemed a false alarm; 
(D)  Each alarm system terminating at the Police/Fire Department shall be installed, maintained, or operated with a device which will prevent activation of the alarm signal during the process of turning on and/or off the alarm system; and 
(E)  Each alarm system which will include a bell, horn or other noise making device which is mounted on the exterior of a building, or can be heard outside the protected premises must be equipped with an automatic reset device which will reset the alarm system within 30 minutes of an alarm. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-6. - Application for permit by alarm user. 
Applications for permits to install, maintain or operate an alarm system shall be filed with the Police Chief on forms supplied by the Police Chief, and accompanied with an application fee of $25.00, a first year permit fee of $25.00, and a signed statement of understanding concerning the responsibilities and duties of the alarm user. An annual alarm user permit fee of $25.00 shall be due and payable to the Village of Glen Ellyn on September 1 each year. Thereafter, if the alarm user permit fee is not paid for a renewal on or prior to September 1 of each year, the applicant shall be charged double the applicable user permit fee. First time user permits purchased during the course of a permit year shall not be subject to any late fees. Whenever, after March 1 of any year, application is made for the issuance of an alarm user permit, the applicant shall only be required to pay one-half of the applicable user permit fee. 
The annual alarm user permit fee shall be waived for any unit of local government or school district that makes application for an alarm user permit. 
(Ord. 5765, 6-8-2009) 
6-6-7. - Permit form. 
The application for alarm permit shall include the following: 
(A)  Names, addresses, telephone numbers, emergency telephone numbers and type of business organization (individual, partnership, corporation) of the alarm user; 
(B)  If the alarm user is a partnership, then names, addresses, telephone numbers of the partners; 
(C)  If the alarm user is a corporation, then names, addresses, and telephone numbers of the principal officers and the state where incorporated; 
(D)  The names, addresses and telephone numbers of key holders to the premises and alarm system who can respond to the alarm location as soon as possible, but not to exceed 45 minutes; and 
(E)  The name and address of the alarm installer. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-8. - Permit nontransferable. 
Such permit shall not be transferable to any other person and shall be valid only for the particular premises identified in the permit. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-9. - Permit term. 
A permit issued pursuant to this chapter shall be valid until any one of the following events occurs: 
(A)  The person to whom the permit is issued no longer has immediate control of the premises for which the permit is issued; 
(B)  The person to whom the permit is issued no longer has immediate control of the business for which the permit was issued; 
(C)  The permit is voluntarily relinquished or surrendered to the Police Chief; or 
(D)  The permit is revoked in the manner provided for herein. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-10. - Permit not warranty. 
The issuance of a permit shall in no way constitute a warranty of the alarm system involved and issuance of said permit shall be specifically subject to the Village's disclaimer of liability as detailed in section 6-6-16 of this chapter and further detailed in 745 Illinois Compiled Statutes 10/2-206 of the local governmental and governmental employees tort immunity act. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-11. - False alarms. 
Each permit holder shall be responsible for any false alarm transmitted by the alarm for which the permit is issued and shall have someone present at the alarm location as soon as possible following notification by the Police Department or fire company, but not more than 45 minutes after such notification. The Police Chief shall maintain a record of all false alarms so transmitted and pursuant to the required notice and opportunity to be heard may revoke or suspend the permit for the operation of the alarm system involved in the transmission of four false alarms or more in any calendar year or may make reasonable charges therefor. 
(Ord. 5765, 6-8-2009) 
6-6-12. - Service charges for false alarms; exceptions. 
The Chief of Police shall not charge an alarm user permit holder for the first three false alarms during any calendar year. A false alarm fee of $50.00 for each false alarm in excess of three but less than nine in any calendar year, transmitted by an alarm system shall be charged to the holder of the alarm user permit. A false alarm fee of $100.00 for each false alarm in excess of eight but less than 11 in any calendar year, transmitted by an alarm system shall be charged to the holder of the alarm user permit. A false alarm fee of $200.00 for each false alarm in excess of ten per calendar year shall be charged to the holder of the alarm user permit. Such false alarm fees shall be payable to the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
No charge shall be imposed for false alarms that occur within 60 days after the initial installation of, or within 30 days after major alterations or additions to an alarm system. False alarms during the aforementioned time periods shall not count towards the total number of false alarms during any calendar year. 
(Ord. 5765, 6-8-2009) 
6-6-13. - Contested service charge. 
Each permit holder challenging a service charge for a false alarm shall be entitled to an administrative hearing in accordance with the provisions of title 1, chapter 11 of this Code. At an administrative hearing, the alarm user may offer evidence that an alarm activation, for which he is charged, falls within one of the permissible exceptions as described in section 6-6-12 of this chapter. Failure to request an administrative hearing within ten days of receipt of the statement of the false alarm charge shall constitute an admission that the service charge is justified and due to the Village. 
(Ord. 5765, 6-8-2009) 
6-6-14. - Revocation of permit. 
The Police Chief or his designated agent may revoke any permit issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter if he determines that the alarm system under said permit has been installed, maintained, or operated in violation of the provisions of this chapter or any term or condition of said permit. Such violations shall include, but not be limited to: 
(A)  Any information on the alarm user's permit application has been found to be false or misleading; or 
(B)  The Police or Fire Department receives more than four false alarms in any one calendar year; or 
(C)  If the permit holder fails to pay any service fee charged to the permit holder within 30 days of issuance of service fee charges; or 
(D)  If any alarm activation does not automatically reset in a 30-minute period after activation. 
The permit holder shall be given written notice of the pending revocation and provided an opportunity to effect compliance, or acceptable assurances or explanation, within a period of ten days following the issuance of the notice. If such compliance, assurance or explanation is not accomplished or accepted, the permit revocation, unless timely challenged, shall become effective on the date contained in the written notice. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-15. - Contested revocation. 
Each permit holder challenging the revocation of an alarm user's permit shall be entitled to an administrative hearing in accordance with the provisions of title 1, chapter 11 of this Code. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-16. - Liability of the Village limited. 
In the event that the Village deems it necessary to revoke or suspend the alarm user's permit, the Village shall incur no liability by such action, whether or not the alarm system is functioning. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
6-6-17. - Penalties for violation. 
It is a violation of this chapter for any person to: 
(A)  Operate an alarm system of the type prohibited by this chapter; 
(B)  Operate an alarm system designed to summon the Police/Fire Departments without having a valid alarm user's permit as required by this chapter; or 
(C)  Fail to pay any service charge assessed under this chapter. 
Each such violation constitutes an offense punishable by a fine from $25.00 to $500.00. Each day that such violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2827, 10-25-1982) 
Chapter 7 - AUXILIARY POLICE UNIT 

6-7-1. - Authorization of auxiliary Policemen. 
The Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, is hereby authorized to designate 35 auxiliary Policemen as employees of the Village. Prior to such designation, each proposed auxiliary Policeman shall be fingerprinted, and his fingerprints shall be checked with the Federal Bureau of Investigation, Washington, D.C., for a possible criminal record; and no person shall be designated as an auxiliary Policeman if he has been convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude. 
The services of an auxiliary Policeman may be terminated by the Village President, with the advice and consent of the Board of Trustees, at any time. 
(Ord. 2393, 9-11-1978) 
6-7-2. - Qualifications of member. 
An auxiliary Policeman shall not be a member of the regular Police Department of the Village, but shall be bound by its rules and regulations. 
Identification symbols worn by an auxiliary Policeman shall be selected by the Police Chief and must be different and distinct from those used by the regular Police of the Village. 
(Ord. 2393, 9-11-1978) 
6-7-3. - Powers and duties. 
An auxiliary Policeman, when called for duty, shall be subject to the direction and control of the Police Chief of the Village, and when assigned to duty, shall have the following powers and duties: 
(A)  Direct traffic and assist in traffic control; 
(B)  Aid in controlling natural or manmade disasters; 
(C)  Assist in parade control and keeping the peace at large gatherings in and about the community; 
(D)  Act in all cases of riot, civil disorder and emergencies; 
(E)  Perform normal and regular Police duties on occasions when it is impracticable for members of the regular Police Department to perform such duties; 
(F)  Arrest, or cause to be arrested, with or without process, all persons who break the peace or violate a municipal ordinance or criminal law of the state; 
(G)  Commit arrested persons for examination; 
(H)  If necessary, detain arrested persons in custody overnight or Sunday in a safe place or until they can be brought before the proper magistrate; 
(I)  Serve and execute warrants for violating municipal ordinances or state criminal laws within the limits of the Village and, for this purpose, have all the common law and statutory powers of sheriffs; and 
(J)  Exercise such other powers as conservators of the peace as the corporate authorities may prescribe. 
(Ord. 2393, 9-11-1978) 
6-7-4. - Firearms, permission to carry. 
An auxiliary Policeman shall not carry firearms except with the special permission of, and when issued by, the Police Chief, and then only while in uniform and engaged in performing his assigned duties. 
(Ord. 2393, 9-11-1978) 
6-7-5. - Weapons training course required. 
Prior to entering upon any duties, an auxiliary Policeman shall receive a course of training in the use of weapons and other Police procedures from the Police Chief of the Village. Such course of training shall be of not less than ten hours' duration; and upon completion of the training course, the Police Chief shall file a certificate with the Village Clerk attesting to the auxiliary Policeman's completion of the training course. 
(Ord. 2393, 9-11-1978) 
6-7-6. - Compensation. 
An auxiliary Policeman shall receive no compensation for services performed. 
(Ord. 2393, 9-11-1978) 
Chapter 8 - ACCESS AND REVIEW OF CRIMINAL HISTORY 

6-8-1. - Record information; fee. 
The rules and regulations promulgated pursuant to law by the law enforcement assistance administration of the United States Department of Justice and the Illinois Department of Law Enforcement shall govern the rights of individuals to access and review of their records. The fee charged for such review shall be $10.00, nonrefundable, and shall be payable at the time of submission of an application for access and review of said records. 
(Ord. 2172, 2-18-1977) 
6-8-2. - Access and review of records. 
Access and review of said records shall be from 8:00 a.m. to 4:00 p.m., Monday through Friday, except for Village holidays. 
(Ord. 2172, 2-18-1977) 
6-8-3. - Time limit for access, review of records. 
The right to access and review of said records is limited to 60 days from the date of making said records. 
(Ord. 2172, 2-18-1977) 
6-8-4. - Request sent to bureau. 
The Police Department shall send the request to the Illinois State Bureau of Investigation within seven days of said request. 
(Ord. 2172, 2-18-1977) 
6-8-5. - Process time by bureau. 
The Illinois State Bureau of Investigation shall be requested to process the form within 30 days. 
(Ord. 2172, 2-18-1977) 
TITLE 7 - HEALTH AND SANITATION 
Chapter 1 - HEALTH DEPARTMENT 
(Repealed by Ordinance 3829, April 22, 1991) 
Chapter 2 - NUISANCES 

7-2-1. - Nuisances. 
In all cases where no provision is hereby made defining what are nuisances and how the same may be removed, abated or prevented, in addition to what may be declared a nuisance herein, those offenses which are known to the common law and the statutes of Illinois as nuisances may, in case the same exist within the Village limits, or within one mile thereof, be treated as nuisances and proceeded against as provided in this Code, or in accordance with any other provision of law. 
(1965 Code § 11.01) 
7-2-2. - Abatement. 
It shall be the duty of the Building and Zoning Official to serve notice in writing upon the owner, occupant, agent or person in possession or control of any lot, building or premises, in or upon which any nuisance may be found, requiring him to abate the same in such manner and within the time prescribed by the Building and Zoning Official; provided, however, that if the owner, occupant, agent or person in possession or control of any premises in or upon which any nuisance is found is unknown or cannot be found, the Building and Zoning Official shall proceed to abate such nuisance without notice; and, in addition to any penalty or fine, the expense of such abatement shall be collected from the person who is determined to have created, continued or suffered such nuisance to exist. The Glen Ellyn Police Department and the street division of the Department of Public Works are also authorized to enforce the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 2482, 8-27-1979) 
7-2-3. - Definitions. 
It shall be a nuisance: 
(A)  To obstruct or encroach upon any street, parkway, alley or sidewalk in the Village, except for purposes of repairing the same; 
(B)  To use or occupy any part of a street, parkway, alley or sidewalk in the Village for the purpose of carrying on, soliciting or promoting any trade, business or other enterprise in such manner as to impede or make it dangerous to persons traveling thereon; 
(C)  To conduct, or permit any business to be conducted, upon any lot or parcel of land within the Village, in violation of any provision of this Code; 
(D)  To create or permit to remain any condition which is, or may become, a menace to the health of individuals or the public; 
(E)  To keep, or permit to be kept, upon any premises within the Village any chicken coop, chicken house, stable, kennel, pen or other structure for the retention, care and shelter of any fowl or animals in an unclean, unsanitary or filthy condition, so as to produce offensive and noisome odors, to the annoyance and discomfort of others; 
(F)  To cause or suffer the carcass of any dead animal, any animal or vegetable matter, slops, swill, suds, garbage, filth, stable drippings, offal or noisome substances of any kind to be collected, deposited or remain in any place in the Village to the injury or prejudice of others; 
(G)  To keep, or permit to be kept, upon any premises within the Village a dog, other animal or fowl which, by loud, frequent or continuous noise, is offensive and annoying to others; 
(H)  To erect or use any building or other place for the exercise of a trade, employment, manufacture or other purpose which, by occasioning noxious exhalations, offensive smells or otherwise, is dangerous to the health of the public; 
(I)  To cause or permit any premises within the Village to become or remain littered with refuse, rubbish, junk, waste, manure, straw, weeds, brush, machinery or parts thereof, or other like matter or things which may, or do, become offensive or dangerous to the health of others; 
(J)  To store, or permit to be stored, on any premises lumber, bricks, other building material, crates, cases or boxes, if said articles are piled to a height greater than the distance from such pile to the public way, but in no event to a height exceeding eight feet, unless said yard or lot is entirely surrounded by a fence eight feet in height; 
(K)  To abandon or discard, in any place accessible to children, any refrigerator, icebox or ice chest of a capacity of one and one-half cubic feet or more, having an attached lid or door which may be opened or fastened shut by means of an attached latch; 
(L)  To abandon or discard, in any place accessible to children, any unperforated polyethylene bags or coverings; 
(M)  To keep or use, or permit to be kept or used, any premises within the Village in such condition that rats, flies, noxious vermin or insects infest the same; 
(N)  To create or permit to remain upon any premises within the Village any offensive condition which is dangerous to the health or offensive to others; 
(O)  To corrupt or render unwholesome or impure the water of any spring, river, stream, pond or lake, to the injury or prejudice of others; 
(P)  To obstruct any watercourse, ravine or gutter so as to cause water to stagnate therein, or to permit foul or stagnant water to stand upon any premises, to the injury or prejudice of others; 
(Q)  To allow or permit any dense smoke to come or be emitted from the smokestack of any locomotive, steamroller, steam derrick, steam pile driver, tar kettle or other similar machine or contrivance, from the smokestack or chimney of any building, or from an open fire within the Village; 
(R)  To spread, or to cause any agent or employee to spread, any poison for the purpose of killing rats, mice, rodents, insects or other vermin in any public way or public place in the Village, in any yard, court, passageway or open place on private premises on the outside of any building or structure, or in any place in the Village, in any yard, court, passageway or open place on private premises on the outside of any building or structure, or in any place within a building or structure which is open to the general public where pet dogs, cats or other domestic animals or fowl have access, without placing the same in a receptacle of such kind or character that it can be reached only by the kind of vermin which the poison is intended to kill, or without placing a wire or other guard about the same in such a way that no child or domestic animal, fowl or other harmless creature can reach such poison; 
(S)  To spit upon any public sidewalk, the floor of any public conveyance or the floor of any theater, hall, assembly room or public building; 
(T)  To drop, throw, discard or place any cartons, containers, wrappers, bags, facial tissue, paper napkins or any other wastepaper, waste matter, cans or bottles upon any public way, the floor of any public conveyance or building, the surface of any lot or parcel of ground, the roof of any building, or in any light or air shaft, court or areaway; 
(U)  To cast, drop or throw any object, missile or other substance or article in, from or into any public place, thereby endangering the safety or property of others; 
(V)  To drop or deposit anywhere within the Village, except at such place as may be authorized by a written permit of the Board of Trustees, any garbage, ashes, miscellaneous waste, manure or other substance that may contain diseased germs, be scattered by the wind, decompose, or become filthy, noxious or unhealthful; 
(W)  To rent, use or permit the use of a building or premises for any business, pleasure or recreation which, by its boisterous nature, disturbs or destroys the peace of a neighborhood or is dangerous or detrimental to health; 
(X)  To fail to complete the construction or remodeling of any building within the term for which a building permit is issued, or any extension thereof, if the condition has a depreciating effect on property values in the neighborhood and to the injury and prejudice of others; or 
(Y)  To abandon or leave unattended any grocery cart or shopping cart upon any public street, sidewalk or public way, or upon the private property of any person adjoining or abutting any public way or sidewalk, other than premises where said cart was originally obtained. 
(Z)  To pay or attempt to pay any municipal fine or permit fee or make payment for any other goods or services with check, money order, currency or coin which has been soiled, contaminated, tainted or polluted with any human or animal bodily secretions, such as, but not limited to, blood, urine, semen, feces, mucus, spit or other human or animal waste or which has been soiled, contaminated, tainted or polluted with any foodstuff, adhesive, gluey, gooey, gummy or other material which causes the check, money order, currency or coin to be stuck together or which provides an offensive and/or annoying odor. 
(1965 Code § 11.03; Ord. 3996, 2-22-1993) 
7-2-4. - Weeds. 
(Repealed by Ordinance 3133, July 22, 1985) 
7-2-5. - Diseased trees. 
(Repealed by Ordinance 4670, December 14, 1998) 
7-2-6. - Smoking in stores. 
(Repealed by Ordinance 5751, April 27, 2009) 
7-2-7. - Removal of graffiti. 
(A)  The Village of Glen Ellyn declares "graffiti", as defined in subsection (D) of this section, as a nuisance and as a nuisance, subject to abatement as provided herein. 
(B)  Upon notification by the Village, the owner of property upon which graffiti has been illegally placed shall remove the graffiti within ten working days from the date of the notice. Each day that the graffiti is allowed to remain after the date by which it should have been removed will constitute an additional violation. An extension of the time in which graffiti must be removed may be granted by the Village upon application of the property owner to the Police Department and a showing of cause. Cause shall include, but not be limited to: weather, temperature, availability of chemicals, or physical limitations. 
(C)  The Village of Glen Ellyn, upon notification of graffiti placed upon Village property, shall remove the graffiti within ten working days from the date of notification. 
(D)  "Graffiti" shall be defined as the painting, inscription, drawing or otherwise placement upon the surface of any building or structural surface, such as a wall, fence or tree, that is publicly or privately owned of any sign, symbol, marking, drawing, name, initial, word, diagram, sketch, picture, or letter, which violates any Village ordinance or was not placed there at the owner's request. The above list is not all inclusive, but is merely illustrative of items known as graffiti. It shall be an affirmative defense to the alleged violation of the foregoing provisions if such activity was undertaken with the prior written consent of the owner of the property, demonstrating that the owner was aware of the content and methods of inscription to be placed on the structure or wall; however, no owner of property shall place or give permission to place on any property, real or personal which is in public view any sign, symbol, marking, drawing, name, initial, work, diagram, sketch, picture or letter, which violates the provisions of any Village ordinance or which incites violence by reference to gang or criminal activity, depicts or expresses obscenity by referring to sexual activity or contains defamatory material about a public or private person. 
(E)  Upon a finding of guilty for a violation of this section, there shall be imposed a fine of not less than $100.00 nor more than $500.00. 
(Ord. 5616, 9-24-2007) 
Chapter 3 - FOOD VENDING MACHINES 

7-3-1. - Food vending machines. 
(A)  Definitions: 
AUTOMATIC FOOD VENDING MACHINE: Any mechanical container or device used for the sale of any article of food, the operation of which is governed or controlled by the deposit of a coin or token. 
FOOD: Any cooked or uncooked article of food, drink, condiment or confection used for, or intended to be used for, human consumption. 
INSPECTING OFFICER: Any person or agency designated by the President and Board of Trustees to make inspections under this chapter. 
(B)  License required: It shall be unlawful for any person to engage in the business of installing, keeping or maintaining an automatic food vending machine without first having obtained a license so to do. 
No person shall install, keep, maintain or use, or permit the installation, keeping, maintenance or use upon his premises, of any automatic food vending machine owned or operated by another who has not obtained a license therefor. 
Nothing herein contained shall require a duly licensed food purveyor or food dispenser to procure a license for operating an automatic food vending machine owned by him and operated upon his premises. 
(C)  Application: Application for such license shall be made in conformity with the general requirements of this Code relating to application for licenses. 
In addition, the applicant shall set forth the types of automatic food vending machines intended to be operated, and such information as may be required by the inspecting officer in order to inform him as to the type or types of machines and the kind or kinds of food to be dispensed therefrom. 
Before any license shall issue, the type of vending machine intended to be operated shall be approved by the inspecting officer, who also shall cause an inspection to be made of the premises of the applicant to determine the character and fitness of the premises from the standpoint of ensuring protection of food from improper handling, dust, dirt, flies, vermin or other contamination. 
(D)  License fee: The annual fee shall be according to the following schedule: Each individually mounted or freestanding machine, the operation of which requires a coin not in excess of $0.10 the fees shall be $15.00 per machine. 
If more than one machine but not more than six machines are permanently installed on a common stand, whose overall size is not more than three feet wide nor more than five feet high, and each machine requires a coin not in excess of $0.10, then the fee shall be a minimum of $15.00 for the first machine on a common stand, plus for each machine in excess of one, the fee shall be $2.50 per machine. 
Each machine, the operation of which requires coins in excess of $0.10, whether freestanding or contained on a common stand, the fee shall be $25.00 per machine. 
(E)  Prohibited location: No automatic food vending machine shall be installed or kept for use in any toilet or washroom. 
(F)  Special regulations: All articles of food purveyed by means of an automatic food vending machine shall be clean, wholesome, free from taint, decay or infection, and shall contain no poisonous, deleterious or injurious ingredients, in kind and quantity, so as to render such articles injurious or detrimental to health. 
(M.C. 1965, Sec. 16.11; Ord. 2974, 3-26-1984; Ord. 3390, 11-9-1987) 
7-3-2. - Enforcement interpretation. 
This chapter shall be enforced by the Village President and Board of Trustees, with the aid of such persons as they may designate, in accordance with the interpretations thereof contained in the latest edition of the United States public health service code regulating eating and drinking establishments. Three copies of said Code shall be kept available for public use, inspection and examination at the office of the Village Clerk. 
(M.C. 1965, Sec. 16.12) 
Chapter 4 - MILK 
(Repealed by Ordinance 3390, November 19, 1987) 
Chapter 5 - ROOMING HOUSES 

7-5-1. - Definition. 
Whenever used in this chapter, the term "rooming house" shall mean and include every building furnishing lodging rooms, with or without meals, for persons who are not members of the owner's or keeper's family, for compensation, exclusive of hotels or motels. 
(Ord. 6163, 9-9-2013) 
7-5-2. - Compliance with zoning regulations. 
Any rooming house accommodating three or more persons who are not members of the owner's or keeper's family shall conform to the requirements of the zoning ordinance of the Village, as adopted in section 10-1-2 of this Code, in addition to the requirements of this chapter. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-3. - License required. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to conduct, keep, manage or operate a rooming house without first obtaining a license therefor. The license herein provided for shall be posted at all times in a conspicuous place in the building. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-4. - License fee. 
The license fee required under this chapter shall be the sum of $0.50 per year for each person for whom lodging space is to be provided for compensation, the minimum license fee being $1.00. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-5. - Application for license. 
Written application for a rooming house license shall be made annually to the Village Clerk upon forms furnished by him, which application shall give the following information: 
(A)  Name and address of applicant, 
(B)  Address of rooming house, 
(C)  Person in whose name the license shall issue, 
(D)  Name and address of the owner of the building, 
(E)  Number of rooms in the building, 
(F)  Number of rooms to be rented, and 
(G)  Number of persons to be accommodated in each rented room. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-6. - Approval of application. 
The Village Clerk shall submit all applications to the Building and Zoning Official, who shall be authorized by the application and the applicant to make an inspection of the premises, either personally or by his deputy; no license shall issue until the application has been approved by the Building and Zoning Official. 
The Building and Zoning Official shall determine whether all requirements of the Building, Electrical, Fire and Plumbing Codes and the zoning ordinance have been complied with, and that the premises are safe and suitable for habitation and are provided with adequate heat, light and ventilation facilities. 
If such inspection discloses that the premises do not comply with the provisions of this Code, the applicant may correct the deficiencies within ten days. 
Any applicant who is dissatisfied with the decision of the Building and Zoning Official may appeal, in writing, to the Village President and Board of Trustees. The President and Board shall review the decision appealed from at their next regular meeting, and either affirm of reverse the decision. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-7. - Duration of license; limitations. 
All licenses granted hereunder shall be issued by the Village President, shall expire on July 31 in each year, and shall be nontransferable. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-8. - Inspection. 
In addition to the inspection provided for in section 7-5-6 of this chapter, at least one other inspection shall be made during the license year. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-9. - Cellar, basement occupancy. 
No license shall issue to any person for rooming house occupancy of a "cellar", as defined in the zoning ordinance of the Village; no license shall issue for basement, third floor or attic rooms in any building without the express written approval of the Village Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-10. - Bathroom and toilet facilities. 
Every rooming house shall provide toilet, lavatory and bathing facilities; there shall be at least one toilet stool for every six occupants, or fraction thereof. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-11. - Airspace. 
No room in any rooming house shall be occupied as a sleeping room unless it provides at least 480 cubic feet of airspace and not less than 60 square feet of floor space per person for each person occupying such room. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-12. - Floor area. 
No rooming house shall be operated with less than the following floor area: 
(A)  Where the number of persons lawfully living in the building does not exceed 20, there shall be 200 square feet of floor area for each person living therein; 
(B)  Where the number of persons lawfully living in the building exceeds 20, but does not exceed 30, there shall be 4,000 square feet of floor area, plus an additional 150 square feet for each person in excess of 20; and 
(C)  Where the number of persons lawfully living in the building exceeds 30, but does not exceed 40, there shall be 5,500 square feet of floor area, plus an additional 100 square feet for each person in excess of 30. 
For the purpose of determining the floor area requirements of this section, no child under five years of age shall be included in the number of persons lawfully living in the building. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-13. - Light housekeeping. 
No person who shall keep, conduct, operate or maintain a rooming house shall permit the keeping or preparation of food in any living or sleeping rooms. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-14. - Light and air. 
Window space in each rented room must equal, or exceed, ten percent of the floor area, and at least one window must face directly to the outdoors. All windows shall be provided with adequate screening to protect against insects. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-15. - Accessory building. 
No accessory building, as defined in the zoning ordinance, shall be used for rooming house purposes. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-16. - Private clubs, fraternities. 
All the provisions of this chapter shall apply to private clubs, fraternities and sororities. For the purpose of this chapter, a "private club, fraternity or sorority" is defined to mean a club of individuals banded together under a constitution recognized by a school, chartered by the State of Illinois as a corporation, or affiliated with a nationally recognized organization which owns its own real estate or is leasing real estate from the owner for a period of not less than one year. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-17. - Off street parking spaces. 
Rooming houses accommodating more than three persons, in addition to the members of the family of the owner or keeper, shall provide parking spaces as required by the zoning ordinance. Rooming houses accommodating less than three such roomers shall provide at least two off street parking spaces. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
7-5-18. - Interpretation. 
The provisions of this chapter shall be interpreted to be the minimum requirements adopted for the protection of the public health, safety, comfort and general welfare. 
Where this chapter imposes a greater restriction upon the use of buildings for rooming house purposes than are imposed or required by the provisions of any other code regulations, the provisions of this chapter shall control. 
(Ord. 1617, 10-28-1968) 
Chapter 6 - SOLID WASTE COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL 

7-6-1. - Administration. 
All matters relating to or affecting the accumulation, collection, removal or disposal of wastes, and residential solid waste, unless specifically otherwise assigned elsewhere herein, shall be subject to and under the supervision of the Village Administrator unless specifically otherwise assigned by the Village Administrator. 
All reusable containers shall be subject to inspection and approval or condemnation by the Village Administrator. 
For the purposes of fulfilling the requirements of this chapter, the Village Administrator is hereby authorized and directed to cause all residential solid waste to be collected regularly and systematically at least once each seven days from all residences in the Village, except where weather may dictate otherwise. 
(Ord. 4399, 7-22-1996) 
7-6-2. - Definitions. 
For purposes of this chapter, definitions of certain terms shall be as listed below. Other terms shall be as defined within applicable subsections. 
BUNDLE OF E-WASTE: A bundle of E-Waste shall not exceed the size of a brown paper grocery bag of approximately 12 x 7 x 17 inches. 
COMPOST: Includes those items defined in "Yard Waste", and specifically, grass clippings, garden vegetation, leaves and brush, food scraps, bread, vegetables, table scraps, dairy, coffee grounds, and pasta. 
CURBSIDE: Adjacent to the street pavement, alley pavement, and gutter and within five feet thereof. 
DISPOSAL UNIT: 
(A)  For purposes of refuse collection, a "disposal unit" shall mean one watertight metal or plastic reusable waste container with handles, no larger than 33 gallons in capacity or 50 pounds in weight when filled; one plastic or paper bag, box, carton, or other disposable container not to exceed thirty 33 gallons in capacity and 50 pounds in weight when filled, securely tied or closed in such a fashion so as to prevent the littering, leaking, or scattering of refuse or debris; one securely tied bundle of refuse or debris which is not placed in a container and that does not exceed two feet in diameter, four feet in length, and 50 pounds in weight; or one single miscellaneous or odd shaped item of refuse or debris that does not exceed 50 pounds in weight. A "large household item", as defined in this section, is to be considered a disposal unit. 
(B)  For purposes of yard waste collection, a "disposal unit" shall mean one biodegradable two-ply, 50-pound wet strength Kraft paper bag designed for yard waste collection not to exceed 33 gallons in capacity and 50 pounds in weight when filled; one watertight metal or plastic reusable waste container with handles, no larger than 33 gallons in capacity or 50 pounds in weight when filled; or one securely tied bundle of brush or branches using biodegradable cord, string, rope, or twine that does not exceed 50 pounds in weight, two feet in diameter, and four feet in length. 
E-WASTE: E-Waste shall mean any item defined as a "covered electronic devise" by 415 ILCS 150, the Electronic Products Recycling and Refuse Act. E-waste shall include, but not be limited to, computers, computer monitors, televisions, printers, keyboards, fax machines, videocassette recorders, portable digital music players, digital video disc players, video game consoles, computer mice, scanners, digital converter boxes, cable receivers, satellite receivers, digital video disc recorders, or small-scale servers. 
HOUSEHOLD CONSTRUCTION AND DEMOLITION DEBRIS OR DEBRIS: Waste materials from interior and exterior household construction, remodeling, and repair projects, including, but not limited to, drywall, plywood, paneling, lumber, and other building materials; windows and doors; cabinets; carpeting; disassembled bathroom and kitchen fixtures; and small amounts of sod, earth, clay, sand, concrete, rocks, and similar materials. Such debris shall conform to the following: loose small items shall be placed in suitable containers not exceeding 50 pounds in weight when filled or in bundles not exceeding two feet in diameter, four feet in length, and 50 pounds in weight. Materials not conforming shall not be considered as household construction and demolition debris and shall be subject to collection requirements as specified in subsection 7-6-3(J) and section 7-6-8 of this chapter. 
LARGE HOUSEHOLD ITEM (OR BULK ITEM): Any discarded and unwanted large household appliance and furnishings, including, but not limited to, refrigerators, freezers, stoves, trash compactors, washers, dryers, dishwashers, furnaces, hot water heaters, air conditioners, furnaces, humidifiers, dehumidifiers, microwaves, water softeners, pianos, organs, tables, chairs, mattresses, box springs, bookcases, sofas, and similar furniture. All white goods, including those containing CFCs (chlorofluorocarbons), switches containing mercury, and PCBs (polychlorinated biphenyls) shall fit within this definition. 
NONRESIDENTIAL SERVICE: Collection and disposal service provided to nonresidential, commercial properties and to any single-family or multi-family residential property located within a complex in which refuse generated from the residents is placed in a common waste container. 
REAR DOOR COLLECTION: Collection of disposal units from any location on a property which is not included in the definition of "curbside". 
RECYCLABLES OR RECYCLABLE MATERIAL(S): At a minimum, brown paper bags, corrugated boxes, frozen food packages, magazines and catalogs, mixed paper, newspaper, paperBoard, telephone books, wet strength carrier stock, aerosol cans, aluminum cans, aluminum foil, aseptic packaging and gable top containers, formed steel containers, glass bottles and jars, PET (#1) plastic containers, HDPE (#2) plastic containers, PVC (#3) plastic containers (generally health and beauty products), LDPE (#4) plastic containers (generally food products), PP (#5) plastic containers (generally food products), plastic 6- and 12-pack rings, PS polystyrene (#6), steel cans, steel paint cans and lids, and motor oil (in disposable containers), in addition to any other items which become acceptable at material processing facilities. 
REFUSE: All discarded and unwanted perishable and nonperishable household and kitchen waste, including, but not limited to, food, food residues, and materials necessarily used for packaging, storing, preparing, and consuming same, usually defined as "garbage", and all combustible and noncombustible waste materials resulting from the usual routine of domestic housekeeping, including, but not limited to, aluminum and steel cans; glass, plastic, crockery, and other containers; metal; paper of all types, including newspapers, books, magazines, and catalogs; boxes and cartons; cold ashes; furniture, furnishings, and fixtures; household appliances of all kinds; tires, textiles, and leather; dead animals and animal waste; toys and recreational equipment; and similar items. For the purposes of this chapter, the terms "garbage", "refuse", "rubbish", and "waste" shall be synonymous unless otherwise more specifically defined (for example, "yard waste"). 
RESIDENTIAL SERVICE: Collection and disposal service provided to single-family detached or attached (townhouse or duplex) residences that are not located within a complex in which refuse generated from the residents is placed in a common waste container (i.e., a dumpster or roll off). 
SCHOCK'S SQUARE CONSOLIDATED REFUSE PROGRAM: The Schock's Square Consolidated Refuse Program is established pursuant to the provisions contained and referenced in Resolution No. 18-08. 
STOP (OR HOUSEHOLD): Any single-family detached or attached (townhouse or duplex) residence that is not located within a complex in which refuse generated from the residents is placed in a common waste container. The term "stop" shall be synonymous with the term "household". In this instance, single households will be counted for the purpose of defining the extent of the collection services to be provided and of determining the amount of refuse, recyclables, and yard waste to be collected. 
YARD WASTE (ALSO KNOWN AS LANDSCAPE WASTE): Grass clippings, leaves, branches and brush, other yard and garden trimmings, vines, garden plants, flowers, weeds, tree droppings (for example, pine cones and crab apples), and other similar organic waste materials accumulated as the result of the cultivation and maintenance of lawns, shrubbery, vines, trees, and gardens. Sod, dirt, Christmas trees, and greenery from wreaths and garlands shall not be considered yard waste and shall be disposed of as refuse unless the composting facility will accept it. 
(Ord. 4399, 7-22-1996; Ord. 6513, 7-17-2017; Ord. 6592, 4-9-2018) 
7-6-3. - Residential solid waste collection and disposal service. 
(A)  Residential service required: Every person in possession of any residence in the Village shall, except as otherwise provided herein, be required to have accumulations of residential solid waste collected and disposed of regularly and systematically at least once each seven-day period by the contractor employed by the Village according to the type of service desired and the attendant fee as specified in subsection 7-6-4(A) of this chapter. The occupancy of any premises for residential purposes shall be prima facie evidence that residential solid waste is being produced and accumulated on such premises. The Village shall have the authority to inspect the premises and cause to be removed therefrom any and all residential solid waste found, for which collection and removal service the required fee, as established by this chapter, shall have been or shall be paid by the person in whose name the Village carries the water or sewer account, or both, for the subject premises. 
(B)  Authorization: At any residence, all residential solid waste shall be collected and disposed of by the contractor duly authorized by the Village and, except as otherwise may be provided for herein, shall not be collected or disposed of in any other manner. 
(C)  Exclusive contract: All residential solid waste shall be collected from all households within the Village by the contractor under exclusive contract with the Village. No persons shall use the services of any other scavenger. 
(D)  Types of service: 
1.  Refuse: All households located within the Village's corporate boundaries shall be provided with weekly curbside or rear door collection of refuse, household construction and demolition debris, and large household items. Residents will be allowed to place unlimited amounts of disposal units of refuse at the curb for collection and disposal. There shall be no sticker required for the first approved disposal unit of refuse set out for collection each week. However, the second and any subsequent disposal unit must be properly stickered, or refuse must be placed in approved prepaid bags that do not require stickers. 
2.  Recycling: All households located within the Village's corporate boundaries shall be provided with weekly curbside or rear door collection of an unlimited quantity of acceptable recyclable materials. Disposal units containing recyclable materials will not require stickers. 
3.  Yard waste: All households located within the Village's corporate boundaries shall be provided with weekly curbside collection only of yard waste. Yard waste collection shall begin each year on the first Monday in April and end on the first Monday in December. Yard and leaf waste set out for collection will be done so on a pay per disposal unit basis. Notwithstanding programs implemented by the Village to provide alternate means of collecting all or part of the yard and leaf waste stream, residents will be allowed to place unlimited amounts of disposal units of yard and leaf waste at the curb for collection as long as a sticker is attached to each disposal unit. 
4.  Composting: All households located within the Village's corporate boundaries shall be provided with the option of subscribing to curbside collection of compost. Collection shall be weekly during the months of April to November and biweekly December to March. Residents shall be allowed to place unlimited amounts of disposal units of compost at the curb for collection and disposal. There shall be no sticker required for the first approved disposal unit of compost set out for collection each week. However, the second and any subsequent disposal unit must be properly stickered. 
5.  E-Waste: All households located within the Village's corporate boundaries shall be provided with weekly curbside collection of E-Waste. Households must tag each E-Waste item or bundle of E-Waste items with the number of refuse stickers required. There shall be no maximum or minimum amount of E-Waste that a household can set out for collection, provided that each item is properly stickered. 
(E)  Use of disposal units: All households receiving the aforementioned services shall be required to place all materials for collection and disposal into proper disposal units. 
(F)  Special haul service for the Village : The contractor, as provided for in subsection (C) of this section, will furnish refuse trucks and drivers for special ("natural disaster") cleanup activities on the following basis: 
8/1/2018 through 7/31/2019 $180.25/hr./2 men/1 truck  
(G)  (Repealed by Ordinance 4940, April 23, 2001) 
(H)  Counterfeit stickers: It shall be a violation of the provisions of this chapter for any person to make, sell, give away or use a refuse, yard waste, or leaf sticker, tag or prepaid bag which shall counterfeit the actual sticker, tag, or prepaid bag sold by or on behalf of the Village or its contractor. 
(I)  Hours and standards of collection by contractors and scavengers: No collections shall commence before 7:00 a.m. nor continue after 7:00 p.m. in residential districts. All collections shall be made as quietly as possible. 
(J)  Debris from building contractor's operation: Solid waste accumulated from the operation of lot clearing and building contractor's construction debris caused by building, rebuilding or otherwise altering a building or structure shall be removed by the person or building contractor performing such work, except that the person or contractor may employ a scavenger licensed under the provisions of title 3, chapter 28 of this Code; provided such scavenger shall not remove residential waste generated by the occupants of any residential unit whether or not under repair or construction. Such scavenger need not be the contractor employed by the Village but shall be licensed by the Village. 
(K)  Hours for placement of containers: Residential solid waste shall be set out no earlier than 4:30 p.m. on the evening before collection is scheduled and no later than 7:00 a.m. on the day collection is scheduled. All containers and solid waste shall be removed from the specified location within 24 hours after the contractor has been present for the purpose of collection and disposal, and the contractor's refusal to collect such solid waste does not limit the requirements provided for herein. 
(Ord. 4399, 7-22-1996; Ord. 4785, 11-22-1999; Ord. 4940, 4-23-2001; Ord. 5357, 5-9-2005; Ord. 6039, 7-9-2012; Ord. 6513, 7-17-2017; Ord. 6617, 7-16-2018) 
7-6-4. - Residential solid waste collection fees. 
(A)  Residential collections : Effective on the August 1, 2018 Village Services Bill, the fees to be charged for residential solid waste collection and disposal services shall be as follows: 
      Monthly Base Rate 
Monthly refuse collection program: 
Curbside collection of one Village provided 35-gallon wheeled cart ..... $11.74

Large household items (non-electronics) ..... 2 Refuse Stickers 
TV and monitors up to 25" ..... 10 Refuse Stickers 
TV monitors greater than 25" ..... 16 Refuse Stickers 
Bundles of electronic waste ..... 6 Refuse Stickers 
Single small electronic waste item ..... 2 Refuse Stickers 
(B)  Billing: The monthly fee for refuse and recycling services shall be billed by the Village to, and paid by, the person in whose name the Village water and sewer account then appears. The Village shall be responsible for collecting any and all delinquent accounts. Monies received in payment for the combined water, sewer, Fire Department service fee and solid waste bill will be credited first to any outstanding balances, then to the solid waste account fee, then to the Fire Department service fee, with the balance credited to the water and sewer fee. The Village may refund or adjust on a monthly pro rata basis an amount equal to such service paid for but not received. 
(C)  Nonresidential collections: Solid waste collection and disposal service for nonresidential establishments and residences for which nonresidential service is required shall be performed by scavengers fully licensed to operate in the Village in accordance with title 3, chapter 28 of this Code at such schedules and rates as may be mutually agreed upon between the licensed scavengers and such nonresidential accounts. 
(D)  Senior citizen collection rates: A senior citizen collection rate, where the head of the family unit is age 65 or older, shall be available only after application for such rate has been filed with the Cashier's Office. A person claiming eligibility for a senior citizen rate shall file an application certifying that the head of the family unit residing at the address is age 65 or older. The Village may require reasonable verification of the age, address, and head of family unit status of the applicant. The senior citizen rate shall not be retroactively applied to cause a rebate or reduction of an amount previously billed at the regular rate. 
(Ord. 4399, 7-22-1996; Ord. 6204, 12-9-2013; Ord. 6414, 6-27-2016; Ord. 6513, 7-17-2017; Ord. 6617, 7-16-2018) 
7-6-5. - Nonresidential solid waste collection and disposal service. 
(A)  Service required: 
1.  It shall be the duty of every owner of property for which nonresidential service is appropriate to provide for the collection and removal of all solid waste of any quantity whatsoever generated by such property with such frequency as is necessary to avoid health hazards or unreasonable accumulations of waste materials. 
2.  It shall be the duty of every property owner who provides for the collection and removal of such nonresidential solid waste to effect proper placement of nonresidential solid waste containers. 
3.  It shall be the duty of every owner of residential property for which nonresidential service is appropriate to provide for the separate collection and removal of recyclable material from the residents of the property. For purposes of this subsection, recyclable material shall include the following: at a minimum, brown paper bags, magazines and catalogs, mixed paper, newspaper, paperBoard, aluminum cans, glass bottles and jars, PET (#1) plastic containers, HDPE (#2) plastic containers, and steel cans. 
(B)  Containers: 
1.  Containers for such nonresidential solid waste shall be watertight, equipped with tightfitting covers and be so designed and maintained as to prevent waste deposited therein from being blown or scattered about. 
2.  All containers for such nonresidential solid waste shall be located in an area set aside for the storage and collection of such material; and when such area includes an enclosure or screen specifically identified for the purpose of shielding the containers, all such containers shall be wholly located therein or behind said enclosure or screen. 
(C)  Location: All areas set aside for the collection of nonresidential solid waste shall be so located as to not be unsightly in appearance and offensive in odor and shall be so maintained as to prevent substances from scattering and becoming windblown. 
(D)  Licensing Requirements: It shall be the duty of every property owner who provides for the collection and removal of nonresidential solid waste and recyclables to see that such collection is effected by a scavenger duly licensed to operate in the Village pursuant to this chapter as well as title 3, chapter 28 of this Code. 
(E)  Hours of operation by scavengers: The regulations outlined in subsection 7-6-3(I) of this chapter shall also apply to nonresidential collection and disposal. 
(F)  Hazardous materials: The applicable state regulations shall govern the removal and disposal of hazardous materials. 
(G)  Effective date: The provisions of subsection (A)3. of this section relating to the separate collection of recyclable material shall become effective November 23, 2000. 
(H)  Exemption for hardship: Property owners who believe that the collection of recyclable materials as described herein cannot be implemented at a certain location may petition the Village for an exemption from this requirement. Petition shall be made to the Environmental Commission by both the owner and hauler for the property and shall identify the specific hardship for which the waiver is requested and shall include all pertinent information for review. The petition should include information on what options were considered and the reasons they were excluded and a properly scaled site plan showing the location of all buildings, structures, utilities and other obstacles needed for consideration. In the event that the Environmental Commission should deny a petition for exemption from this requirement, the petitioner shall be allowed to appeal the decision to the Village Board within 30 days of the Environmental Commission decision. The Village Board shall affirm, reverse, or modify the decision of the commission. 
(Ord. 4785, 11-22-1999) 
7-6-6. - Disposal of solid waste other than by collection. 
(A)  Burning restricted; burying prohibited: It shall be unlawful for any person to burn solid waste within the Village except in accordance with chapter 7 of this title.
