Whenever the Building and Zoning Official of the Village, or his/her authorized agent(s) or representative(s), determines that there are reasonable grounds to believe that there is, or has been, a violation of this section, the Building and Zoning Official of the Village, or his/her authorized agent(s) or representative(s),shall give notice of the alleged violation(s) to the user and/or the person in control of the FOG trap or FOG recovery system, as herein provided. Such notice shall: 
(a)  Be in writing; 
(b)  Include a statement of the reason(s) for issuance of the notice; 
(c)  Allow a reasonable time for the performance of any act it requires; 
(d)  Be served upon the user or operator of the FOG producing facility, as the case may require; provided that such notice shall be deemed to have been properly served upon such user or operator when a copy thereof has been sent by first class mail, postage prepaid, to his/her last known address as furnished to the Village, or personally delivered to the Executive Director or other person in charge of the FOG producing facility; and 
(e)  Contain an outline of remedial action which is required to affect compliance. 
(f)  In the event the alleged violation(s) are not remediated in a timely fashion, as determined by the Building and Zoning Official of the Village, or his/her designated agent(s) or representative(s), a citation will be issued which shall be adjudicated through the Village's Administrative Adjudication process set forth in Title I, Chapter 13 of the Glen Ellyn Municipal Code. 
2.  Whenever an emergency exists which requires immediate action to protect the public health, safety or welfare, or to protect public or private property from damage or destruction, the Building and Zoning Official of the Village, or his/her designated agent(s) or representative(s) may, without any administrative notice or procedure, seek an injunction to require that such action be taken as may be deemed necessary to meet the emergency. 
(M)  Enforcement penalties/remedies. 
1.  Any person or user, who violates any provision of this section, shall be fined not less than $100.00 or more than $750.00 for each violation, with each day that a violation has existed or continues to exist constituting a separate offense. 
2.  In addition to (1) above, any sewer or manhole overflow, or sewer back-up, resulting from a violation(s) of any provision of this section, or an inadequately operating FOG recovery system, or lack of an approved FOG recovery system, shall result in the imposition of a charge to the responsible owner(s) or user(s) equal to the costs incurred by the Village in cleaning the blockage out of the immediately adjacent Village wastewater collection system. Imposition of a charge under this subsection (2) shall not preclude other enforcement action(s). In addition, the responsible owner(s) or user(s) shall be responsible for payment of any fine levied by the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency against the Village as a result of any overflow or blockage in the Village's wastewater collection system, or NPDES permit discharge violations attributable to the owner(s)' or user(s)' violation of any provision of this section, or an inadequately operating FOG recovery system, or lack of an approved FOG recovery system. Any such charges as referenced in this subsection (2) shall be added to the sewer bill of the user. 
3.  The Building and Zoning Official of the Village, or his/her designated agent(s) or representative(s) may also take any other available legal action necessary to prevent or to remedy any violation, including, but not limited to, appropriate equitable or injunctive relief or discontinuation of wastewater treatment service to the FOG producing facility. 
(Ord. 6595, 4-23-2018) 
Editor's note- Ord. 6595, adopted April 23, 2018, repealed § 7-9-30 and enacted a new section as set out herein. Former § 7-9-30 pertained to traps required and derived from Ord. 4581, adopted April 13, 1998. 
7-9-31. - Dilution prohibited. 
No user shall increase the use of process water, or in any other way attempt to dilute a discharge as a partial or complete substitute for adequate pretreatment to achieve compliance with any applicable federal, state, and/or local pretreatment standard or requirement. The manager may impose mass limitations on users who use dilution to meet applicable pretreatment standards or requirements, or in cases where mass limitations are deemed appropriate. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-32. - Spill containment required. 
(A)  Each industrial user whose wastewater includes, or could include, compatible or incompatible pollutants in amounts or concentrations great enough to cause interference or pass through at the POTW treatment plant or to otherwise violate the provisions of this chapter shall provide protection from accidental discharge to the POTW of prohibited materials or other substances regulated by this chapter. Slug control plans and/or facilities to prevent such accidental discharge shall be provided and maintained at the owner's or user's expense. 
(B)  Each significant industrial user, and other industrial users as deemed necessary by the manager, shall be evaluated at least once every two years to determine the necessity for a slug control plan and/or facilities to prevent the accidental discharge of compatible or incompatible pollutants. The manager may require the user to develop, submit for approval, and implement a slug control plan. At the manager's discretion, such a plan may be developed for any user for which it is deemed necessary. Such a plan shall be developed in accordance with the requirements outlined in 40 CFR part 403.8(f)(2)(v)(A)-(D), and shall contain the following: 
1.  A description of discharge practices, including nonroutine batch discharges; 
2.  A description of stored chemicals; 
3.  Procedures for immediate notification to the POTW of slug discharges, including any discharge that would violate a prohibition under 40 CFR 403.5(b), with procedures for follow up written notification within five days; 
4.  If necessary, procedures to prevent adverse impact from accidental spills, including inspection of storage areas, handling and transfer of materials, loading and unloading operations, control of plant site runoff, worker training, building of containment structures or equipment, measures for containing toxic organic pollutants (including solvents) and/or measures and equipment for emergency response. 
(C)  In the case of an accidental or deliberate discharge of compatible or incompatible pollutants, including, but not limited to, slug loadings, which may cause interference at the POTW or will pass through the POTW or violate requirements of this chapter, it shall be the responsibility of an authorized officer of the industrial user to notify the manager and Director or other officials of the POTW by telephone, within 24 hours of discovery of the incident. The notification shall include name of caller, location and time of discharge, type of wastewater, concentration and volume. 
(D)  Within five working days following such an accidental or deliberate discharge or slug loading, the industrial user shall submit to the manager a detailed written report, signed by an authorized officer, describing the cause of the discharge and the measures to be taken by the user to prevent similar future occurrences. Follow up reports may be required by the manager as deemed necessary. Such report, or reports, shall not relieve the industrial user of any expense, loss, damage, or other liability which may be incurred as a result of damage to the POTW, fish kills or any other damage to person or property; nor shall such report relieve the user of any fines, civil penalties or other liability which may be imposed by this chapter or otherwise. Failure to report accidental or deliberate discharges may, in addition to any other remedies available to the Village or authority under this chapter, result in disconnection of the discharger's service line. 
(E)  The industrial user shall control production of all discharges to the extent necessary to maintain compliance with all applicable regulations upon reduction, loss, or accidental failure of its facility, until the facility is restored or an alternative method is provided. This requirement includes the situation where, among other things, the primary source of power of the facility is reduced, lost or fails. 
(F)  In cases where violations of discharge standards have occurred, the industrial user shall, in addition to providing 24-hour notification of violation to the POTW, resample its discharge for compliance with applicable discharge standards within 30 days. 
(G)  A notice in English and the language of common use shall be permanently posted on the industrial user's bulletin Board or other prominent place advising employees whom to call in the event of an accidental or illegal discharge. Employers shall ensure that all employees who are in a position to cause, discover, or observe such discharges are advised of the emergency notification procedures. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-33. - Responsibility of intermediate user. 
Any intermediate users shall be primarily responsible for complying with all provisions of this chapter. If any user serviced by an intermediate user is violating any provision of this chapter, it shall be the responsibility of the intermediate user to compel compliance by the user and, if necessary, disconnect the user from the intermediate user's collection system. 
Any enforcement procedures provided in this chapter, including fines, costs, and disconnection, may be instituted by the manager directly against the intermediate user, as well as the end user. In addition, the intermediate user shall be responsible for providing monitoring facilities as set forth in section 7-9-37 of this chapter where such facilities are deemed to be required or necessary by the manager. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-34. - Failure to pay sewer charges. 
Any user, whether domestic, nonindustrial, industrial or intermediate, who fails to pay the sewer charges provided by section 7-11-28 of this title shall be subject to late penalties, possible termination of service including disconnection from the sanitary sewer and a lien for delinquent charges upon the real estate to which the service is supplied or upon an intermediate user's collection system, as provided by sections 7-11-17 and 7-11-19 of this title. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-35. - Maximum allowable flow. 
(A)  The maximum allowable daily flow from a service line to a sanitary sewer shall be no more than three times the average daily domestic water usage of the users served by the service line. 
(B)  The maximum allowable daily peak flow of the intermediate users shall be no more than the amount determined by the following formula, plus uncorrected, nonexcessive inflow and infiltration, as follows: 
Three times domestic water usage plus permitted infiltration of 1,500 gallons per inch diameter per mile per day, plus allowable uncorrected, nonexcessive inflow and infiltration as follows: 
1.  For Citizens Utilities service area uncorrected, nonexcessive inflow and infiltration of 2.2 million gallons per day; 
2.  For Glen Ellyn Heights area served by DuPage County uncorrected, nonexcessive inflow and infiltration of 0.52 million gallons per day. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-36. - When pretreatment required. 
All significant industrial users shall provide necessary wastewater pretreatment as required to comply with this chapter, and shall achieve compliance with all applicable pretreatment standards within the time limitations as specified by appropriate statutes, regulations, and this chapter. National categorical pretreatment standards shall be made a part of this chapter as described in section 7-9-28 of this chapter. Any facilities required to pretreat wastewater to a level acceptable to the POTW shall be provided, properly operated and maintained at the user's expense. All industrial users shall obtain all necessary construction-operating permits from the IEPA. Such pretreatment facilities shall be under the control and direction of an IEPA certified wastewater treatment operator. Any subsequent significant changes in the pretreatment facilities or method of operation shall be reported to and required to be accepted by the manager prior to the industrial user's initiation of the changes. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-37. - Monitoring facilities. 
(A)  The significant industrial user shall provide, at its own expense, monitoring facilities to allow inspection, sampling and flow measurement of the service line in internal drainage systems. The monitoring facility will be situated on the user's premises unless such a location would be impractical and cause undue hardship to the user, and the manager allows the facility to be constructed in the public street or sidewalk area and located so that it will not be obstructed by landscaping, parked vehicles, or other activities of the user. 
(B)  Where required by the manager, to meet the objectives of this chapter, additional control manholes or sampling chambers shall be provided at the end of each industrial process, at the expense of the industrial user, which are suitable for the determination of compliance with pretreatment standards. 
(C)  Whenever required by the manager, any significant industrial user shall install a large manhole or sampling chamber for each separate discharge into the service line in accordance with plans and specifications approved by the manager, installed and maintained at all times at the user's expense, which shall have ample room in each sampling chamber to permit the manager to obtain accurate composite samples for analysis. The chamber shall be safely, easily and independently accessible to authorized representatives of the Glenbard Wastewater Authority at any time. 
1.  Each sampling chamber shall contain a Palmer-Bowlus flume unless a weir or similar device is approved by the manager with a recording and totalizing register for measurement of the liquid quantity; or at the discretion of the manager the metered water supply to the industrial plant may be used as the liquid quantity where it is substantiated that the metered water supply and waste quantities are approximately the same, or where a measurable adjustment agreed to by the POTW is made in the metered water supply to determine the liquid waste quantity. 
2.  When required, samples shall be taken by the industrial user every hour or half hour, as determined by the manager, and properly refrigerated and preserved in accordance with "standard methods" and shall be composited in proportion to the flow of a representative 24-hour sample. 
3.  The sampling chamber, metering device, and documentation of the frequency of sampling, sampling methods and analyses of samples shall be subject, at any reasonable time, to inspection and verification by the manager. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-38. - Testing standards. 
All measurements, tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes to which reference is made in this chapter shall be determined in accordance with 40 CFR 136, and shall be determined at the control manhole provided or upon suitable samples taken at said control manhole. In the event that no such manhole has been required, the control manhole shall be considered to be the nearest downstream manhole, in the sanitary sewer, to the point at which the service line is connected. Sampling shall be carried out by customarily accepted methods to reflect the effect of constituents upon the sewage treatment plant and to determine the existence of hazards to the treatment process and equipment and public health, safety and welfare. The particular analyses involved will determine whether a 24-hour composite of all outfalls of a premises is appropriate or whether a grab sample or samples should be taken. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-39. - Reporting requirements. 
(A)  Categorical dischargers: The following reporting requirements shall apply to categorical dischargers, and to significant industrial users not subject to categorical standards when required by the manager: 
1.  Discharge application: Significant industrial users shall submit an application form furnished by the POTW and signed by an authorized representative of the user. 
2.  Baseline report: 
(a)  Industrial users subject to national categorical pretreatment standards shall submit baseline monitoring reports to the POTW in a form prescribed and furnished by the POTW. 
(b)  Within 180 days after the effective date of a national categorical pretreatment standard, or 180 days after a final administrative decision has been made upon a categorical determination submission in accordance with 40 CFR section 403.6(a)(4), whichever is later, industrial users which are existing sources subject to such national categorical pretreatment standards and currently discharging to the POTW shall submit to the manager a properly completed baseline monitoring report. 
(c)  New sources, when subject to a national categorical pretreatment standard, shall submit a baseline monitoring report no later than 90 days prior to commencement of any discharge to the POTW. A new source shall provide the method of pretreatment it intends to use to meet applicable categorical standards, and estimates of its anticipated flow and quantity of pollutants to be discharged. 
(d)  In support of the baseline monitoring report, the industrial user shall submit, in units and terms specified in the application, the following information: 
(1)  Name and address of the facility including the name of the operator and owner (s). 
(2)  List of any environmental control permits held by or for the facility. 
(3)  Brief description of the nature, average rate of production, and standard industrial classification of the operations carried out by such user. This description shall include a schematic process diagram indicating points of discharge to the POTW from the regulated processes. 
(4)  Information showing the measured average daily and maximum daily flow, in gallons per day, to the POTW from each of the following: 
A.  Regulated process streams; and 
B.  Other streams as necessary to allow use of the combined waste stream formula of 40 CFR section 403.6(e). 
(5)  The industrial user shall identify the national categorical pretreatment standards applicable to each regulated process, and shall: 
A.  Submit the results of sampling and analysis identifying the nature and concentration of regulated pollutants in the discharge from each regulated process. Both daily maximum and average concentration shall be reported. The sample shall be representative of daily operations. 
B.  A minimum of four grab samples must be used for pH, cyanide, total phenols, oil and grease, sulfide and volatile organics. For all other pollutants, 24-hour composite samples must be obtained through flow proportional composite sampling techniques where feasible. The control authority may waive flow proportional composite sampling for an industrial user that demonstrates that flow proportional sampling is infeasible. In such cases, samples may be obtained through a minimum of four grab samples where the user demonstrates that this will provide a representative sample of the effluent being discharged. 
C.  Sample based on the flow of the sampled stream, as follows (composite samples are required where feasible): 
i.  Where the flow of the stream being sampled is less than or equal to 950,000 liters /day (approximately 250,000 gpd), the industrial user shall take a minimum of three samples within a two-week period. 
ii.  Where the flow of the stream being sampled is greater than 950,000 liters/day (approximately 250,000 gpd), the industrial user shall take a minimum of six samples within a two-week period. 
D.  Take the samples immediately downstream from pretreatment facilities if such exist or immediately downstream from the regulated process if no pretreatment exists. If other wastewaters are mixed with the regulated wastewater prior to pretreatment, in order to evaluate compliance with the national categorical pretreatment standards, the industrial user shall measure the flows and concentrations necessary to allow use of the combined waste stream formula of 40 CFR section 403.6(e). Where an alternate concentration has been calculated in accordance with 40 CFR section 403.6(e), this adjusted limit along with supporting data shall be submitted to the POTW. 
E.  Submit, only with POTW authorization, a baseline monitoring report which utilizes only historical data, so long as it provides information sufficient to determine the need for industrial pretreatment measures. 
F.  Provide for each report the time, date and place of sampling and methods of analysis and certification that such sampling and analysis is representative of normal work cycles and expected pollutant discharges to the POTW. 
(6)  The industrial user shall provide a statement, reviewed by an authorized representative of the industrial user and certified by a qualified professional indicating whether national categorical pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis and, if not, whether additional operation and maintenance measures or additional pretreatment is required for the industrial user to meet the national categorical pretreatment standards. 
(7)  If additional pretreatment or operation and maintenance measures will be required to meet the national categorical pretreatment standards, the industrial user will provide the shortest schedule which will provide such additional pretreatment or operation and maintenance measures. The completion date in this schedule shall not be later than the compliance date established for the applicable national categorical pretreatment standard. 
A.  Where the industrial user's national categorical pretreatment standard has been modified by the combined waste stream formula (40 CFR section 403.6(e)), or net /gross calculations (40 CFR section 403.15), at the time the industrial user submits a baseline monitoring report the information required in 40 CFR section 400.115(a)(4)(F) and (G) shall pertain to the modified limits. 
B.  If the national categorical pretreatment standard for the industrial user is modified after the baseline monitoring report is submitted, the industrial user shall make any necessary amendments to information provided as a response to 40 CFR section 400.115(a)(4)(F) and (G) and submit them to the POTW within 60 days after the modified limit is approved. 
(8)  The following conditions shall apply to any schedule submitted in response to 40 CFR section 400.115(a)(4)(G): 
A.  The schedule shall contain increments of progress in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of additional pretreatment required for the user to meet the applicable national categorical pretreatment standards (e.g., hiring an engineer, completing preliminary plans, completing final plans, executing contract for major components, commencing construction, completing construction). 
B.  No increment referred to in 40 CFR section 400.115(a)(4)(H) shall exceed 180 days. 
C.  Not later than 14 days following each date in the schedule and the final date for compliance, the user shall submit a progress report to the POTW including, at a minimum, whether or not it complied with the increment of progress to be met on such date and, if not, the date on which it expects to comply with this increment of progress, the reason for delay, and the steps being taken by the industrial user to return the construction to the schedule established. In no event shall more than nine months elapse between such progress reports to the POTW. 
D.  Such other information as may be reasonably requested by the POTW. 
3.  Compliance date report: Within 90 days following the date for final compliance with applicable national categorical pretreatment standards, or in the case of a new source, introduction by the new source of wastewater into the POTW, any industrial user subject to such pretreatment standards shall submit to the manager a report, on forms provided by the POTW, indicating the nature of the concentration of all pollutants in the discharge from the regulated process which are limited by pretreatment standards and requirements and the average and maximum daily flow for these process units in the user's facility which are limited by such pretreatment standards. The report shall state whether the applicable pretreatment standards are being met on a consistent basis and if not, what additional user operation and maintenance or pretreatment techniques or installations are necessary to bring the user into compliance with the applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. This statement shall be signed by an authorized representative of the industrial user and certified by a qualified professional. 
4.  Periodic compliance reports for significant industrial users: 
(a)  All significant industrial users subject to an applicable national categorical pretreatment standard, after the compliance date of such applicable national categorical pretreatment standard or, in the case of a new source, after discharge of wastewater to the POTW begins, shall submit to the POTW during the months of June and December for the preceding two calendar quarters, unless required more frequently in the national categorical pretreatment standard or by the POTW or IEPA, a certified report indicating the nature and concentration of pollutants in the effluent which are limited by such applicable national categorical pretreatment standards. In addition, this report shall include a record of measured or estimated average and maximum daily flows for the reporting period. 
(b)  At the discretion of the POTW, the significant industrial user not subject to national categorical pretreatement standards shall sample, analyze and report pollutants semiannually during the months of June and December for the preceding two calendar quarters, as determined and required by the manager, with any conditions he deems necessary. 
(c)  At the discretion of the POTW and in consideration of such factors as a local flow rate, holidays and budget cycles, the POTW may agree to alter the months during which the above reports are submitted. 
(d)  All wastewater discharge applications, baseline monitoring reports, and user compliance reports must be signed by an authorized representative of the user and contain the following certification statement: 
    I certify under penalty of law that this document and all attachments were prepared under my direction and supervision in accordance with a system designed to assure that qualified personnel properly gather and evaluate the information submitted. Based on my inquiry of the persons directly responsible for gathering the information, the information submitted is, to the best of my knowledge and belief, true, accurate, and complete. I am aware that there are significant penalties for submitting false information, including the possibility of fine and imprisonment for knowing violations. 
(B)  Industrial and intermediate users: The following reporting requirements shall apply to all industrial and intermediate users: 
1.  Industrial users and intermediate users are required to complete and return questionnaires, which may include baseline monitoring reports within 30 days of receipt to the Director or the manager. These questionnaires will inquire as to the nature and volume of wastes generated by particular industrial users. Additional information may be required concerning the disposal of byproducts or sludges generated by the industrial user, or excessive inflow or infiltration into the service lines of all users discharging into a sanitary sewer of an intermediate user or excessive infiltration or inflow into the sanitary sewer of an intermediate user. 
2.  The industrial user and intermediate user are required to submit a baseline monitoring report or any information regarding the introduction of pollutants into the sewage system. All information gathered through industrial user or intermediate user reports with respect to effluent data will be available to the public without restriction. 
Confidentiality may be granted to the industrial user by the EPA once the industrial user follows prescribed steps in claiming such confidentiality in compliance with 40 CFR part 2. In addition to the questionnaires as described in subsection (B)1. of this section, additional reports may be required at the discretion of the manager in carrying forth the objectives of this chapter. 
3.  In accordance with section 7-9-52 of this chapter, the industrial user shall assist the manager in his efforts to locate and identify all discharges into the sewage system which are in violation of this chapter. 
(C)  Record keeping procedures: Record keeping procedures shall be in accordance with 40 CFR 403.12(n). These provisions include the following: 
1.  Record keeping requirements: Records shall include for all samples: 
(a)  Names of sampling persons. 
(b)  Dates analyses were performed. 
(c)  Names of who performed analyses. 
(d)  The analytical methods used. 
(e)  The results of such analyses. 
2.  Records retention: The user shall keep the records for a minimum of three years. 
3.  Records inspection: All records shall be made available for inspection and copying by the Director, the manager, the Director of the Illinois environmental protection agency, and the regional administrator of the USEPA or their designees. This period of retention of records shall be extended during the course of any unresolved litigation regarding the industrial user or POTW or when requested by the Director, the manager, the Director of IEPA or the regional administrator of USEPA. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-40. - Required testing; expense. 
(A)  Any industrial user discharging industrial waste or industrial wastewater may be required by the manager to take samples and provide laboratory measurements, tests and analyses of wastewater and wastes to demonstrate compliance with this chapter and with any orders issued pursuant to the provisions of this chapter. 
(B)  The number, type, and frequency of the sampling and testing shall be as stipulated by the manager, and all samples and test results shall be reported within five days of completion. 
(C)  The user shall be responsible for all expenses of sampling, measurements, testing, analyses and reporting required by the manager. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-41. - Means for ensuring compliance. 
To ensure compliance with the industrial pretreatment program, the manager may take the following actions: 
(A)  Deny or condition new or increased contributions of pollutants, or changes in the nature of pollutants, to the POTW by industrial users where such contributions do not meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements or where such contributions would cause the POTW to violate its NPDES permit. 
(B)  Require compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements by industrial users. 
(C)  Control, pursuant to the requirements outlined in 40 CFR 403.8(f)(1)(iii), compliance with national categorical pretreatement standards, in those cases where such limits are applicable, and local ordinance limits, which are applicable to all industrial users, through issuance of a discharge control document. Such a document shall contain the required elements stated in 40 CFR 403.8(f)(1)(iii)(A)-(E), and shall consist of: 
1.  Statement of duration (in no case more than five years); 
2.  Statement of nontransferability (without prior written notification to the control authority and provision of a copy of the existing control document to the new owner or operator); 
3.  Statement of applicable federal, state, and/or local effluent discharge limits; 
4.  Statement of self-monitoring, sampling, reporting, notification, and record keeping requirements; 
5.  Statement of applicable criminal and civil penalties and any applicable compliance schedule (such a schedule may not extend the compliance date past applicable federal deadlines). 
(D)  Require the development of a compliance schedule by each industrial user for the installation of technology required to meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements; and the submission of all notices and semiannual self-monitoring reports from industrial users as are necessary to assess and assure compliance by industrial users with pretreatment standards and requirements including, but not limited to, the reports required in 40 CFR 403.12; said schedule shall contain progress increments in the form of dates for the commencement and completion of major events leading to the construction and operation of pretreatment facilities required for the user to meet applicable pretreatment standards (including, but not limited to, hiring an engineer, completing preliminary or final plans, executing contracts for major components, commencing and completing construction, and beginning and conducting routine operation); 
1.  No increment required in a compliance schedule shall exceed nine months; 
2.  The user shall submit progress reports no later than 14 days following each date in a compliance schedule and the final date of compliance. Such reports shall include, at a minimum, whether or not the increment of progress has been met, the reason for any delay, and, where necessary, the steps to be taken by the user to return to the established schedule. 
(E)  Carry out at least once yearly inspection and sampling of all significant industrial users to determine, independent of information supplied by industrial users, compliance or noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements by industrial users. 
(F)  Obtain remedies for noncompliance by any industrial user with any pretreatment standard and requirement. 
(G)  Identify and locate all possible industrial users which might be subject to the pretreatment program. Any compilation, index, or inventory of industrial users made under this division shall be made available to the regional administrator or Public Works Director upon request. 
(H)  Provide industrial users with information concerning applicable pretreatment standards. 
(I)  Receive and analyze semiannual self-monitoring reports and other notices submitted by industrial users in accordance with the self-monitoring requirements of the pretreatment program. 
(J)  Randomly sample and analyze the effluent from industrial users and conduct surveillance and inspection activities in order to identify, independent of information supplied by industrial users, occasional and continuing noncompliance with pretreatment standards. The results of these activities shall be made available to the regional administrator or Public Works Director upon request. 
(K)  Investigate instances of noncompliance with pretreatment standards and requirements, as indicated in the reports and notices required or indicated by analysis, inspection, and surveillance activities. Sample taking and analysis and the collection of other information shall be performed with sufficient care to produce evidence admissible in enforcement proceedings or in judicial actions; and 
(L)  Notify the Village to instigate enforcement procedures, where necessary to obtain compliance, as set forth in sections 7-9-48 through 7-9-50 of this chapter. 
(M)  The Manager shall require all industrial users to: 
1.  Identify the character and volume of pollutants contributed to the POTW by the industrial users and require the industrial user to provide notification to the POTW of any discharge that could be considered a hazardous waste if disposed of in a different manner. 
2.  Provide to the control authority, in writing, prior notification of any changes in the volume or character of the pollutants in their discharges. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-42. - Public notification of significant noncompliance. 
The Manager shall annually publish in the largest daily newspaper published in the municipalities in which the authority is located, a list of industrial users and intermediate users who were determined to be in significant noncompliance with applicable pretreatment standards or requirements or excessive inflow or infiltration during the previous 12 months. The notification shall also summarize any enforcement actions taken against those industrial users or intermediate users during the same 12 months. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-43. - Compulsory compliance procedures. 
(A)  Notice of violation and compliance meeting: Should a violation of this chapter by an industrial user or intermediate user occur, including a violation of the maximum permissible inflow and infiltration of storm water, whether or not a significant industrial user, the manager shall notify the offending user, in writing, through a "notice of violation" as to the particulars of such violation or violations and set a time and place for a meeting (hereinafter called a "compliance meeting") to be attended by representatives of the POTW and the industrial user and/or intermediate user. The purpose of such a meeting shall be to establish such procedures, investigations, studies and compliance measures as the manager deems necessary and desirable to control and prevent violation of this chapter. Prior issuance of a "notice of violation" is not required for the manager to institute further enforcement actions, in addition to the procedures outlined above. The industrial user and/or intermediate user shall cooperate fully with the manager in making such investigations and studies. 
(B)  Order: 
1.  Following the completion of any procedures, investigations or studies as described in subsection (A) of this section, the manager may issue an order which may: 
(a)  Require compliance with applicable pretreatment standards and requirements. 
(b)  Require the user to control the contribution to the POTW to ensure compliance with applicable treatment standards and requirements and the conditions of any NPDES permit of the authority or the POTW. 
(c)  Require the development of a compliance schedule for the installation of technology required to meet applicable pretreatment standards and requirements; and the submission of all notices and self-monitoring reports as are necessary to assess and assure compliance by industrial users with pretreatment standards and requirements, including, but not limited to, the reports required by sections 7-9-36 through 7-9-41 of this chapter. 
(d)  Require abatement of excessive inflow or infiltration of storm water. 
(e)  Require payment of any costs associated with sampling, analytical or testing purpose to detect or prove any violation of this chapter. 
2.  If the manager has sufficient information at the time of the compliance meeting to determine necessary and desirable compliance measures, he may, at the time of the compliance meeting, issue an order directing and requiring the industrial user and/or intermediate user to take such action, including pretreatment, without further investigation or study. 
3.  Failure to comply with the order of the manager shall be deemed a violation of this chapter and may be grounds for such other actions as may be authorized for violation of this chapter. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-44. - Order to show cause regarding disconnection. 
(A)  Order to show cause: The manager may, upon discovering an ongoing or potential discharge to the POTW which presents or may present a danger to the environment or which threatens to interfere with the operation of the POTW, including excessive inflow or infiltration of storm water, immediately issue an order to the responsible industrial user and/or intermediate user to show cause why the POTW or Village should not disconnect service, or seek injunctive relief to prohibit the industrial user or intermediate user from making the discharge to the POTW. 
(B)  Procedures for show cause hearing: 
1.  A notice shall be served on the industrial user and/or intermediate user specifying the time and place of a hearing to be held by the manager or his delegate regarding the ongoing or potential discharge of pollutants or excessive storm water to the POTW which reasonably appears to present an imminent danger to the health or welfare of persons, or the operation of the POTW, the reasons why the action is to be taken, the proposed action, and directing the industrial user and/or intermediate user to show cause why its service should not be disconnected. The notice of the hearing shall be served personally or by registered or certified mail, return receipt requested, at least ten days before the hearing. Service may be made on any agent or officer of a corporation or other business entity. 
2.  The executive oversight committee may itself conduct the hearing and take the evidence, or may designate any of its members or its attorney to conduct the hearing as a Hearing Officer and to: 
(a)  Issue in the name of the executive oversight committee notices of hearings requesting the attendance and testimony of witnesses and the production of evidence relevant to any matter involved in such hearing; 
(b)  Take the evidence; 
(c)  Transmit a report of the evidence and hearing, including transcripts and other evidence, together with recommendations to the executive oversight committee for action thereon. 
3.  At any hearing held pursuant to this chapter, testimony taken must be under oath and recorded stenographically or by tape recording. The transcript of said hearing will be made available to any member of the public or any party to the hearing upon payment of the usual copying charges therefor. 
4.  After the executive oversight committee has reviewed the evidence, it may issue an order to the industrial user or intermediate user responsible for the discharge directing either: 
(a)  That the service be disconnected; or 
(b)  That following a specified time, the sewer service shall be discontinued unless adequate treatment facilities, devices or other related appurtenances have been installed and operated properly; or 
(c)  Direct the user to cease the unauthorized discharge effective after a specified period of time; or 
(d)  That such other action as deemed necessary by the executive oversight committee to abate the discharge be done by the industrial user or by the intermediate user. Further orders and directives as are necessary may be issued. 
5.  Following an order under this section, the industrial user or intermediate user shall cease discharging to the POTW in accordance with the terms of said order. Failure to do so shall be prima facie evidence of continuing harm to the POTW and provide grounds for the granting of injunctive relief or temporary restraining orders. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-45. - Excessive inflow or infiltration of storm water for users other than industrial users or intermediate users. 
(A)  This section applies to all users other than industrial users and intermediate users. 
(B)  In the event the Director or the manager determines that a user to whom this section applies, is discharging excessive flows of storm water to a sanitary sewer due to improper connections, inadvertence, lack of maintenance of the service line or due to any other cause, then the Director or the manager may institute the compulsory compliance and show cause procedures set forth in sections 7-9-43 and 7-9-44 of this chapter as to the user, as though the user was an industrial user. The remedy of disconnection of the service line from the sanitary sewer shall not apply in these instances, until the user has failed to eliminate the prohibited storm water connection or the excessive flow or infiltration of storm water for 120 days after being ordered to do so. 
(C)  In addition to the remedies set forth herein, the remedies set forth in sections 7-9-48 through 7-9-51 of this chapter shall apply. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-46. - Immediate disconnection of service. 
(A)  Conditions for immediate disconnection of service: Any industrial user is subject to immediate disconnection of service whenever immediate disconnection is required to halt or prevent any discharge of pollutants to the POTW which reasonably appears to the manager to present an imminent endangerment to the health or welfare of persons. The manager may also immediately suspend an industrial user's discharge, after notice and opportunity to respond, that threatens to interfere with the operation of the POTW or which presents, or may present, an endangerment to the environment. 
(B)  Procedures of immediate disconnection: Not withstanding section 7-9-43 or 7-9-44 of this chapter, the manager shall have the authority, after informal notice to the industrial user and the Village, to immediately and effectively halt or prevent any discharge of pollutants to the POTW that reasonably appears to present an imminent endangerment to the health or welfare of persons. When the manager determines that such an emergency situation exists, he shall issue a verbal order (followed immediately by a written order) to the industrial user stating the problem and requiring immediate cessation of discharge. The manager's actions may include disconnection of wastewater collection service, by blockage or severance of the sewer connection. The manager shall obtain the concurrence of the attorney for the Village before disconnection. Methods of informal notice shall include, but not be limited to, any of the following: personal conversation between the industrial user and authority employees, telephone calls, letters, hand delivered messages or notices posted at the industrial user's premises or point of discharge. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-47. - Elimination of discharge; reinstatement. 
Any industrial user and/or intermediate user notified of a disconnection of wastewater treatment service under sections 7-9-43 and 7-9-44 of this chapter shall immediately stop or eliminate the discharge. In the event of a failure of the industrial user and/or intermediate user to comply voluntarily with the disconnection order, the manager shall take such steps as deemed necessary, including immediate blockage or severance of the sewer connection, to prevent or minimize damage to the POTW system or danger to any person. If the manager exercises his authority under section 7-9-46 of this chapter, the manager shall reinstate the wastewater treatment service upon satisfactory proof of the elimination of the noncomplying discharge. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-48. - Injunctive relief. 
(A)  The Village may institute a civil action for an injunction to restrain violations of this chapter. 
(B)  The Village may, upon discovering an ongoing or potential discharge of pollutants or of excessive storm water to the POTW which reasonably appears to present an imminent danger to the health or welfare of persons, or an ongoing or repetitive interference with proper operation of the POTW, including excessive flows of storm water, seek and obtain a temporary restraining order or preliminary injunction to halt or prohibit such discharge. Informal notice between the Village and the discharger shall be attempted, but shall not be considered a condition precedent to POTW petitioning for and obtaining a temporary restraining order. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-49. - Additional remedies. 
(A)  In addition to remedies available to the Village set forth elsewhere in this chapter, if the POTW, the authority or the Village is fined by the State of Illinois or USEPA for violation of the POTW NPDES permit, violation of water quality standards or violation of the maximum capacity of the POTW as the result of discharge of pollutants or of excessive inflow or infiltration of storm water, then the fine, including all the POTW legal, sampling, analytical, and testing costs and any other related costs shall be charged to the responsible industrial user or intermediate user. Such charge shall be in addition to, and not in lieu of, any other remedies the Village may have under this chapter, statutes, regulations, at law or in equity. 
(B)  If the discharge from any user causes a deposit, obstruction or damage to any of the POTW, the manager shall cause the deposit or obstruction to be promptly removed or cause the damage to be promptly repaired. The cost for such work, including materials, labor and supervision, shall be the responsibility of the user causing such deposit, obstruction or damage. 
(C)  The remedies provided in this chapter shall not be exclusive and other remedies as authorized by statute, at law or in equity may be sought against any user violating the provisions of this chapter. 
(D)  In addition to any fine levied under sections 7-9-50 and 7-9-51 of this chapter, where the circumstances of the particular case so dictate, injunctive relief to prohibit the user from discharging into the sanitary sewer system, or to provide such other affirmative relief as may be appropriate may be sought. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-50. - Fines and costs. 
Any user who is found to have violated an order of the manager or who has failed to comply with any provision of this chapter and the orders, rules and regulations, shall be subject to a fine not to exceed $1,000.00, in which case the standard of proof shall not be such standard as is applicable in an ordinance violation without a fine; or in the event that imprisonment up to six months in jail is sought, the standard shall be that applicable to a criminal penalty. For the purpose of this section, each day in which any such violation shall occur, shall be deemed a separate violation, and a separate violation shall be deemed to have occurred for each constituent which has limitations listed in section 7-9-28 of this chapter found to exceed the limits established in this chapter during any such day. In addition to the penalties provided herein, the Village may recover reasonable attorney fees, court costs, court reporter fees and other expenses of litigation such as sampling analytical and testing costs by appropriate suit at law against the person found to have violated this chapter or the orders, rules, regulations and permits issued hereunder. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-51. - Falsification. 
Any person who knowingly makes any false statements, representation or certification in any application, record, report, plan or other document filed or required to be maintained pursuant to this chapter or wastewater discharge permit, or who falsifies, tampers with or knowingly renders inaccurate any monitoring device or method required under this chapter, shall be subject to the penalties and costs provided in section 7-9-50 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-52. - Power and authority of inspectors. 
As a condition of the provisions of sewage collection and/or treatment, the manager and other duly authorized representatives of the authority and/or of the Village, bearing proper credentials and identification, shall be permitted to enter all properties of any user for the purposes of inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing to determine compliance with the provisions of this chapter. The management or duly authorized representatives shall have authority to inquire into any processes, including metallurgical, chemical, oil refining, ceramic, paper or other industrial processes beyond that point having a direct effect on the kind and source of discharge to the storm or sanitary sewers, natural outlet or facilities for wastewater treatment. Failure to allow such inspection, observation, measurement, sampling and testing at any reasonable time may result in the termination of service to such premises. Notification of such intention to terminate service to such premises shall be given in accordance with section 7-9-46 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-53. - Appeal from decision of Director. 
Any person directly aggrieved by any provisions of this chapter or any decisions of the Director made pursuant to this chapter shall have the right to request a variance from the provisions of this chapter or appeal any decision of the Director made pursuant to this chapter to the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-54. - Appeal from decision of manager. 
Any person directly aggrieved by any provisions of this chapter or any decision of the manager made pursuant to this chapter shall have the right to request a variance from the provisions of this chapter or appeal any decision of the manager made pursuant to this chapter to the authority. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-55. - Severability. 
If any provision, paragraph, word, section or article of this chapter is invalidated by any court of competent jurisdiction, the remaining provisions, paragraphs, words, sections and chapters shall not be affected and shall continue in full force and effect. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-56. - Waiver of liability. 
All sewer connections applied for, and all sewer service used under this chapter shall be upon the express conditions that the Village shall not be liable for any claim made against it, for damages or injury caused by reason of the breaking of any main, branch, service pipe, apparatus or appurtenance connected with said pipe, apparatus or appurtenance connected with said system, or for any interruption of service by reason of the breakage of equipment or machinery or by reason of stoppage, alteration, extension or renewal. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-9-57. - Property owner's responsibility. 
The sanitary service line serving a building and extending to the public sewer is owned by the property owner. The property owner is responsible for the maintenance and repair of the service line serving his property in accordance with section 7-9-22 of this chapter. 
(Ord. 5318, 12-20-2004) 
7-9-58. - Cost sharing for repair. 
The Village will reimburse a property owner for one-half of costs to repair the service line where the area of repair occurs in the public right-of-way between the sanitary sewer main and a point ten feet from the edge of pavement or back of curb on the property owner's side of the street (the cost share area) when all the terms and conditions of this repair program are satisfied. A repair will typically consist of excavation, pipe replacement, pipe bedding, backfill, and temporary surface restoration to return the dig site to a safe and usable condition. 
(Ord. 5318, 12-20-2004) 
7-9-59. - Need for repair. 
The property owner must determine, to the satisfaction of the Village and at his expense, the need for and location of the proposed repair of the service line. 
(Ord. 5318, 12-20-2004) 
7-9-60. - Repairs performed by property owner. 
The property owner will be responsible for hiring the underground contractor to perform repairs. The contractor must have the requisite experience and ability; have sufficient capital, facilities, and plan to perform the intended repair successfully and promptly; and be properly licensed, bonded, and insured. The Village may assist the property owner by providing a list of contractors that could be contacted to perform the repair. The Village reserves the right to review the proposal provided by a contractor to the property owner for terms, completeness of the project scope, and reasonableness of costs. 
(Ord. 5318, 12-20-2004) 
7-9-61. - Permits required. 
The property owner will be responsible for procuring the required Village permit prior to the start of repair work. The Village will inspect the work performed to verify the location of the repair and that the repair satisfies code requirements. 
(Ord. 5318, 12-20-2004) 
7-9-62. - Surface restoration costs. 
The Village will be responsible for all final surface restoration costs associated with qualifying service line repairs that are required in the cost share area. Restorations may include pavement, curb and gutter, landscaping, sidewalk, shoulder and driveway. The Village may utilize its own forces or outside contractors to perform the final restorations required. The property owner is solely responsible for all sewer pipe repairs /replacement and surface restoration costs for service line repairs that occur from the building to the demarcation point located ten feet from the back of curb or edge of pavement. 
(Ord. 5318, 12-20-2004) 
7-9-63. - Maintenance responsibility. 
Property owners are solely responsible for all maintenance activities on their private sanitary sewer service line from the building to the main public sewer. Maintenance activities include, but are not necessarily limited to, sewer rodding, flushing, cleaning, root cutting or other root eradication procedures, televising, and locating. 
(Ord. 5318, 12-20-2004) 
7-9-64. - Applicability to new construction projects. 
Property owners may participate in the sanitary sewer service line repair cost sharing program if the work is part of a project to replace the entire private sanitary service line from the building to the Village sanitary sewer main and meets any one of the following requirements: 
(A)  The existing building floor area is increased by not less than 75 percent or more than 150 percent. 
(B)  The existing building exterior roof and wall area is structurally altered by not less than 50 percent or more than 75 percent. 
(C)  The existing building is remodeled with a hard cost not less than $15,000.00 and not more than $200,000.00. 
(Ord. 5996, 1-30-2012, eff. 3-1-2012) 
7-9-65. - Sanitary sewer mains and services on private property. 
Where a sanitary sewer service serving a property lies wholly or substantially outside of the public right-of-way, the Village will reimburse a property owner for one-half of the costs to repair the service line when the area of repair occurs between the sanitary sewer main and a point established toward the principal structure a length of one-third of the distance between the structure and the centerline of the main, but in any case not less than 15 feet nor greater than 25 feet (private property cost share area). 
Private property surface restorations would be the responsibility of the property owner. The Village will reimburse the owner a lump sum amount of $500.00 to defray restoration costs within the private property cost share area. The Village will not be responsible for extraordinary expenses associated with the removal and replacement of structures, landscaping and other impediments to performing the service line repairs within the private property cost share area. 
(Ord. 5379, 7-25-2005) 
Chapter 10 - WATER SYSTEM REGULATIONS 

7-10-1. - Water division. 
(A)  Creation: There is hereby created the water division within the Public Works Department, consisting of the water superintendent and such other officers and employees as may be assigned thereto. 
(B)  Superintendent: The water superintendent shall be appointed by the Village Administrator. 
(C)  Duties: The water superintendent shall be responsible for the efficient management of the water division. All officers and employees assigned to this division shall perform their duties, subject to the control and supervision of the superintendent, and shall obey all instruction and orders given by him. 
(D)  Enforcement of regulations: The water superintendent, and all officers and employees of the water division, shall be charged with, and be responsible for, the enforcement of all regulations relating to the water supply system. 
(E)  Plumbing inspection: In the absence of a specific appointment to the office of plumbing inspector, plumbing will be self-inspected by a state licensed plumber. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982; Ord. 3829, 4-22-1991) 
7-10-2. - Jurisdiction. 
Except as otherwise provided in this chapter, there is hereby vested in the water division, subject to the control of the President and Board of Trustees, the responsibility for the operation, maintenance, preservation and extension of the waterworks system of the Village and the procuring and selling of water. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-3. - Reports. 
(A)  The water superintendent shall, when requested by the Board of Trustees, report upon the condition of the division and all matters and things relating thereto. 
(B)  He shall also prepare and keep in his office a complete atlas of all water mains, and appurtenances thereto, laid or constructed in the Village. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-4. - Forms. 
The Management Services Director, in consultation with the water superintendent and subject to the approval of the President and Board of Trustees, shall cause to be prepared suitable forms for applications for water service and for water bills, with such information concerning rules, regulations, ordinances and water rates printed thereon as may be deemed advisable. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-5. - Extension of water mains. 
(A)  It shall be the duty of the Public Works Director to determine when it is necessary or advisable to lay or extend any water mains or water supply pipes in the Village and to recommend to the Village Board the proposed location and size of such main or pipe. 
(B)  No water main or water supply pipe shall be laid or extended except upon the passage and approval of an ordinance by the President and Board of Trustees, directing the laying or extension of such main or pipe, fixing the location thereof, the size to be used, and the method of financing the cost of the same. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982; Ord. 5454, 4-10-2006) 
7-10-6. - Extension of combined waterworks and sewage system to new areas. 
(A)  Preliminary survey: When the owner of one or more building sites within a lot, block, tract or parcel of land within the corporate limits of the Village, which is not served by the Village water or sanitary sewage system, requests permission to construct, at his expense, an extension of the water or sewage system to serve the property owned by him, the Public Works Director shall make a preliminary survey of the premises, and report to the Board of Trustees on the feasibility of such construction and connection to the water or sewage system. The property owner requesting such connection shall pay the cost of this preliminary service. 
(B)  Plans, specifications and estimate of cost: If it appears from the report of the Public Works Director that the Village water or sewage system, as it then exists, is of ample size and design to accommodate the property which will be serviced by such extensions, and if the property owner desires to proceed with construction, the property owner shall employ a registered professional engineer to prepare construction plans, specifications and a detailed estimate of cost including construction engineering fees. The plans, specifications and cost estimates shall be submitted to the Public Works Director for review and approval. An engineering review and inspection fee equal to four percent of the estimated costs of the improvements shall be paid to the Village Collector. 
(C)  Construction bids: Upon approval of the plans, specifications and cost estimates by the Public Works Director and at the discretion of the property owner requesting the water or sewer extension, the Board of Trustees shall advertise and take bids for the construction of the work specified in the plans and specifications and exhibit such bids to the property owner. 
(D)  Cost deposit: If one of the bids is acceptable, the property owner will deposit with the Village an amount of money sufficient to pay the entire cost of constructing said extension, including construction, engineering and legal fees, if any; and the Village Collector shall hold the money so deposited with him in a separate account which shall be used for no purpose other than to pay the cost of constructing the water and sewer extension. 
(E)  Contract for work: Upon the deposit of money provided for above, the Board of Trustees will enter into a contract with the successful bidder for the construction of the requested water or sewer extension, and the work shall be done under the supervision of the Public Works Director. 
(F)  Payments for work: Payments for the work shall be made by the management services Director from the funds deposited with him upon payment estimates from time to time received from the Village Engineer, which have been approved by the Board of Trustees. 
(Ord. 2615, 12-8-1980; amd. Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982; amd. Ord. 5454, 4-10-2006) 
7-10-7. - Permit required. 
No person shall turn on or use water from the water system unless so authorized by the water superintendent, by the issuance of a permit to use the water system. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-8. - Seals. 
No seal affixed by the water division at any meter, valve, fitting or other water connection shall be defaced or broken. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-9. - Fire hydrants. 
(A)  No person, other than a member of the Fire Department or an employee of the water division, shall open or use water from any fire hydrant connected with the water system of the Village unless specifically authorized by the utilities superintendent. 
(B)  Any use of fire hydrants authorized by the utilities superintendent shall be through Village furnished hydrant meters. Water supplied through hydrant meters shall be billed at twice the current rate charged for water and sewer service in the Village. No discount shall be given for water used and not returned to the Village sanitary sewer system. A nonrefundable administrative charge of $50.00 and a deposit of $500.00 shall be collected prior to the issuance of all hydrant meters for use in the Village. Said deposit shall be returned to the applicant, minus the cost of the water used, upon return of the meter in good condition to the Public Works Department. 
(C)  Water may be purchased in bulk quantities at the Reno Public Works Service Center at a ten percent surcharge to the current water rate charged to residents. This water charge will not include a sewer charge. 
(D)  Any use of fire hydrants authorized by the Public Works Department for the demolition of any structure or part thereof shall be through Village furnished hydrant meters and must comply with the following regulations: 
1.  All meters shall be installed and removed by the Village of Glen Ellyn. The demolition permit applicant or authorized agent shall contact Public Works to schedule the hydrant installation for the date of the proposed demolition. A minimum of 48 hours' notice is required to schedule the hydrant installation. On the day of the demolition, Public Works staff will install the meter before 8:00 a.m. Contractors must be on site to accept responsibility for the hydrant meter and show that a one and one-half inch diameter hose is available. When the outdoor temperature is 32 degrees or less, a hydrant meter shall not be required for demolition unless authorized by the Public Works Director, and in lieu thereof a watering truck must be provided as a source of water to control dust and airborne particles during the demolition process. 
2.  The Village will remove all hydrant meters by 4:00 p.m. The applicant or authorized agent shall contact Public Works for an earlier removal or special arrangements can be made for a later pick up at the applicant's expense. 
3.  The fee for water usage, hydrant meter installation and removal in the amount of $250.00 for the first day and an additional fee in the amount of $75.00 for each additional day shall be required for the demolition of a building or structure, or part thereof, greater than 1,000 and up to 4,000 square feet and not exceeding 45 feet in height. 
4.  The fee for water usage, hydrant meter installation and removal in the amount of $400.00 for the first day and an additional fee in the amount of $100.00 for each additional day shall be required for the demolition of a building or structure, or part thereof, greater than 4,000 square feet or exceeding 45 feet in height. 
(E)  Any use of fire hydrant meters may only occur when the ambient temperature is above 32 degrees Fahrenheit. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998; Ord. 4599, 5-26-1998; Ord. 5432, 2-13-2006; Ord. 5996, 1-30-2012, eff. 3-1-2012) 
7-10-10. - Tampering with meter. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to tamper with any water meter, or in any way interfere with the proper recording of the water consumed on, or in respect to, any premises. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-11. - Connection required. 
All buildings constructed in the Village on lots which are within 400 feet of a water main shall be connected thereto and subject to the provisions of this chapter. In the case of involuntarily annexed property, the time period for such connection may be established as provided in subsection 7-11-31(D) of this title. 
(Ord. 4075, 12-20-1993) 
7-10-12. - Supplying other premises. 
No person receiving water through the water system of the Village shall supply other persons or premises unless a permit to do so has been applied for and obtained from the utilities superintendent. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-13. - Private water supply system restrictions. 
(A)  Interconnection prohibited: Whenever a private water system which receives its supply from any well, cistern or other source apart from the water system of the Village is installed or maintained inside or outside of any building or structure, on public or private property, such private water system shall be kept entirely separated from and not connected, directly or indirectly, with any pipe or system of pipes receiving water from the water system of the Village. 
(B)  Limitation on use: No private water supply system shall be installed or maintained to serve any premises or property within the Village limits if that premises or property is within 400 feet of the water system of the Village, except to construct, maintain and operate a private water supply system solely to irrigate landscaped areas, in accordance with the following requirements: 
1.  No more than one private water supply system shall be permitted per lot, parcel, or zoning lot. No private water supply system is allowed to provide service to another lot, parcel or zoning lot. 
2.  The private water supply system shall not be connected in any manner to supply potable water, drinking water or water for any other domestic use, including filling or replenishing swimming pools. In order to assure that water from such a private water supply system is not so connected, the Village may require and take a periodic bacteriological sampling of the water entering any building on the property served by such a system. 
3.  No private water supply system shall be permitted which, within reasonable engineering certainty, could adversely affect the aquifer from which the well receives water or otherwise interfere with any public or other private water supply system. 
4.  No permit for a private water supply system shall be granted if such private water supply system is in violation of any rule or regulation of the DuPage Water Commission or in breach or violation of any contract between the Village and the DuPage Water Commission which presently exists or may be entered into by the Village in the future. 
5.  Should the DuPage Water Commission charge the Village any amount of fee, penalty or other charge relative to the water supplied by any private water supply system for which a permit is granted, then the owner of the private system shall pay such amount to the Village as a condition of maintaining such private water supply system. 
6.  Wells for the private water supply system shall not be drilled to a depth greater than 200 feet. 
7.  Wells shall be no less than 15 feet from any publicly operated or privately owned water main. 
8.  No permit for a private water supply system shall be issued until evidence is provided that a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer (RPZ), or equal device as approved by the water division, has been installed on any water service pipe(s)/line(s) connecting a structure to the well and on any water service pipe(s)/line(s) connecting the structure to the public water supply. The owner of property required to install a reduced pressure principle backflow preventer (RPZ) shall have the device tested annually at his or her expense by a person approved by the Illinois environmental protection agency as a cross connection control device inspector (CCCDI). This certificate of inspection shall be filed with the Village utilities superintendent or his designee within ten days of the annual inspection requirement date. Each RPZ shall have a tag attached listing the date of the most recent test, the name of the CCCDI, and type and date of any repairs. The owner shall maintain a maintenance log including: a) date of each test, b) name and approval number of person performing the test, c) test results, d) repairs or servicing required, e) repairs and date completed, and f) service performed and date completed. The backflow prevention device shall be maintained in good working condition by the owner. 
9.  The private water supply system may supply water to a pond or other storage facility from which water is pumped for use solely to irrigate landscaped areas. 
Should the pond to which the well supplies water also be used for detention or retention as part of a stormwater management system, then an engineering analysis and opinion must be provided by the private water supply system owner to show to the reasonable satisfaction of the Public Works Director that the stormwater management function of the pond will not be adversely affected by pumping well water to the pond, or if such stormwater management function could be adversely affected by pumping well water to the pond, then operation limitations shall be suggested in the engineering analysis to eliminate any adverse effect on the stormwater management function of the pond. 
10.  Any permit for construction, operation and maintenance of a private water supply system shall be subject to such conditions as the Village Board deems proper to protect the health, safety or welfare of the Village and its residents. 
11.  The Village reserves the right to shut off or cap the private water supply system without advance notice to the owner in the event of an emergency affecting the health or safety of persons. 
(C)  Permit required: It shall be unlawful for any person to maintain or permit to be maintained, to dig, drill, redrill or extend, or cause to be dug, drilled, redrilled, or extended, any well, hole or other excavation in the ground for the purpose of extracting water therefrom, without: 1) having first applied for and obtained a permit for such well from the Village, which permit shall not be issued unless the applicant provides satisfactory evidence to the effect that such well is permitted under provisions of subsection (B) of this section; 2) establishing that permits therefor have also been issued by DuPage County, the Illinois Department of Mines and Minerals and any other governmental authority having jurisdiction thereof; and 3) certifying that such well will be in full compliance with all applicable health and safety requirements of DuPage County and the state. Permit fee cost shall be $100.00. 
(D)  Water conservation regulation: Such private water supply systems shall not be subject to the water conservation regulations in section 7-10-26 of this chapter if the owner or occupant of the property on which the well is located displays a "private well" sign. A metal sign shall be placed in the front yard or a paper sign in the window of the property in a location clearly visible from the street. Except as otherwise provided in the preceding sentences, such private water supply systems shall be subject to the water conservation regulations in section 7-10-26 of this chapter. 
(E)  Public drinking fountains: In any event, no private water supply system shall be used to furnish water for a public drinking fountain or as a source from which to supply or sell to the public water for drinking or domestic purposes. 
(F)  Annual fee: Expenses incurred by the Village to regulate and administer private water supply systems for irrigation use shall be paid for by the owners of such systems through an annual fee of $50.00. The fee charged shall be added to the water bill for Village water for such system owner and shall constitute an expense to the owner thereof. 
(G)  Penalty: In the event that the certificate of inspection for the reduced pressure principle backflow preventer (RPZ) is not filed with the Village utilities superintendent or his designee within ten days of the annual certification date, the utilities superintendent or his designee shall notify the property owner (by certified mail) of the delinquency. The utilities superintendent or his designee is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue the water service to any property after reasonable written notice. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such certification has been provided to the Village and until a $20.00 service fee for termination of service is paid to the Village. 
(H)  Costs: If contamination of the Village's water system occurs through an illegal cross connection or improperly installed, maintained, repaired and/or bypassed backflow prevention device, the private water supply system owner must bear the cost of cleanup of the Village's water system. In addition to any other legal remedy to collect such costs, such costs shall constitute a lien on such property which shall be filed by the Village with the recorder of DuPage County. 
(I)  Violations: Remedies for violations of this section, as set forth herein, shall not be deemed exclusive or a limitation upon the authority of the Village to apply the penalty provisions available in section 7-10-28 of this chapter, to such violations. 
(J)  Annual inspection: To the extent permitted by law, the Village reserves the right to make periodic visits to properties or premises with a private water supply system for the purposes of inspection and water sampling. Such spot checks will occur on an annual basis but may occur at random times throughout the year. Reasonable access to properties by the Village for the purposes of inspection and sampling shall not be denied by owners of private water supply systems. 
(K)  Annual report: For a period of three years following the effective date hereof, the Utilities Superintendent shall provide the Village Board of Trustees with an annual report of activities and information related to the number, status and administration of private water supply systems in the Village. 
(Ord. 4247, 4-10-1995; Ord. 5454, 4-10-2006) 
7-10-14. - Wells.
