(A)  Permit: No water well shall be constructed or repaired, except in accordance with the provisions of this Code, regulations prescribed by the health officer and after obtaining a permit therefor from the Village Collector. 
(B)  Application for permit: Applications for a permit for the construction or repair of a well shall be in writing on a form prescribed by the utilities superintendent. 
Each application shall be accompanied by a plat showing the location of all wells, septic tanks, subsurface tile systems and privy vaults constructed, or to be constructed, upon the lot or premises. 
(C)  Prohibited locations: No well shall be constructed or maintained within 75 feet of any septic tank or privy vault, or within ten feet of any tile leading to a septic tank. 
(D)  Construction regulations: The construction or repair of water wells shall be governed by the following: 
1.  The well site shall have good surface drainage and be higher than all sources of pollution, such as septic tanks, subsurface tile systems and privy vaults. 
2.  The well shall be a drilled or driven well, and the casing thereof shall be extra heavy, threaded joint, galvanized iron or steel pipe. If solid rock is encountered, the casing ends at the depth of less than ten feet from the ground surface, there must be a watertight union of the casing with the rock. In case the upper rock stratum consists of creviced limestone to solid rock, the well shall be encased in a concrete envelope or as an alternative, the well shall be encased to a depth of at least 15 feet below the maximum drawdown level when pumping with the pump to be installed or its equivalent, and approved equipment for continuous and adequate chlorination shall be provided. 
3.  A pump pit should be avoided, but if necessary shall be constructed of monolithic, waterproof, reinforced concrete, at least six inches in thickness, and the pump pit cover shall be of watertight construction. The casing top shall extend at least 18 inches above the concrete floor of the pump pit, and no pit drain shall be permitted. If water accumulates in the pit, a concrete sump, with an automatic sump pump with a free fall discharge aboveground, shall be provided. 
4.  The annular opening between the well casing and the drop pipe shall be sealed, either by the casing extending up into a solid base pump, by an oakum and lead seal, or by flanged and bolted fittings. 
(E)  Testing of water: Newly constructed water wells and systems shall be disinfected, and the owners thereof shall have the water analyzed and approved by the department of health of the state before the well is placed in service. It shall also be the duty of the owner or user of the well to have the water therefrom analyzed and approved by the state department of health at regular intervals of not more than 90 days, and a copy of such analysis, together with the original approval, shall be filed with the DuPage County Health Department. The cost of each analysis and report shall be borne by the owner or user of the well. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-15. - Permit application. 
Any person desiring to make any connection with the water system of the Village, or to use the water therefrom, shall first make application to the Village Collector upon such form as may be furnished for that purpose. Each applicant shall state in such application the location of the premises for which such service is sought, the type of improvement thereon and the purposes for which the water is to be used. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-16. - Deposit required. 
(A)  A cash deposit of no less than $150.00 shall be required with each application for service. When service to the applicant is discontinued permanently, this deposit, less any amount due the Village for water service, shall be refunded to the applicant without interest. 
(B)  For the purposes of this section, the shutting off of any water supply for nonpayment of a water bill, or for any other causes due to the fault of the consumer, shall be considered as a permanent discontinuance of such water service; and a new application shall be required before the water service shall be restored. 
(C)  Should any person fail to make the cash deposit required by this section within ten days after a request therefor has been made by the Village, then the Village may terminate all sewer and/or water services to that consumer, and such termination shall be considered as a permanent discontinuance of such water and/or sewer service, thereby requiring a new application before service will be restored. 
(D)  The deposit requirement as identified in subsection (A) of this section shall be waived in the event the applicant applies for, and remains in good standing, participation in the Village's "auto bill pay" program. 
The Management Services Director is hereby authorized to process a refund of deposits held by the Village on behalf of water and sewer customers who participate in the "auto bill pay" payment program. Refunds shall be processed in the form of an account billing credit. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982; Ord. 3284, 1-12-1987, eff. 2-1-1987; Ord. 5148, 3-10-2003; Ord. 5319, 12-20-2004) 
7-10-17. - Permit for service inside corporate limits. 
Where the premises for which water service is sought are located within the Village limits, application to make a connection with the water system shall be referred to the Utilities Superintendent, who, if satisfied that all pertinent requirements of this chapter have been complied with, shall then issue a permit authorizing a connection to be made and specifying the size thereof. No connection shall be made prior to the issuance of such permit. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-18. - Permit for service outside corporate limits. 
Where the premises for which water and sewer services are sought are located outside the Village, permission to make such connections may be granted only by the Village President and Board of Trustees to whom applications must be for both water and sewer services; neither service will be extended without the other. If permission is granted for extension of the water and sewer services, the Village President and Board of Trustees may impose conditions, restrictions or limitations thereon as they deem advisable, and reserve the right to discontinue the services when required to do so by order of a superior authority. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-19. - Water connections. 
All water connections to the Village water supply proposed for any purpose shall be reviewed and approved by the utilities superintendent prior to construction. This work will be performed by the owner at his expense and includes the tapping of the water main, insertion of a corporation cock, installation of service line from the corporation cock to a point seven feet from the property line of the premises being served, at which point a curb stop shall be inserted and a B-box attached in conformance with water division specifications for materials and workmanship. 
(Ord. 3829, 4-22-1991) 
7-10-20. - Installation, maintenance of service pipes. 
(A)  All water service lines from the water main to the premises being served shall be installed by, and at the cost of, either the owner of the premises or the applicant for water service. All service lines, meters and other equipment from the curb stop to and within the premises shall be property of the owner or applicant. Installation of all service pipes shall be made under the supervision and approval of the utilities superintendent, and no service pipes shall be installed unless they are a minimum of one inch in diameter and made of type "K" copper or ductile iron in three inches and larger sizing. No such installation shall be covered until the work has been inspected by the utilities superintendent. 
(B)  Service lines from the curb stop of the water meter of the premises being served shall be kept in good repair at all times, and all repairs to the water pipe shall be made by and at the expense of either the owner of the property or the occupant receiving the service. 
(C)  Water service lines which are abandoned or taken out of service for more than six months shall be disconnected from the water main at the corporation cock by the owner or applicant. All costs incurred for this work, including excavation and restoration, shall be the responsibility of the owner or applicant. 
Service lines that are deficient in size (less than one inch in diameter) or material (such as type "M" copper) shall be replaced from the public main to the structure by the owner of the premises served whenever any one of the following improvements are made to an existing building: 
1.  The existing building floor area is increased by more than 75 percent. 
2.  The existing building exterior roof and wall area is structurally altered by more than 50 percent. 
3.  The existing building is remodeled with a hard cost of more than $100,000.00. 
(D)  Water service lines greater than one inch in diameter shall be installed based on the demand for water use as determined in the Illinois State Plumbing Code for the structure served. 
(E)  An alternative method to design the service line size employing current engineering practices may be used provided the design is approved in writing by an Illinois licensed professional engineer, an Illinois licensed architect or an individual certified in plumbing engineering (CIPE) by the American Society of Plumbing Engineers and approved in writing by the Utilities Superintendent. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998; Ord. 5996, 1-30-2012, eff. 3-1-2012) 
7-10-21. - Compression stops. 
A compression and waste stop shall be attached to every supply pipe entering the building being served. Such compression stop shall be located inside the building at a point where the pipe enters the building so that water may be shut off at that point. No service pipe shall be laid or used to supply water to more than one building. Where two or more meters serve the same building, a lock type compression stop shall be installed ahead of each meter. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-22. - Meters; installation, maintenance. 
(A)  All water furnished to consumers from the water system of the Village shall be supplied through water meters equipped with an outside register. No service line shall have more than one meter. The kind and pattern of such water meters shall be as determined by the utilities superintendent. All water meters shall be sized based on the demand for water use as determined in the Illinois State Plumbing Code for the structure served. All water meters shall be placed inside the building with a conduit installed to the outside location for the outside register wire. The water meter shall be installed in an area making the meter easily accessible for reading, inspection or repair, subject to the review and approval of the utilities superintendent. Accuracy at all flow rates shall meet American Water Works Association (AWWA) standards for water meters of the size and kind approved by the utilities superintendent. No meters shall be installed inside vaults or other areas which are considered a confined space under Illinois Department of Labor Regulations, unless otherwise approved by the Public Works Director. 
(B)  All three-fourths inch and one inch meters shall be installed with a solderless meter holding device which will be supplied by the Village. 
(C)  Where the premises being served is outside the Village limits, a B-box shall be located within the public right-of-way and responsibility for maintenance and repair of the service beyond the B-box shall be the responsibility of the owner of the property or the occupant receiving the service. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998) 
7-10-23. - Access to premises and termination procedures. 
The utilities superintendent, and all persons authorized by him, shall be given ready access to the premises wherein water meters are located for the purpose of reading, examining, testing, repairing, and replacing such meters and appurtenant wires and reading devices; and they may, if necessary, remove or replace meters for such purpose or for testing the consumption, use, and flow of water. Should any person unreasonably refuse to allow entry of a duly authorized representative of the Village for the purpose of reading, examining, testing, repairing, or replacing water meters and appurtenant wires and reading devices, then the Village shall have the right to disconnect and refuse further service to said premises. 
If water meters require removal or replacement and said work cannot be accomplished by the Village due to defects in the interior plumbing of the premises, the owner of said premises shall make the necessary repairs required to allow for the removal or replacement of said water meters. In the event the owner does not complete the required repairs in a reasonable time, as determined by the Utilities Superintendent, then the Village shall have the right to disconnect and refuse further service to said premises until said repairs have been completed. 
(Ord. 4826, 3-27-2000) 
7-10-24. - Interference prohibited. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to interfere with, prevent or obstruct the utilities superintendent, or any authorized person, in the performance of his duties under this chapter. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-25. - Waiver of liability. 
All water connections applied for, and all water used, under this chapter shall be upon the express condition that the Village shall not be liable, nor shall any claim be made against it, for damages or injury caused by reason of the breaking of any main, branch, service pipe, apparatus or appurtenance connected with said water system, or for any interruption of the water supply by reason of the breakage of equipment or machinery or by reason of stoppage, alterations, extensions or renewals. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-26. - Lawn sprinkling. 
It shall be unlawful for any person to sprinkle the lawns of residences or other buildings within the corporate limits of the Village, except in accordance with the following schedule: 
(A)  Odd numbered lots: All persons owning or controlling property bearing an odd numbered street address may sprinkle their lawn on days having an odd numbered calendar date. 
(B)  Even numbered lots: All persons owning or controlling property bearing an even numbered street address may sprinkle their lawn on days having an even numbered calendar date. 
(C)  Hours: The hours of the day when the sprinkling of lawns is permitted shall be governed by the following: 
1.  General hours: Sprinkling shall only be permitted during the hours of 5:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. and 7:00 p.m. to 11:00 p.m., except as otherwise may be limited by action of the President and Board of Trustees pursuant to this section. 
2.  Emergency hours: A majority of the President and Board of Trustees may determine that a water emergency may exist, in which event, the sprinkling of lawns shall only occur between the hours of 6:00 a.m. to 8:00 a.m. and 8:00 p.m. to 10:00 p.m. The determination that a water emergency exists shall be made by the passage and approval of an ordinance declaring such emergency and establishing the period during which emergency lawn sprinkling hours shall exist. 
(D)  Exemptions: The local governmental agencies and private golf courses shall be exempt from the above provisions, but the Village President is hereby given the authority to revoke said exemption in times of emergency. 
(E)  New lawns: Notwithstanding the foregoing, freshly planted or newly seeded lawns may be watered daily between 1:00 p.m. and 4:00 p.m. for a period of 30 days. 
(F)  Penalty: Any person violating the provisions of this section shall be subject to fines of not less than $50.00 for the first offense, not less than $75.00 for the second offense and not less than $100.00 for the third and any succeeding offense. 
(G)  Inspection fee: Every applicant installing a new lawn sprinkler system shall pay an inspection fee in the amount of $50.00. 
(H)  Equipment: Pursuant to 17 Illinois Administrative Code 3730.307(c)(4) and subject to the Illinois Plumbing Code (77 Illinois Administrative Code 890) and the Lawn Irrigation Contractor and Lawn Sprinkler System Registration Code (77 Illinois Administrative Code 892), all new irrigation controllers installed after the effective date hereof shall bear the WaterSense label (as designed by the United States Environmental Protection Agency WaterSense Program), when such labeled fixtures are available. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982; Ord. 3665, 7-24-1989; Ord. 5154, 3-24-2003; Ord. 6488, 3-20-2017) 
7-10-27. - Shutting off service for reasons other than nonpayment of bills. 
When water is furnished to any building, and it is found that: 
(A)  False representations have been made in the application for water service; 
(B)  Water is being used for purposes not set forth in the application; 
(C)  Water is being supplied to persons or buildings other than those for whom the service was introduced; 
(D)  The owner or occupant of the premises being served has failed, after notice, to repair the service pipes or meters; 
(E)  Employees of the Water Division, or anyone duly authorized, has been denied access to the premises for the purpose of examining pipes, meter or connections with the water supply system; or 
(F)  The water meter has been tampered with or the proper recording of the water furnished to the premises has been otherwise unlawfully interfered with. 
The Utilities Superintendent shall have, and is hereby given, authority to promptly shut off the supply of water to such building or premises until proper application is made or the defaults corrected and such additional sum of money paid to the Village Collector as shall be found due for water therefor furnished. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-28. - General penalty. 
Any person, firm or corporation violating any provision of this chapter shall be fined in a sum not to exceed $500.00 for each offense. Each day that a violation continues shall constitute a separate offense. 
(Ord. 2732, 2-22-1982) 
7-10-29. - Cross connection control regulations. 
(A)  All plumbing installed within the Village of Glen Ellyn shall be installed in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code, 77 Illinois Administrative Code 890. That, if in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code or in the judgment of the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, an approved backflow prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water supply system, the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, will give notice to the water customer to install such an approved device immediately. The water customer shall, at his own expense, install such an approved device at a location and in a manner in accordance with the Illinois Plumbing Code and all applicable local regulations, and shall have inspections tests, and maintenance performed to such approved devices upon installation and as required by the Illinois Plumbing Code and local regulations. 
(B)  No person, firm or corporation shall establish or permit to be established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a private, auxiliary or emergency water supply other than the regular public water supply of the Village of Glen Ellyn enter the supply or distribution system of said Municipality, unless such private, auxiliary or emergency water supply and the method of connection and use of such supply shall have been approved by the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, and the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency. 
(C)  It shall be the duty of the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, to cause surveys, inspections, and/or investigations to be made of commercial, industrial and other properties served by the public water supply to determine whether actual or potential hazards to the public water supply may exist. Such surveys, inspections, and/or investigations shall be made a matter of public record and shall be repeated at least every two years, or more often as the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, shall deem necessary. Records of such surveys shall be maintained and available for review for a period of at least five years. 
(D)  After reasonable notice, the approved cross connection control device inspector shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the Village of Glen Ellyn for the purpose of verifying the presence or absence of cross connections, and that after reasonable notice the Utilities Superintendent or his authorized agent shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply or distribution system of the Village of Glen Ellyn for the purpose of verifying information submitted by the customer regarding the required cross connection control inspection. On demand the owner, lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, any information, which he may request regarding the piping system or systems or water use on such property. The refusal of such information, when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, be deemed evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in this section. 
(E)  The Public Works Director, or his /her representative, of the Village of Glen Ellyn is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue, after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of this section is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of the public water supply distribution mains. Water service to such property shall not be restored until such conditions have been eliminated or corrected in compliance with the provisions of this section, and until a minimum reconnection fee of $100.00 is paid to the Village of Glen Ellyn. Immediate disconnection with verbal notice can be effected when the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, is assured that imminent danger of harmful contamination of the public water supply system exists. Such action shall be followed by written notification of the cause of disconnection. Immediate disconnection without notice to any party can be effected to prevent actual or anticipated contamination or pollution of the public water supply, provided that, in the reasonable opinion of the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, or the Illinois Environmental Protection Agency, such action is required to prevent actual or potential contamination or pollution of the public water supply. Neither the public water supply, the Public Works Director, or his /her representative, or its agents or assigns shall be liable to any customer for any injury, damages or lost revenues which may result from termination of said customer's water supply in accordance with the terms of this section, whether or not said termination was with or without notice. 
(F)  The customer responsible for back siphoned material or contamination through backflow, if contamination of the potable water supply system occurs through an illegal cross connection or an improperly installed, maintained or repaired device, or a device which has been bypassed, must bear the cost of cleanup of the potable water supply system. 
(Ord. 6214, 2-10-2014) 
Chapter 11 - WATER AND SEWER RATES AND CHARGES 

7-11-1. - Definitions. 
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of the terms used herein shall be the same as defined in section 7-9-1 of this title. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986) 
7-11-2. - Metering required. 
(A)  As required by section 7-10-22 of this title, all water furnished to consumers from the water system of the Village shall be supplied through meters only, except for water used in construction work. 
(B)  If a person discharging wastes into the public sewers procures any part or all of his water from sources other than the Village public waterworks system, all or a part of which is discharged into the public sewers, that person shall install and maintain, at his own expense, water meters of a type approved by the Director for the purpose of determining the volume of water obtained from these other sources. 
(C)  If in the opinion of the Director, the volume of wastewater cannot otherwise be determined from the metered water consumption, he may require devices for measuring the volume of waste discharged into the public sewers. 
(D)  Should wastewater metering devices be required to determine the volume of waste discharged into the public sewers, such metering device shall be installed, owned and maintained by the person discharging wastewater into the public sewers. Following approval and installation, such meters may not be removed without the consent of the Director, unless service is first cancelled. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986) 
7-11-3. - Water for construction purposes. 
(A)  Any person desiring to use water from the water system of the Village during construction pursuant to a validly issued building permit, before a water meter is installed for the premises, will be permitted to do so by making application therefor to the Village. Such construction water permit shall be granted and the water furnished, only upon the conditions that the construction work proceed with all reasonable dispatch, and that a meter be installed as soon as the foundation of the premises under construction has been completed. Until such permanent meter has been installed, the applicant shall pay, in advance, the flat fee established in subsection (B) of this section for all water to be consumed within three months from the date of the permit; and if the permanent meter has not been installed before the expiration of the three months, an additional flat fee per quarter, or part thereof, shall be paid in advance for all water consumed. Water during construction shall not be provided at a location for longer than one year. After the installation of the permanent meter, all water shall be charged and paid for, at the rates provided in this chapter. 
(B)  The flat fee for water consumed during construction shall be based upon the area of the proposed addition or building at the rate of $2.00 per 100 square feet of building or addition, per quarter. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986) 
7-11-4. - Responsibility for charges. 
(A)  Where water or sewer services are provided, directly or indirectly, to any premises, the owner, tenant or occupant of those premises and/or the user of any water or sewer service shall be considered to be a customer of the Village and shall be jointly and severally liable to pay for the services to such premises. Water and/or sewer services are furnished to premises by the Village only upon the condition that the owner of the premises, tenant or occupant thereof and user of the services are jointly and severally liable therefor to the Village. 
(B)  Where water or sewer services are provided to any premises through another municipal corporation or through a private utility regulated by the Illinois Commerce Commission, the other municipal corporation or private utility shall also be liable to the Village for all water or sewer services furnished by the Village for premises served by the other municipal corporation or by the private utility. 
(Ord. 3572, 1-23-1989, eff. 2-1-1989) 
7-11-5. - Charges based upon meter reading. 
Unless otherwise specifically provided herein all fees and charges for water and/or sewer services shall be based upon the flow registered by a water or wastewater flow meter, and no reduction shall be made or rebate allowed, on account of leakage into or from any pipe, tank or other apparatus. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986) 
7-11-6. - Procedure for change in occupancy. 
In the event an owner, tenant or occupant of any premises served by the Village sells or vacates the premises served, he shall notify the Village prior to his selling or vacating the premises. A final bill shall be rendered, which bill shall be due immediately upon receipt. The Village may discontinue service to a premises upon rendering a final bill. When the new owner, new tenant or new occupant acquires or occupies such premises, he shall notify the Village of his desire to have service and make application for service. Any person who is moving to another property which receives water or sewer service from the Village shall not receive water service until the final bill from his previous ownership or occupancy shall have been paid in full. 
(Ord. 3572, 1-23-1989, eff. 2-1-1989) 
7-11-7. - Reading meters. 
(A)  Within constitutional limits, duly authorized representatives of the Village shall have the right to enter, at any reasonable hour, any building, structure or premises which directly or indirectly receives water or sewer services from the Village for the purpose of reading any water or wastewater flow meter. Should any person unreasonably refuse to allow entry of a duly authorized representative of the Village for the purpose of reading a water or wastewater flow meter, then the Village shall have the right to disconnect and refuse further service to said premises. 
(B)  Where another municipal corporation or private utility renders a bill based upon metered flow of water or wastewater to a user of the Village's water and/or sewer service and directly or indirectly uses the Village's water or sewer services to service its customers, then at the request of the Village such municipal corporation or private utility shall certify on a monthly basis to the Village the following information: 
1.  A listing of all water meter readings taken during the previous month; 
2.  The number of individual users, the amount of water flow recorded by each user's meter, an estimate of the water flow through those meters that were not read, an estimate for any nonmetered users, and the total flow, including both metered and nonmetered users; 
3.  Where the municipal corporation or private utility bills one or more of its customers on the basis of wastewater flow, a listing of all wastewater flow meter readings taken and the total flow through said meters, with estimates where a meter reading is not available; 
4.  A list of all locations where service was discontinued, where service was turned on, and/or where new meters were installed; and 
5.  Such other information requested by the Village and pertaining to water flow, wastewater flow or use of the Village's water and/or sewer services. 
(C)  Where the customer is another municipal corporation or private utility, then the Village shall have the right, at all reasonable hours, to audit the books and records of such customer as they pertain to any aspect of meter flow or wastewater flow of such customer or of its end users or customers. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986; Ord. 3572, 1-23-1989, eff. 2-1-1989) 
7-11-8. - Billing frequency. 
(A)  Bills for water and sewer service directly provided to a premises by the Village shall be rendered to the customer monthly. 
(B)  Monthly bills shall be due and payable 20 days after being mailed to the customer. 
(Ord. 4409, 8-26-1996) 
7-11-9. - Estimated bills. 
(A)  Monthly bills will be based upon actual readings whenever possible. If an actual meter reading cannot be obtained for any reason, then an estimated bill will be produced. Adjustments shall be made on the next succeeding bill after an actual meter reading is available to the Village. 
(B)  Each consumer has the obligation to arrange for access to its billing meter for the purpose of allowing the same to be read by the Village as part of the normal route of the person reading meters. Should access to the building or buildings housing any billing meter be inconvenient for any reason, then the Village may require the person receiving sewer and/or water service to provide a meter capable of being read externally of the building housing the meter, at the sole cost and expense of the consumer. 
(C)  Should the Village be unable to obtain access to billing meter for the purpose of reading the same for one year, then the Village may terminate service to that customer. 
(Ord. 3284, 1-12-1987, eff. 2-1-1987; Ord. 3829, 4-22-1991; Ord. 4409, 8-26-1996) 
7-11-10. - Meter failures. 
Whenever any water or sewer flow meter fails to properly register the water or sewage passing through it, the consumer shall be charged with the amount billed for a corresponding time for the previous year. If no record of the previous year exists, then the amount of water consumed or sewage introduced into the public sewer during the time such meter failed to register shall be estimated by the Village, and the consumer shall pay for the amount so estimated. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-11. - Notices. 
All bills and notices herein provided for may be delivered or served in person or by mail, addressed to the customer or other person liable for the charges, at the last known address contained in the records of the Village. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986) 
7-11-12. - Revenues. 
All revenues and monies derived from the collection of water and sewer rates and charges shall be deposited in an appropriate fund as determined by the Village. All such revenues and monies shall be held by the management services Director and all of said sum, without any deductions whatever, shall be delivered to the management services Director not more than ten days after receipt of the same, or at such more frequent intervals as may from time to time be directed by the President and Board of Trustees. The management services Director shall receive all revenues from the user charge system and all funds and monies incident to the operation of the waterworks and sewage system as the same may be delivered to him and deposit the same in an appropriate fund. The funds shall be administered in every respect in the manner provided by statute. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-13. - Accounts. 
The management services Director shall establish a proper system of accounts and shall keep proper books, records and accounts in which complete and correct entries shall be made of all transactions relative to the user charge system, and at regular annual intervals he shall cause to be made an audit by an independent auditing concern of the books to show the receipts and disbursements of the user charge system. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-14. - Outside readers. 
In cases where the inside meter and outside reader do not agree, the customer shall be charged with the amount billed for a corresponding time the previous year. If no record of the previous year exists, then the amount of water consumed or sewage introduced into the public sewer during the time of discrepancy shall be estimated by the Village, and the customer shall pay for the amount so estimated. The account may be adjusted to forgive the remaining difference between an erroneous outside reader and actual inside meter on a one time only basis. After an adjustment is made and the reader and meter adjusted, all water passing through the inside meter will be billed to the customer, and the amount on the inside meter will control the amount that will be billed. 
(Ord. 4409, 8-26-1996) 
7-11-15. - Meter testing. 
If a meter is pulled for testing at the request of the customer and found to be in good working order, the cost of the replacement meter will be charged to the water account. 
(Ord. 4243, 3-27-1995, eff. 5-1-1995) 
7-11-16. - Penalty. 
All accounts will be penalized ten percent of the current amount if not paid on or before the due date. The penalty may be waived once every 12 months, effective May 1, 1995. 
(Ord. 4243, 3-27-1995, eff. 5-1-1995) 
7-11-17. - Delinquency and termination of service. 
(A)  In the event that charges for water and/or sewer services are not paid within the time specified in section 7-11-8 of this chapter, a past due notice will be included with the next monthly bill. If the bill continues to be unpaid ten days after the issuance of the next monthly bill, a final notice will be mailed to the delinquent customer. This notice shall indicate that if the bill is not paid within ten days, or other arrangements have not been made with the Village, service will be terminated. 
(B)  On those occasions where it becomes necessary to terminate service provided directly to a premises by the Village, then the direct customer shall be required to pay a $40.00 service fee for termination of services in addition to payment of all delinquent bills. 
(C)  On those occasions where it becomes necessary to terminate service to a municipal corporation or private utility where services are provided indirectly to the end users of such municipal corporation or private utility, then the municipal corporation or private utility shall be required to pay any and all costs incurred by the Village in terminating service, including reasonable compensation for staff time and out of pocket expenses, in addition to payment of all delinquent bills. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986; amd. Ord. 4677, 1-25-1999)(Ord. 4409, 8-26-1996) 
7-11-18. - No service to delinquent customers. 
No consumer owing water and/or sewer charges who moves to other premises where there are water and sewer connections, or where such connections shall afterwards be made, shall be supplied with water or sewer services until delinquent charges are satisfied. Further, should service be terminated for nonpayment of bills, service will not thereafter be supplied until all delinquent charges, including termination charges and late penalties, are satisfied. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-19. - Lien for charges. 
In the event water and/or sewer charges are not paid within the time specified in section 7-11-8 of this chapter, after the mailing of the bill for services, such charges shall be deemed delinquent and such delinquency shall constitute a lien upon the real estate to which the service was provided. The Village Clerk shall file a sworn statement showing such delinquency in the office of the County Recorder of Deeds, in the manner provided by statute. The filing of a statement of delinquency shall be deemed notice and demand for the payment of this delinquency. 
(Ord. 3572, 1-23-1989, eff. 2-1-1989) 
7-11-20. - Reserved. 
7-11-21. - Right to change rates. 
Nothing herein shall prohibit the Village from amending the provisions of this chapter, and it shall retain authority to improve the water system, sewage system or wastewater treatment facilities or any part or portion thereof, and to establish new or different rates, regulations or provisions concerning the use of the Village water and sewer service. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-22. - Filing rates. 
A copy of water and sewer charges set forth in this chapter, and as amended from time to time, shall be certified by the Village Clerk and filed in the office of the County Recorder of Deeds. The filing of these charges shall be notice to an owner of real estate of his liability for the service supplied by the Village through its combined waterworks and sewage system. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-23. - Combined water and sewer system. 
Pursuant to the powers granted in 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5/11-139-1 et seq., the Village has heretofore elected to operate its waterworks and the sewage system as a combined waterworks and sewage system. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-24. - Basis for water service charges. 
The charge for water service shall consist of a fixed demand charge and a variable charge as follows: 
(A)  Fixed demand charge: The fixed demand charge takes into consideration the cost of providing peak demand capacity for the waterworks system and is dependent upon the size of meter servicing the premises and the use of the premises served by the waterworks. 
(B)  Variable charge: The variable charge shall be based upon water usage as recorded by water meters. 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986) 
7-11-25. - Basis for sewer collection and wastewater service charges. 
The charge for sewer services shall consist of a fixed charge for sewer only users, a variable charge for all users and a surcharge dependent upon the concentration of wastes discharged to the sewer system, as follows: 
(A)  Fixed demand: The fixed charge takes into consideration the billing, collection and related administrative costs for sewer only users with such costs for combined water and sewer users being incorporated into the fixed charge for water. Where the Village bills an intermediate user for sewer only service, the fixed charge shall be charged and paid for each end user. 
(B)  Variable charge: The variable charge shall be based upon water usage as recorded by water meters, unless metering of water is impractical, as determined by the Village, in which event the variable charge shall be based on wastewater flows measured by a wastewater flow meter. The variable charge is based upon the wastewater having normal concentrations (as measured as close as possible to the point of discharge to the sewage collection system) as follows: 
1.  A five-day, 20 degree Centigrade biochemical oxygen demand (BOD) of 295 milligrams per liter, and 
2.  A suspended solids (SS) content of 295 milligrams per liter. 
The variable charge is dependent upon the operation and maintenance costs plus replacement costs for the sanitary sewer system, including the Village's proportionate share of the Glenbard Wastewater Authority expenses. 
(C)  Surcharge: A surcharge will be levied to all users whose waters exceed the normal concentrations of BOD 295 milligrams per liter and SS 295 milligrams per liter. The surcharge will be based upon water usage as recorded by a water meter and/or sewage flow meter for all wastes which exceed the normal concentration for either BOD or SS, respectively. The procedure for computing a surcharge is set forth in subsection (D) of this section. 
(D)  Computation of surcharge: The concentration of waste used for computing surcharges shall be established by waste sampling and analyses in conformance with "standard methods". Waste sampling shall be performed as often as may be deemed necessary by the Public Works Director and shall be binding as a basis for surcharges. 
The amount of the surcharge for each billing period shall be computed as follows: 
CS = [(B-Bb) Rb + (S-Sb) Rs] F Where: CS       = Surcharge payment in dollars B       = BOD 5 established by sampling and analysis Bb       = BOD 5 base above which the surcharge applies Rb       = Rate for excess BOD 5 in dollars S       = Suspended solids established by sampling and analysis Sb       = Suspended solids base above which the surcharge applies Rs       = Rate for excess suspended solids in dollars F       = Flow during billing period measured in thousands of gallons  
  
(E)  Computation of wastewater service charge: The wastewater service charge shall be computed by the following formula: 
CW = CF + Q (CV) + CS Where: CW       = Amount of wastewater service charge ($) per billing period CF       = Fixed charge Q       = Water consumption or wastewater volume for the billing period CV       = Variable charge for collection and treatment system CS       = Amount of surcharge  
  
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982; Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986; Ord. 3572, 1-23-1989, eff. 2-1-1989) 
7-11-26. - Measurement of flow. 
The volume of flow used for computing the variable charges or surcharges for the water and sewer service rates shall be the metered water consumption or wastewater flow read to the lowest even increments of 1,000 gallons. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
7-11-27. - Classes of service. 
There shall be two classes of service based upon usage: "residential users" and all "other users", defined as follows: 
(A)  Residential users: Shall include all single-family, multi-family, townhouse or other residential premises where the primary occupancy of the premises is for residential purposes and the premises is served by a separate meter having a size of one inch or less. 
(B)  Other users: Shall include all other water or sewer services that do not fall within the definition of "residential users". 
(Ord. 3168, 1-27-1986, eff. 3-1-1986) 
7-11-28. - Water and sewer rates and charges. 
The rates and charges for the use and services supplied by the combined waterworks and sewage systems of the Village are as follows: 
Effective with bills issued January 1, 2018 Within Village  Water $9.93 per 1,000 gallons  Sewer $7.18 per 1,000 gallons Outside Village  Water $14.87 per 1,000 gallons  Sewer $7.55 per 1,000 gallons  Sewer only $7.55 per 1,000 gallons + $3.25 per month service fee  Non-metered Sewer $45.30  
    In addition, all sewer customers of the Village shall be assessed a flat monthly Drainage Reimbursement Fee of $3.00 for the purpose of funding stormwater improvements and maintenance, the sewer repair reimbursement program, and the clear water removal program. 
(Ord. 6468, 12-12-2016; Ord. 6561, 11-13-2017; Ord. 6687, 4-8-2019) 
7-11-29. - Minimum bill. 
The minimum water bill shall be two times the rate per 1,000 gallons of consumption and shall include the use of up to 2,000 gallons of water. Sewer shall be billed upon actual water consumption for water and sewer customers. 
(Ord. 4409, 8-26-1996) 
7-11-30. - Water connection fees. 
All connections to the water mains shall be made upon the following conditions and subject to the following charges: 
(A)  Service line size; fee: A water connection fee shall depend upon the size of the customer service lines as follows: 
Water Service Size       Connection Fee 
3/4 inch diameter ..... $450.00 
1 inch diameter ..... 800.00 
11/4 inch diameter ..... 1,250.00 
11/2 inch diameter ..... 1,800.00 
2 inch diameter ..... 3,200.00 
3 inch diameter ..... 7,200.00 
4 inch diameter ..... 12,800.00 
6 inch diameter ..... 28,800.00 
The service line size shall be determined in accordance with the Illinois State Plumbing Code. The water flow requirement for fire sprinklers shall not be included when calculating the connection charge. 
(B)  Multiple-family homes; multiple commercial units: Multiple-family homes and multiple commercial units connected to one service line shall pay $400.00 for each additional unit more than one served by the connection. Provided, however, that for any permits issued between April 13, 1998 and December 1, 1998, the connection fee payable under this subsection and subsection (A) of this section for multiple-family homes shall not exceed $60,000.00 without regard to the number of multiple-family homes served by a single connection. 
(C)  Work performed: All work performed by owners shall be in accordance with the State of Illinois Plumbing Code. At least 24 hours' advance notice shall be given to the Village before any water service line work is undertaken. 
(D)  Inspection fees: An inspection fee for the connection, repair, replacement or disconnection of any water service line shall be in the amount of $100.00. Subsequent inspections required due to failure of final inspection shall be charged at $50.00 per inspection. 
(Ord. 4581, 4-13-1998, eff. 5-1-1998; Ord. 5154, 3-24-2003) 
7-11-31. - New subdivisions and annexed land. 
(A)  Connection fee: All persons subdividing or annexing any lot, block, tract or parcel of land of more than one acre which is not serviced by the Village water and sewage system and which has not been previously assessed for such service shall pay, in addition to any and all other charges, a fee of $1,000.00 per acre for connecting the land so subdivided or annexed to the Village water and sewerage system. 
(B)  Less than one acre: All persons subdividing or annexing any lot, block, tract or parcel of land of less than one acre which is not serviced by the Village water and sewage system and which has not been previously assessed for such service shall pay, in addition to any and all other charges, a fee of $250.00 for each residence site to be connected to the Village water and sewage system. 
(C)  Land previously assessed: If the land so subdivided or annexed, as provided in subsections (A) and (B) of this section, has been previously assessed for either water or sewer service, then upon the approval of the plat of subdivision, resubdivision or annexation by the Board of Trustees, it will be assessed the sum of $500.00 per acre or $125.00 per residence site, whichever is smaller, for connecting to the service for which the land was not heretofore assessed. 
(D)  Land involuntarily annexed: By resolution, the Village Board may authorize an extension of time up to and including 20 years from the date of annexation for owners of property involuntarily annexed to connect to the Village water and sewage system and pay the required connection fees and charges upon a finding that such relief is warranted by the circumstances and will not adversely affect the public health and welfare. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982; Ord. 4075, 12-20-1993) 
7-11-32. - Sewer connection fees within the corporate limits. 
No permit allowing use of the Village sewer system, including the Village's portion of the POTW, by a property within the Village corporate limits shall be issued until the following fees are paid in full: 
Sanitary Sewers Residential:  Single-family $1,000.00 Village connection fee plus $278.00 per PE (population equivalent), which will be collected by the Village and passed on to the Glenbard Wastewater Authority.  Multi-family: $1,000.00 plus $278.00 per PE (population equivalent), as described above. Nonresidential: $1,000.00 plus $278.00 per PE (population equivalent), as described above. An additional charge of $400.00 shall be paid for each multiple-family or nonresidential unit more than 1 served by a single sanitary sewer connection. Inspection fee: An inspection fee for the connection, repair, replacement or disconnection of any sanitary service line shall be in the amount of $100.00. Storm Sewers Inspection fee: An inspection fee for the connection, repair, replacement or disconnection of any storm sewer service line shall be in the amount of $100.00.  
(Ord. 5154, 3-24-2003) 
7-11-33. - Sewer connection fees beyond the corporate limits. 
No permit allowing use of the Village sewer system, including the Village's portion of the POTW, by a property beyond the Village corporate limits shall be issued until the following fees are paid in full: 
Sanitary Sewers Residential: $1,000.00 Village connection fee plus $278.00 per PE (population equivalent), which will be collected by the Village and passed on to the Glenbard Wastewater Authority. Nonresidential: $1,000.00 plus $278.00 per PE (population equivalent), as described above. An additional charge of $400.00 shall be paid for each multiple-family or nonresidential unit more than 1 served by a single sanitary sewer connection. Inspection fee: An inspection fee for the connection, repair, replacement or disconnection of any sanitary service line shall be in the amount of $100.00. Storm Sewers Inspection fee: An inspection fee for the connection, repair, replacement or disconnection of any storm sewer service line shall be in the amount of $100.00.  
(Ord. 5154, 3-24-2003) 
7-11-34. - Annexation fee. 
When a property has paid the fees set forth in section 7-11-33 of this chapter, the property shall receive credit on the annexation fee for the sum so paid when the property is annexed to the Village. 
(Ord. 2733, 2-22-1982, eff. 5-1-1982) 
Chapter 12 - WEED CONTROL CODE 

7-12-1. - Short title. 
This chapter of this Code shall be known as and may be called as the Weed Control Code of Glen Ellyn. 
(Ord. 3133, 7-22-1985) 
7-12-2. - Definitions. 
Unless the context specifically indicates otherwise, the meanings of the terms used in this chapter shall be as follows: 
PROPERTY: Any real property within the Village. 
WEED: Any uncultivated plant. 
(Ord. 3133, 7-22-1985) 
7-12-3. - Growth of weeds over certain height prohibited. 
Every owner of property within the Village shall cut, chemically treat or otherwise destroy the weeds on his property at all times necessary to prevent the weeds from exceeding eight inches. 
(Ord. 3133, 7-22-1985) 
7-12-4. - Village's right to destroy overgrown weeds. 
If any owner neglects or refuses to cut, chemically treat or otherwise destroy the weeds on his property, the Village may do so, or contract with any other person to perform the services under the authority of the Village. 
(Ord. 3133, 7-22-1985) 
7-12-5. - Collection of expenses from property owner. 
If any property owner neglects or refuses to cut, chemically treat or otherwise destroy the weeds on his property and the Village has elected to do so under the provisions of this chapter, then the owner shall pay to the Village its expenses incurred in cutting or destroying the weeds, including a reasonable amount for services performed by Village employees or for use of Village equipment. If any owner fails or refuses to reimburse the Village for expenses incurred, including reasonable administrative costs in destroying weeds on the owner's property, the Village may collect such amount in an action at law. 
(Ord. 3133, 7-22-1985) 
7-12-6. - Annual publication of notice. 
In the spring of each year, the Village Administrator shall cause to be published in a newspaper of general circulation in the Village a notice setting forth the provisions of this chapter. This publication shall be undertaken one time, and no further notice shall be required before the Village may undertake any weed cutting or destruction, if necessary, following the publication of the notice. 
(Ord. 3133, 7-22-1985) 
Chapter 13 - ANTILITTERING CODE 

7-13-1. - Short title. 
This chapter shall be known as and may be cited as the Village of Glen Ellyn Antilittering Code. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-2. - Purposes. 
The purpose of this chapter is to: 
(A)  Define, prevent and abate littering within the Village as a nuisance; 
(B)  Promote the public health by preventing and abating the accumulation of litter, garbage, refuse, rubbish and debris on the public streets, alleys, sidewalks and upon other public and private property; and 
(C)  Prevent and abate the unwanted and possibly destructive placement of litter, including commercial handbills, upon vehicles, the public streets and other public property and upon private property when and where it is not desired by the owner of such private property. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-3. - Definitions. 
Unless otherwise expressly stated or the context clearly indicates a different sense, the following terms shall, for the purpose of this chapter, have the meanings indicated in this section: 
AIRCRAFT: Any contrivance now known or hereafter invented, used or designated for navigation or for flight in the air. The word "aircraft" shall include helicopters and lighter than air dirigibles and balloons. 
AUTHORIZED PRIVATE RECEPTACLE: A container as required and authorized in chapter 6 of this title. 
COMMERCIAL HANDBILL: Any handbill which: 
(A)  Advertises for sale or rent any merchandise, product, commodity or service or any other business activity; or 
(B)  Directs attention to any business or commercial establishment or other activity for the purpose of either directly or indirectly promoting sales; or 
(C)  Directs attention to or advertises any meeting, theatrical performance, exhibition or event of any kind for which an admission fee will be charged unless such event is being sponsored by a not for profit organization. 
(D)  A handbill containing a religious, political or other nonbusiness related message shall not be considered a commercial handbill. (See also definition of Handbill.) 
CONTAINER: 
(A)  A "reusable container" is a receptacle made of plastic, metal, or fiberglass with a capacity not to exceed 32 gallons, a loaded weight of no more than 35 pounds, a tightfitting lid, and handles of adequate strength for lifting; 
(B)  A "nonreusable container" is a bag made of plastic with sufficient wall strength to maintain physical integrity when lifted by the top. 
DISTRIBUTE: Give to a person or place upon, affix or attach to any part of a building, structure or vehicle. 
GARBAGE: Putrescible animal and vegetable waste resulting from the handling, preparation, cooking, serving or consumption of food and including food containers. 
HANDBILL: Any printed or written matter, sample or device, circular, leaflet, pamphlet, paper, booklet or any other manner of literature with the purpose of making an announcement or otherwise communicating a message, but does not include a newspaper or similar publication. (See also definition of Commercial Handbill.) 
LITTER: "Garbage", "refuse", "rubbish", "commercial handbills" and "newspapers", as defined herein and all other waste material of any kind which if thrown or deposited as herein prohibited tends to create a danger to public health, safety and welfare. 
NEWSPAPER: Any newspaper of general circulation as defined by general law, any newspaper duly entered with the post office department of the United States, in accordance with federal statute or regulation, and any newspaper filed and recorded with any recording officer as provided by general law; and in addition thereto, shall mean and include any periodical or current magazine regularly published with not less than four issued per year, and sold to the public. 
PARK: A park, reservation, playground, beach, recreation center or any other public area in the Village, owned or used by the Village and devoted to active or passive recreation. 
PRIVATE PROPERTY OR PREMISES: Any real estate, including any building or other improvement which may be on it, that is owned or controlled by any private person, corporation or entity, whether or not such property is open to the public. 
PUBLIC PROPERTY OR PLACE: Any street, sidewalk, parking lot, parkway, plaza, building or other place owned or controlled by the Village of Glen Ellyn or other governmental body that is open to the public. 
REFUSE: All putrescible and nonputrescible solid waste, except body waste, including garbage, rubbish, ashes, street cleaning debris, dead animals, abandoned automobiles, solid market, and industrial wastes, in a solid or semiliquid state, and in any combination. 
RUBBISH: Nonputrescible solid waste consisting of both combustible and noncombustible wastes, such as paper, wrappings, cigarettes, cardBoard, tin cans, yard clippings, leaves, wood, glass, bedding, crockery and similar materials, including yard and garden waste. 
VEHICLE: Every device in, upon, or by which any person or property is or may be transported or drawn upon a highway, including devices used exclusively upon stationary rails or tracks. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-4. - Principles of construction. 
This chapter shall be construed and applied in accordance with the following principles: 
(A)  Words imparting the singular number may extend to and include plural, words imparting the plural number may extend to and include the singular, and words in the masculine gender shall include the female gender; 
(B)  The word "shall" is always mandatory and not merely Directory; and 
(C)  The specifications in this section of principles shall not be a limitation to other accepted principles of statutory and ordinance construction. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-5. - Litter in public places prohibited. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter or newspapers in any public place within the Village except in public trash receptacles and in such a manner that the litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any part of any park or upon any street or other public place. Where public trash receptacles are not provided, all such litter shall be carried away from the park, street or public place by the person responsible for its presence and properly disposed of elsewhere, as provided herein. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-6. - Placement of litter in receptacles so as to prevent scattering. 
Persons placing litter in public trash receptacles or in authorized private receptacles shall do so in such a manner as to prevent such litter from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk or other public place or upon any private premises. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-7. - Sweeping litter into gutters prohibited. 
No person shall sweep into or deposit in any gutter, street or other public place within the Village, the accumulation of litter from any building or lot or from any public or private sidewalk or driveway. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-8. - Duty to keep sidewalks free of litter. 
Owners, occupants and/or operators of private premises within the Village shall keep the sidewalk in front of those private premises free of litter. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-9. - Litter thrown by persons in vehicles. 
No person while a driver of or a passenger in a vehicle shall throw or deposit litter upon any street or other public place within the Village, or upon private premises. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-10. - Truckloads causing litter. 
No person shall drive or move any truck or other vehicle within the Village unless such vehicle is so constructed and/or loaded as to prevent any load, contents or litter from being blown or deposited upon any street, alley or other public place. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-11. - Dropping litter from aircraft. 
No person in an aircraft shall throw out, drop or deposit within the Village any litter, handbill or any other object, nor shall any person knowingly authorize another person to throw out, drop or deposit from an aircraft any litter, handbill or other object. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-12. - Litter in lakes and fountains. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter in any fountain, pond, lake, stream, river or any other body of water within the Village. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987) 
7-13-13. - Distributing handbills. 
(A)  Public property: No person shall distribute any commercial handbill from or on any public street, sidewalk or other public property. 
(B)  Private property: No person shall distribute any handbill from or on any private property without permission from the owner or other person in control of such property. A conspicuous notice posted by the person in control of the property indicating that distribution of handbills is prohibited shall constitute denial of permission to distribute handbills upon the property. 
(C)  Vehicles: No person shall affix, attach or in any way place any handbill on any vehicle which is on any public street or Village owned parking lot nor on any vehicle which is on any private property without permission from the owner of the property. 
(D)  Streets: No person shall distribute any handbill while standing in the traveled portion of any street. 
(Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-14. - Discarding handbills. 
No person in possession of any handbill shall discard it upon any public or private property except in a proper waste receptacle. Any person who distributes any handbill in any public or private place shall collect any such handbill found littering any such place and dispose of it in a proper waste receptacle. 
(Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-15. - Delivery of mail and newspapers. 
(A)  Delivery of mail: The provisions of this chapter shall not apply to the distribution of mail by the United States. 
(B)  Delivery of newspapers: The provisions of this chapter shall not prohibit the delivery of a "newspaper", as defined in section 7-13-3 of this chapter, to private premises or public buildings, provided, however, that the newspaper shall be placed on the private premises or public building to which it is intended to be delivered or on that portion of the public street adjacent thereto and which is not occupied by sidewalk, curb, gutter, drainage facility, ditch or street pavement and shall be placed in such a manner as to prevent it from being carried or deposited by the elements onto any private premises or public building, other than where it was placed, or onto the sidewalk, curb, gutter, drainage facility, ditch or street pavement. All newspapers, as defined in section 7-13-3 of this chapter, placed for delivery on a public place and not removed within 12 hours of their placement shall be removed from the public place by the distributor or publisher of the newspaper, or the agent of either. A "newspaper", as defined in section 7-13-3 of this chapter, found in a public place at a location not permitted by this chapter shall be presumed to have been delivered in violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-16. - Responsibility for handbill and newspaper distribution. 
(A)  Any person for whose benefit a "commercial handbill" or "newspaper", both as defined in section 7-13-3 of this chapter, is distributed, including any advertiser named in a handbill, or the publisher or the distribution agent of any handbill or newspaper shall be responsible for the proper distribution of the handbill or newspaper. 
(B)  No person shall knowingly authorize or allow another person to distribute a "commercial handbill" or "newspaper", both as defined in section 7-13-3 of this chapter, in violation of the provisions of this chapter. 
(C)  Any "handbill" or "newspaper", both as defined in section 7-13-3 of this chapter, distributed within the Village shall be presumed to be distributed in a manner authorized or allowed by the advertisers or publishers named in the handbill or by the publisher named in the newspaper. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-17. - Posting notices prohibited. 
No person shall post, affix or fasten in any way any notice, poster, or paper or other device, calculated to attract the attention of the public, to any lamppost, public utility pole or shade tree in the public right-of-way or upon any public structure or public building, except as may be authorized or required by law. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-18. - Litter on occupied private premises. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter on any occupied private premises within the Village, whether owned by such person or not, except that the owner or person in control of private premises may maintain authorized private receptacles for collection in such a manner that litter will be prevented from being carried or deposited by the elements upon any street, sidewalk, other public place or upon any other private premises. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-19. - Owner to maintain premises free of litter. 
The owner or person in control of any private premises shall at all times maintain the premises free of accumulated litter, provided, however, that this section shall not prohibit the storage of litter in authorized private receptacles for collection nor prevent the maintenance of a compost pile for personal use and in an inoffensive manner, with the compost only consisting of yard clippings and leaves. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-20. - Litter on vacant lots. 
No person shall throw or deposit litter on any open or vacant private premises within the Village whether owned by such person or not. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
7-13-21. - Public notices of the village. 
(A)  The provisions of this chapter shall not prohibit the Village's placing of public notices on public places. 
(B)  The provisions of this chapter shall not prohibit the Village's distribution, by itself or by its agents, or posting of public notices, including handbills, concerning public emergencies, Public Works projects, maintenance of public facilities or other matters concerning public services, to or on private premises. 
(Ord. 3272, 1-26-1987; amd. Ord. 5196, 10-27-2003) 
Chapter 14 - COST RECOVERY FOR EMERGENCY SERVICES 

7-14-1. - Definitions. 
As used in this chapter, the following terms shall have the following meanings: 
FACILITY: Any building, structure, installation, equipment, pipe or pipeline, including, but not limited to, any pipe into a sewer or publicly owned treatment works, well, pond, lagoon, impoundment, ditch, landfill, storage container, tank, motor vehicle, truck trailer, rotting stock or aircraft; also, any site or area where a hazardous material has been deposited, stored, disposed of, abandoned, placed, or otherwise come to be located. 
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS: As defined by the United States department of transportation, including, but not limited to, any material, substance or mixture of materials or substances which are toxic, flammable, corrosive, explosive, carcinogenic or radioactive. 
PERSON: Any individual, business, firm, partnership, corporation, association, trust, estate, joint venture or other legal entity, or their legal representative, agent or assign. 
RELEASE: Any spilling, leaking, pumping, pouring, emitting, escaping, emptying, discharging, injecting, leaching, dumping or disposing of a hazardous material into or on any land, air, water, well, stream, sewer or pipe so that such hazardous material or any constituent thereof may enter the environment. 
REMEDIAL ACTION: Any action which is consistent with any permanent remedy and which is taken instead of, or in addition to, removal actions in the event of a release or threatened release of a hazardous material into the environment, to prevent or minimize the release of hazardous materials so that they do not migrate to cause a substantial present or potential hazard to human health, property or the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, such actions at the location of the release as storage, confinement, perimeter protection using dikes, trenches, or ditches, clay cover, neutralization, cleanup of released hazardous materials or contaminated materials, recycling or reuse, diversion, destruction, segregation of reactive wastes, repair or replacement of leaking containers, collection of leachate and runoff, on site treatment or incineration, provision of alternate water supplies, and any monitoring reasonably required to assure that such actions protect the public health and welfare and the environment. 
REMOVAL: The cleanup or removal of released hazardous materials from the environment; such actions as may be necessary or appropriate to monitor, assess, and evaluate the release or threat of release of hazardous materials; the disposal of removed material; or the taking of such action as may be necessary to prevent, minimize, or mitigate damage to the public health or welfare of the environment. The term includes, but is not limited to, security fencing, provision of alternative water supplies, and temporary evacuation of threatened individuals. 
RESPONSE: Any removal or remedial action or special rescue services. 
RESPONSIBLE PERSON: Any person who is deemed by the Village of Glen Ellyn to have caused or contributed to causing the incident or circumstances giving rise to the necessity of emergency response or such person who is responsible as defined or established by any statute or regulation of the State of Illinois or of the United States of America. 
SPECIAL RESCUE INCIDENT(S): Those incidents arising where vehicles or personnel of the Glen Ellyn Volunteer Fire Department or any other agency acting at the request of or in cooperation with the Village of Glen Ellyn provide special rescue services for the purposes of providing rescue services or support. 
SPECIAL RESCUE SERVICE(S): Services in high angle rescue, trench rescue, confined space rescue, and other rescue services performed by the Village of Glen Ellyn Volunteer Fire Company or any other agency at the request of or in cooperation with the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
(Ord. 5610, 9-24-2007) 
7-14-2. - Response authority. 
(A)  The Fire Chief or his /her designee shall have authority to respond to any incident requiring special rescue services or involving release or threatened release of hazardous materials within or into the Village or affecting the air or public water supply, wells or sewage treatment works serving the Village. This authority includes, but is not limited to, remedial action and removal or any special rescue services. 
(B)  The Fire Chief or designee, during such time as response authority is given to him /her, shall be authorized to utilize all department personnel and equipment and may in his /her sole discretion order any special rescue service or take such remedial or removal action as he /she may deem necessary or appropriate to respond to the incident or release or threatened release of hazardous material. 
(C)  All Village personnel shall cooperate with and operate under the direction of the Fire Chief or designee or response authority under this chapter until such time as the person exercising such response authority has determined that the response is complete or responsibility for response is assumed by the federal, state, or local public health, safety, or emergency agency having primary jurisdiction over the release or threatened release or special rescue incident. 
(D)  The person exercising response authority under this chapter shall coordinate and/or cooperate with other federal, state, or local public health, safety, or emergency agencies involved in response to the release or threatened release of hazardous materials or special rescue incident. 
(Ord. 5610, 9-24-2007) 
7-14-3. - Liability for costs. 
Notwithstanding any other provisions or rule of law, the Village of Glen Ellyn may charge the responsible party for hazardous materials removal or remediation and special rescue incident responses to the extent that such charges exceed the sum of $50.00 as follows: 
(A)  For each fire or ambulance vehicle responding to the scene: At a per vehicle, per hour rate as determined by the Village for the time that the presence of such vehicle was deemed necessary by the officer in charge of each response, with the time computed from dispatch to return to the station; 
(B)  For each firefighter or other emergency service personnel responding to the scene: At a per person, per hour rate as determined by the Village for the time that the presence of such person was deemed necessary by the officer in charge of each response, with the time computed from dispatch to return to the station; 
(C)  For expended materials other than fuel of vehicles: The actual costs incurred by the Village or other service provider for such materials or, if a portion of a unit of material is used, the cost to replace the unit of material; and 
(D)  For damaged or destroyed vehicles, portable equipment, or personal protection clothing or gear: The actual costs to repair such item or, if deemed unsafe or not feasible to repair such item, then for the full current cost of replacement of such item. This shall include personal fire protection equipment contaminated by any hazardous material or substance if deemed unsafe for further use in firefighting or rescue operations. 
(Ord. 5610, 9-24-2007) 
7-14-4. - Failure of responsible party to pay costs; collection proceedings. 
(A)  In the event that the responsible party fails to provide payment within 30 days of receipt of Village or Fire Department invoice or take requested actions related to a release or special rescue incident within the time limit directed by the Fire Chief or his /her designee, the Village may take actions pursuant to law to collect such amounts due, including all Village attorney fees and related legal costs. 
(B)  Charges for special rescue incident or removal or remedial action when rendered by the Village or a mutual aid company shall be as provided by those agencies. 
(Ord. 5610, 9-24-2007) 
Chapter 15 - ILLICIT DISCHARGE DETECTION AND ELIMINATION REGULATIONS 

7-15-1. - Authority and purpose. 
(A)  Statutory authority: 
1.  This chapter shall be known and cited as the Illicit Discharge Detection and Elimination Regulations of the Village of Glen Ellyn. 
2.  The Glen Ellyn Village Board promulgates these regulations pursuant to their authority to adopt ordinances regulating the quality of all stormwater runoff in channels, streams, and basins in Glen Ellyn, in accordance with the stormwater and floodplain regulations (stormwater regulations) of the Village of Glen Ellyn as adopted and amended from time to time. The stormwater regulations embody the Village's policy for management of stormwater quantity and quality. 
3.  The Village may promulgate and enforce these regulations pursuant to 65 Illinois Compiled Statutes 5 /1-2-1, 5 /11-12-12, 5 /11-30-2, 5 /11-30-8 and 5 /11-31-2 and such other authority as applicable. 
(B)  Purposes: 
1.  The purpose of this chapter is to protect and enhance water quality within the Village in a manner pursuant to and consistent with the federal water pollution control act (33 USC section 1251 et seq.) through the regulation of nonstormwater discharges to the storm drainage system. This chapter establishes methods for controlling the introduction of discharges other than those occurring as a direct result of precipitation and snowmelt into the municipal separate storm sewer system (MS4) and the storm drainage system in order to comply with requirements of the national pollutant discharge elimination system (NPDES) phase II permit process. Other purposes of this chapter include: 
(a)  To regulate the contribution of pollutants to the MS4 and the storm drainage system by nonstormwater discharges; and 
(b)  To prohibit illicit connections and discharges to the MS4 and the storm drainage system. 
2.  The purposes of this chapter are consistent with the stormwater regulations and advance the following objectives: 
(a)  Protect and enhance the quality, quantity, and availability of surface and ground water resources. 
(b)  Preserve and enhance existing aquatic and riparian environments and encourage restoration of degraded areas. 
(c)  Promote equitable, acceptable, and legal measures for stormwater management. 
(Ord. 5804, 10-26-2009) 
7-15-2. - Definitions. 
The following words and terms shall have the meanings set forth except where otherwise specifically indicated. Words and terms not defined shall have the meanings indicated by common dictionary definition. 
(A)  Interpretation of terms and words: The terms and words used herein shall be interpreted as follows: 
1.  Words used in the present tense include the future tense; and 
2.  Words used in the singular number include the plural number and words used in the plural number include the singular number; and 
3.  The words "shall", "will", and "must" are mandatory, not permissive; and 
4.  The phrase "Director" refers to the individual responsible for the enforcement.
